The smell of bhog, the chorus of pushpanjali from almost every household and the deluge of youngsters stepping out in their ethnic best — the festival that honours the goddess of wisdom — is celebrated with a lot of fervour. Besides the traditional norms, what’s also indispensable to Saraswati Puja is the colour yellow that signifies a fresh start and new bloom. We asked our Tollywood brigade about their fondest memories of Saraswati Puja, what plans they have for this year and why yellow is a sartorial mandate on the auspicious day. Here’s what they had to say...Saraswati Puja has always been special. My fondest memories revolve around going to invite other schools and colleges back in the day. Since we would also visit girls’ schools, the excitement knew no bounds! Now, I mostly spend a working Saraswati Puja. However, I do visit my in-laws’ place to attend puja. As for wearing yellow, I’ve always defied pre-set rules! So, the colour isn’t mandatory for me.Like every year, this year too there will be Saraswati Puja at my place. I prepare the bhog all by myself. I make it a point to wear a sari on this day and consciously try to stick to shades of yellow.— ArpitaSaraswati Puja has always been special. I still remember, my mother would buy a new set of yellow kurta pyjama for me and I’d ask, ‘Why do you get yellow clothes every year?’ To this she would always say, ‘Basanti pujo te holud porte hoye.’ And the tradition still continues, except that I prefer sunshine yellow over mustard! And since we have a puja at home, pushpanjali and bhog are a must. I also love seeing everyone wearing yellow today, especially the little girls who wear laal par holud sari.— YashThis year it’s a working Saraswati Puja for me as I’m shooting. Every year, I wear a kurta on the festive day. It’s not mandatory that it has to be in a yellow shade but I have always preferred the basanti hue above any other colour on Saraswati Puja.Although I’m busy promoting my upcoming film, I will certainly take out time to attend the Saraswati Puja hosted by a city production house. I will also attend the puja at my manager’s place. Every year, since my childhood, I wear a yellow attire on Saraswati Puja. I believe, yellow goes best with the festivities. All year round, we can wear clothes of our favourite colours, but on Saraswati Puja, it has to be yellow — at least for me! I will be wearing a yellow sari.This year I plan to head to a friend’s place in the evening for Saraswati Puja. Wearing yellow is a must on this day and the day is never complete unless I sport a sari. So, like every year, I will wear a traditional sari. I also love digging into pujor bhog. No matter who has cooked the bhog, it always tastes heavenly.— Paayel SarkarSaraswati Puja is one of my most favourite days of a year. Not only do I have a puja at home, I also visit my school at Salt Lake. It’s like a reunion of sorts with my schoolmates. After attending the puja at school, I will head out for lunch with my friends and spend hours indulging in delicious spread and adda. Visiting a mela every year near my school is also a must. I wear either a yellow tant or a Dhakai sari on Saraswati Puja and this year will be no different.— DarshanaBanik

Title: NPR faces fresh hurdle, Odisha and Bihar against seeking parents’ information
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

People at an awareness rally on CAA that was addressed by Union home minister Amit Shah at Kharauna Pokhar in ... Read More

PATNA/ BHUBANESWAR: The National Population Register updation process faced hurdles in Bihar and Odisha on Tuesday.

A month after rejecting any National Register of Citizens in Bihar, CM Nitish Kumar on Tuesday asked the Centre to remove the new questions related to the date and place of birth of parents in the NPR updation form as “they would create unnecessary confusion”. In Odisha, the Naveen Patnaik government said it has decided against asking these questions and the relevant column will be deleted from the form for the state.

Talking to reporters, Nitish said“If answering certain questions in the NPR is optional, then what is the need of asking those questions?” JD(U) will convey its opinion to the Centre, he added. On the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, he asserted that it is the Centre’s responsibility to implement it. He said the matter is now in SC and people should wait for its decision.

About the NPR, he said: “NPR has been there since 2011. It was reviewed in 2015 and it is being done again in 2020. But new questions added in it are likely to create confusionAdding new things to NPR, which can create confusion, is not required.”

On the optional questions in the NPR form, Nitish further said: “There is a provision in the new NPR questionnaire that if someone doesn’t want to answer a question, he will not be forced to do it. But even then, there will be a blank space in the questionnaire. This is creating confusion as people may think the blank space may create trouble for them in future, if NRC is to be implemented. Thus, we are of the view that the old format for NPR be followed to avoid unnecessary confusion.”

In Odisha, BJD’s Pinaki Mishra, after a meeting of MPs chaired by CM Patnaik, said, “The specified Column 13 (ii) of the NPR form will be deleted from the state NPR sheet.” As per instruction manual for the update of NPR-2020, column 13 (ii) seeks data on the place of birth of the applicants’ father and mother. The Centre has, however, clarified that filling this column is optional. He explained that the regional party — which faced flak from a section of citizens for supporting CAA in Parliament and for going ahead with the NPR update even as several non-BJP states opposed both — was always concerned about column 13 (ii).

Title: Women too should get command posts in Army, says Supreme Court
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Emphasising the need for change of mindset to treat women officers on par with men, the Supreme Court on Tuesday said suitability and competence should be the criteria in deciding command appointments within the Army and there should not be any gender discrimination.

Though a bench of Justices D Y Chandrachud and Ajay Rastogi appreciated the Centre for taking a “very positive step” in granting permanent commission to women officers, it asked why women are considered only for staff appointments and not command posts. “Test them on the same footing as men. Do not exclude them (women officers) as a class. Change of mindset is required,” the bench observed when senior advocate Aishwarya Bhatti and lawyer Meenakshi Lekhi, appearing for women officers, contended that not giving command appointments to women amounts to treating them as second class citizens within the Army.

Senior advocate R Balasubramanian and lawyer Neela Gokhale, appearing for the ministry of defence, contended that Army personnel work under very hostile conditions, particularly in forward areas. But their contention was opposed by the women officers and they told the bench that there are many instances of women officers performing their duty successfully in adverse conditions and pointed out that one such officer Archana had created bunker at the front-line during the Kargil War . The bench said that it may not direct the government to give command appointments to women officers but it would ask them to consider them on the basis of suitability and competence. The arguments would resume next week. It said the court would examine the plea of women officers in Air Force and Navy separately.

Title: Coronavirus: Special camps in Nepal border areas
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: The state health department on Tuesday issued a slew of directives, including providing personal protection equipment (PPE) to civil surgeons in all 38 districts and setting up medical camps in Nepal border areas as preventive measures against deadly coronavirus “Medical hospitals across the state have been instructed to give PPE, medicines and masks to patients with symptoms similar to that of coronavirus,” state surveillance officer Dr Ragini Mishra, who is also the and nodal officer for coronavirus, told this newspaper.The department has decided to set up medical camps and enhance surveillance in bordering districts of Nepal, with special vigil in Jogbani, Forbesganj and Raxaul. Besides, polio teams have been advised to be active in the border areas.The department has also asked the district magistrates to spread awareness about the virus and take the help of panchayats and anganwadi and healthcare workers.“All passengers travelling from the affected countries are undergoing thermal screening at the Gaya international airport,” she said.Meanwhile, doctors at PMCH claimed that the 29-year-old Chhapra woman with symptoms similar to that of coronavirus is fine. The research scholar, who returned from Tianjin in China, was admitted to the isolation ward of PMCH on Monday.“She has no major medical ailment. But I can’t say anything until I get her medical reports from Pune virology lab,” PMCH medical superintendent Bimal Kumar Karak said.A close relative of the woman said she is just suffering from a viral fever, which is common during winter. “We are waiting for her reports to arrive, after which we will take her home,” he said.

Title: ‘Automated driving test centre likely by September-end’
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

PATNA: As things are going hi-tech, even driving test centres in the state capital will soon be automatic. Those seeking driving licences will have to undergo test through sensors and high-definition closed-circuit cameras on an especially designed track.

As of now, applicants undergo driving test near Golghar and at Phulwarisharif in Patna where a motor vehicle inspector (MVI) takes the test manually.

Transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said three acres of Bihar State Road Transport Corporation (BSRCT) land have been earmarked at Phulwarisharif to set up an automated driving test centre , which will be ready by September. The Central Institute of Road Transport (CIRT) will develop this centre.

Agarwal said the decision was taken to do away with malpractices in granting driving licences. He further said once this automated driving test centre is ready, people will not have to wait for their turn as at least 300 applicants can be tested in a day, while manually only around 150-200 people can undergo tests daily.

For both the two-wheelers and four-wheelers, there will be certain set norms which applicants have to fulfil and then only they will be given driving licences. Those who fail the test will have to come again after a week.

The applicants for four-wheelers will have to undergo six stages of test, which include reverse driving, figure of 8, overtaking, traffic junction, parallel parking and uphill drive. All the stages will have a set time period for completion and in a few of them one or two hits will be relaxed. For two-wheelers, an applicant will have to undergo three stages of test, which include straight driving on a ramp, followed by driving on serpentine route and then for applying emergency break.

Agarwal said such automated driving test centres will also come up at Aurangabad and Muzaffarpur in Bihar. While in Aurangabad, the department has set the target to get it ready by June, the one at Muzaffarpur will get ready by the year-end.

Title: India Inc needs to brace for rising employee activism
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

By James Agrawal

Employee activism is a relatively new phenomenon, observed in big ticket IT companies like Google and Amazon over the last few years. In an age termed to be one of activism, does employee activism need to be looked at seriously? This is not an easy question to answer because of the unpredictability of the nature of activism. But you can’t ignore and push it to become a reactive crisis management topic. HR managers need to start somewhere and evolve a policy along the way that aligns corporate goals with those of the employee.

Employee activism can be looked at as an extension of the unions that fought for their rights — like fair pay and reasonable work hours. It widens the ambit to include employees raising their voice to be heard on issues like environmental pollution, inclusive workplaces and, in some instances, even company business decisions. With the decreasing influence of unions across the world, employees are now organising based on common interests to engage in protests.

What has also changed now from unions to activists is the visibility of the protests. With internet proliferation and social media activism, a large-scale protest only takes a few minutes to be all over the news, worldwide. This can turn into a PR nightmare with the company’s brand value at stake. Corporate email and memo leaks have also embarrassed many companies, especially when confidential data is leaked.

In November 2018, 20,000 Google employees staged a walkout to protest against the management protecting highly placed executives accused of sexual harassment. In April 2019, employees at Google again voiced their opinion against Google working with the government on US military projects. Amazon also got a taste of this activism in September last year, when hundreds of employees walked out of Amazon offices to support a global ‘climate strike’. The employees were part of a group named ‘Amazon employees for climate justice’ who were and are trying to influence Amazon to decrease its carbon footprint worldwide.

These companies took note and tried to address the concerns of the employees. Google decided not to go ahead with the US military project. Amazon initiated a ‘climate pledge’, promising to decrease carbon emissions in its operations globally. There are many more such examples from technology companies in the US — Microsoft, Facebook and WeWork — which have dealt with employee activism. So, is this kind of activism only seen in large tech firms with a highly educated workforce and only in the US?

HR experts say that though the scale of activism is nowhere near what has been witnessed in the US, employee activism is all set to soar in all companies — tech or non-tech, big or small. Companies in India will also have to gear up to address activism with a well-thought out strategy. Almost 50% of India’s workforce today comes from the ‘millennial’ generation, born between 1980 and 2000. The research on ‘millennials’ indicates that they want their jobs to mean more than just jobs. Most of them would like to work for companies that align with the values they uphold in their daily life.

With social media, opinions are everywhere and knowledge just a few clicks away. Trends from across the world are easy to follow even in remote locations and opinions can be mobilised quickly through 140-character tweets. We are already seeing a change with CEO activism, where leaders are stepping out of their comfort zone to take a stand on current issues — political or otherwise. This is a huge shift from a traditional corporate environment that did not believe in protesting of any sort.

HR should be ready with a strategy on activism to understand how it can be encouraged to further company goals. This will add value to companies that are looking to engage with customers by being more socially responsible. Many of them like to be seen as having values that allow them to grow profitably without compromising on ethics. Drawing out an employee activism framework will help companies in enhancing their overall reputation. Here are some guidelines that can help HR in starting out:

* Listen to employees: Establish processes where employees can reach out to communicate issues that concern them. Employees should be able to talk without fear of any backlash. Sometimes issues can be solved by the senior management being clued into what the popular opinion is. Having an open channel for communicating helps in solving issues faster too.

* Framing values with actionable items: Organisational values need to be spelled out clearly with a plan of action. Just talking about values without actually walking the talk will not help. Say, an organisation believes that ethics are important for it to operate, then it should be also ready to be questioned by employees on that front.

* Establishing a response protocol with dos and don’ts: With social media usually at the forefront of employee activism, lack of a proper response strategy will leave you staring at a problem much bigger than it actually is. HR should be proactive in communicating upfront on how the company will deal with issues that concern employees, so that issues can be addressed internally first. It is also important to list things that you consider non-negotiable. For example, companies can state that employees who leak confidential documents online will incur penal action.

* Building flexibility into the policy: While drafting this policy, HR should be flexible enough to change it as and when required. The unpredictable nature of activism will give rise to many a scenario that companies don’t foresee. Keep communications transparent and open, so feedback can be incorporated to improve on the go.

Initiating this exercise and having an open approach will help in developing an organisation-wide culture towards activism. Over time, this can help build goodwill and foster an environment of collaboration among employees. An approachable leadership will make employees feel engaged to contribute to the company.

This is an opportunity to build a company that actually reaches out to employees who want to be part of a good work environment. Even if an actual instance of activism could be further away, starting conversations around the topic will give companies an edge in this age of activism.

(The writer is MD, BTI Executive Search )

Title: Travel planners tweak offers as demand dips for summer holidays
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Chennai: The global economic situation coupled with recent mishaps like Australian bushfire, breakout of coronavirus in China, many travellers are either delaying their holiday plans, or cancelling them completely, giving indications of a tepid demand this summer.

Despite unfavourable situations making it tough to decide on whether to take a holiday or not, travel planners are putting their best foot forward. From lowering deposit rates at time of booking a holiday, cheaper EMIs, offering bonus holidays on the next trip, extending the number of tour days, travel planners are trying ways to push demand for this summer holiday season.

“On packages for European countries priced at 1 lakh and above, we always collected deposits between the range of Rs 50,000-Rs 60,000 per person at the time of booking, which is now lowered to Rs 30,000-Rs 35,000. For non-European packages it is reduced from Rs 30,000 to Rs 20,000 per person. Moreover, for every booking to the US or European countries, customers will get four free extra days on their next trip valid till September, 2020,” Daniel D’souza, president and country head, leisure, SOTC Travel, said. A Chennai-based curated travel planner, Pickyourtrail has seen more customers cancelling their booking due to the virus outbreak in China. “Our average cancellation rate of 2%-3% has increased to 10% owing to the ‘corona’ outbreak in China and its repercussions. We now estimate cancellations to go up to 15%, depending on how changes in customer sentiment and changing situation in South East Asia,” said Hari Ganapathi, co-founder, Pickyourtrail. The online travel planner also recorded many opting for Sri Lanka and Maldives as alternate destinations for China. Pickyourtrail has also rolled out packages to Japan where a five-night trip is extended to an eight-night trip, besides adding more cities on its itinerary. Rajeev Kale, president and country head (Holiday, MICE, Visa) of Thomas Cook (India) said “We have recently launched ‘Ek Ka Teen’ offer to encourage Indian travellers to book their annual summer vacation as well and avail of two micro-cations at the price of one.”

Title: Parekh holds just 0.07% in HDFC that he helped build
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Mumbai: HDFC chairman Deepak Parekh holds only 0.07% in HDFC, the corporation that he helped build over four decades and which currently has a market capitalisation of Rs 4.2 lakh crore.

Addressing entrepreneurs in his speech at the TiEcon Mumbai 2020 event, Parekh said, “In the truest sense, I am not an entrepreneur, though I always felt like one and managed the company like it belonged to me 100%.”

While HDFC was founded by Parekh’s uncle H T Parekh in 1977 after his retirement, it was Deepak Parekh who is credited with having built the organisation into the mortgage giant that it is today.

“I have been in the company for 42 years now. I joined as an employee and retired as executive chairman in 2009, and since then have been the non-executive chairman. My shareholding in the company is only through employee stock options, which have been given to each employee,” said Parekh. He added that he has not drawn a salary for the last 11 years though he come to work every day.

Speaking on leadership qualities, Parekh asked his audience to ensure that the trait of humility sticks like glue. “Secondly, don’t do anything that you would be embarrassed if it came in the newspaper. Remember, there is no softer pillow to rest your head at night than a clear conscience,” he said.

He urged the entrepreneurs to have a value-based work culture through demonstration from the top to the lowest level.

Title: Patna: Eco-friendly Saraswati idols in demand
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

A woman buys an idol of Goddess Saraswati from a shop on Bailey Road in Patna

PATNA: People, especially students, across the city are ready to celebrate Saraswati Puja with traditional fervour and religious gaiety on Thursday.

As Goddess Saraswati is the deity of wisdom and learning, youngsters celebrate it on Basant Panchami with utmost enthusiasm and zeal. From setting up ‘pandals’, putting idols of Goddess Saraswati and organising cultural activities, youngsters across the city celebrate the festival with devotion and fervour.

Pandal samitis claimed they have made all necessary arrangements. Patna district magistrate Kumar Ravi has already issued directives for immersion of idols only in the artificial ponds made on the river banks.

City-based priest Kanhaiya Upadhyay said Saraswati Puja marks the beginning of spring. “The festival is celebrated on the fifth day of ‘Maagh’ as per the Hindu calendar. It is believed that offering fruits and ‘abir’ to Goddess Saraswati on Basant Panchami brings knowledge and wisdom. Many students place their books in front of the Goddess’ idol and pray to the deity for excelling in studies.”

He added: “People even decorate their houses with yellow flowers and wear bright yellow clothes. They also eat yellow coloured sweets and fruits.”

Shreya, a student of Magadh Mahila College, said they will organize cultural activities like dance, songs and skits on the occasion. “We have also planned to dress up in vibrant shades of yellow,” she said Shreya.

Several Patnaites have also opted for ecofriendly ways of celebrating the festival. Akshat Raj, a Class VII student of a private school in Kadamkuan area, said he and his friends have made an eco-friendly idol with clay. “Idols of Goddess Saraswati available in the market are either made of mud or plaster of paris. Those made of plaster of paris contain several chemicals like sulphur, gypsum and phosphorus, which are toxic and release harmful components when immersed in water,” he said.

Title: AIIMS-Digha elevated road: One flank to be ready for traffic in February
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

The flyover is coming up on the south side approach road of Digha rail-cum-road bridge

PATNA: One flank of the upcoming AIIMS-Digha elevated road will be open for vehicular movement from February-end. The 11.9km-long road, which has a two-lane semi-elevated road from AIIMS-Patna and four-lane on the remaining stretch, is expected to be completed in March.

Elevated road apart, officials said final touches were also being given to 1.25km-long flyover, which is a part of the 12.27km- long two-lane road underneath the elevated road along Digha-Danapur canal road from AIIMS to Digha. The flyover is targeted to become functional for vehicular traffic from February 15.

The flyover is coming up on the south side approach road of Digha rail-cum-road bridge. Being made with an estimated outlay of Rs157.14 crore, the road will serve people coming from Phulwarisharif or AIIMS and going to JP Setu and Digha.

“Motorists from AIIMS or Phulwarisharif have to take quite a few turns while going to JP Setu. The flyover will ease pressure on Gandhi Maidan-Danapur road as it would provide direct connectivity to those going to JP Setu,” said Sanjay Kumar Agarwal, managing director of Bihar State Road Development Corporation Limited (BSRDCL).

“Heavy vehicles coming from Naubatpur and Phulwarisharif side create jam on the Digha-Khagaul canal road. The new flyover will solve that problem,” he added.

Meanwhile, 98% of the work on the Digha-AIIMS elevated road is complete. The project entailing an expenditure of Rs1,231.06 crore was initially targeted to be completed by March 2018. However, sources said it got delayed owing to financial issued faced by the constructing agency.

Another major reason for the delay was construction of a railway overbridge (RoB) at Khagaul. Officials at BSRDCL said th construction of RoB will commence soon. “We have recently got a no-objection certificate (NOC) from railways for construction of the RoB on the eastern side of existing one at Khagaul,” an official said.

Meanwhile, commuters are happy that the elevated road as well as a flyover will be available for traffic soon. “I face traffic jams nearly everyday while going to Digha. I hope to enjoy a seamless driving in the coming months following commencement of vehicular movement on the AIIMS-Digha elevated road,” said Amit Kumar of Mustafapur.

Title: Bihar CM Nitish Kumar to open three-day Bodh Mahotsava beginning today
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Nitish Kumar

GAYA: Mathura MP and ‘Dream Girl’ of yesteryears Hema Malini, will perform at the inaugural day of the three-day-long ‘ Bodh Mahotsava ’ beginning today (Wednesday). The event will be inaugurated by chief minister Nitish Kumar in the iconic Kalchakra Maidan to the north west of Mahabodhi Temple, the seat of Buddha’s enlightenment.

Bodh Mahotsav is held every winter to promote tourism. The then PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee inaugurated the first Bodh Mahotsav in the year 1998. As per the event format, artists from nine countries including Japan, Laos, Myanmar and Bhutan will perform at the event. According to district magistrate Abhishek Singh, local artists too will get the opportunity to show their talent.

Elaborate security arrangements have been made for the event. About 2000 police personnel of different ranks have been deputed to maintain law and order during the mega event. According to SSP Rajeev Mishra, Bodh Gaya has been divided into seven sectors for effective policing. Kalchakra Maidan too has been divided into four parts. Adequate number of CCTV cameras have been installed.

Kalchakra Maidan, it may be recalled, was targetted by Bangladesh-based terror outfit Jamaitul Mujahedden in January 2018. The outfit had engineered a low intensity IED blast in the Maidan.

Bodh Gaya watchers believe that in view of the Corona virus and ongoing anti-CAA protests in different parts of the country, foreign tourists footfall may remain low. Tourism department is yet to evolve a mechanism to make a head count of foreigners visiting Bodh Gaya.

According to Suresh Singh, president of the Bodh Gaya Nagar Vikas Manch, the protests have not affected visitors from Buddhist countries but very few tourists from Europe and USA have come recently and this was a matter of concern for Bodh Gaya’s tourist-centric economy. “Bodh Gaya economy is yet to recover from the impact of liquor prohibition,” he said.

Conceding that Corona virus as well as security concerns of the tourists will affect the footfall in Bodh Gaya, hospitality sector expert Arun Kumar Ojha said the virus factor was more worrisome. As per rough estimate more than 100 mainland Chinese are present in Bodh Gaya and an effective strategy was required to address the genuine concerns of the visitors.

However, civil surgeon Dr BK Singh said he does not have information about the presence of Chinese nationals in Bodh Gaya. “The employees of the Airports Authority of India (AAI) have been sensitised and a 20-bed isolation ward was in place at the Anugrah Narain Magadh Medical College Hospital (ANMMCH),” said Dr Singh. The CS evaded the issue of the installation of the much-needed thermal scanner at the airport.

Title: Bihar: LNMU moves apex court for preponing BEd entrance exam
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Lalit Narayan Mithila University

DARBHANGA: The Lalit Narayan Mithila University (LNMU) has moved the Supreme Court for preponing the date of BEd entrance examination scheduled from April 20-25 to March 29, to ensure that admission test results and the academic session can commence within the stipulated time frame.

The Raj Bhavan has made LNMU the nodal agency for conducting combined entrance test (CET) for admission to BEd course in 15 universities of the state through regular and distance modes as well as Shiksha Shastri (equivalent of BEd course taught in Darbhanga-based Kameshwar Singh Darbhanga Sanskrit University) for the academic session 2020-2022 as per the Supreme Court guidelines.

The university has appointed Prof Ajit Kumar Singh, commerce department, as the state nodal officer (SNO) and constituted a seven-member core committee.

Professor Singh said, “As per the Supreme Court guidelines, the publication of advertisement for entrance test for B Ed course should be on February 1, followed by the exam between April 20 and 24, declaration of results between May 25 and 30 and commencement of the academic session on July1 every year.

“However, since the counselling of selected students through CET in all universities will take more time and the guidelines of the apex court with regard to the last date of admission stipulated as June 28 may not be adhered to, hence the LNMU has moved the SC to prepone the date of examination from April 20-25 to March 29,” he said.

Singh added: “The preponement will help all the 15 universities to publish their results on April 15 and complete the process within the stipulated time frame.

LNMU’s advocate has already filed a petition in this regard with a copy of the tentative schedule of CET prepared by the university.”

The nodal officer also said that all the 15 universities have been asked to nominate one nodal officer for communication with LNMU and furnish the list of BEd colleges under their jurisdiction, out of which 11 have replied.

“Soon after the Supreme Court verdict, LNMU will notify the advertisement for the entrance test on February 1,” Singh said

Title: Two detained in group clash during Republic Day Tiranga Yatra
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

KANPUR: Panic prevailed in Govindnagar area of the city after two groups resorted to stone pelting and hurled ‘sutli -bombs’ (firecrackers) during Tiranga Yatra on the occasion of Republic Day on Sunday.

Police have detained two persons and seized five motorcycles abandoned on the spot.

According to sources, a group near Ram Lila ground in Gujaini’s A block under the limits of Govindnagar police station took out a procession carrying Tricolour on Sunday morning.

Meanwhile, another group carrying out Tiranga Yatra from Barra by-pass area also reached there and asked them to give passage leading to a verbal dual. Soon the situation took an ugly turn and both the groups started pelting stones on each other.

Someone from the clashing mob hurled ‘sutli -bombs’ triggering panic in the area.

Circle officer Manoj Gupta, along with police force reached the spot and and detained two suspects. “We have detained two suspects and they are being questioned. Also, we have seized five motorcycles,” he said.

The situation was under control. Additional force from adjoining areas has been deployed in the affected areas to keep a tight vigil, said the CO.

Title: HC summons UGC secretary on Rs 287 crore disbursal to colleges
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

PATNA: The Patna high court on Tuesday ordered University Grants Commission (UGC) secretary to physically appear on February 11 and explain the manner in which Rs287 crore was disbursed to several colleges and educational institutes in state since 2007.

The division bench of Chief Justice Sanjay Karol and Justice Mohit Kumar Shah was hearing a PIL filed by Veteran Forum for Transparency in Public Life. The petitioner alleged funds embezzlement and pleaded for an inquiry by some independent agency like CBI as no utilization certificate was submitted against the sum disbursed. The petitioner also sought direction to the authorities concerned to recover the entire amount on the ground of its defalcation.

The entire amount was allocated in phases from 2007 to 2017.

The UGC, however, apprised the high court that it had received utilization certificates against Rs122 crore, but did not submit the details.

Petitioner counsel Dinu Kumar submitted that spot verification was required to ascertain that the funds were actually and properly utilized or not as certificates were submitted after several years.

On December 12, the high court had directed the UGC to file a composite affidavit within three weeks’ time indicating the manner in which Rs287 crore was disbursed to several colleges in state. The HC had ordered that UGC secretary would have to remain present if he failed to comply with the order.

The matter was again taken up for hearing on January 9. The high court again granted two weeks’ time and fixed January 27 as the next date for hearing, reiterating that the secretary would have to physically appear before court in case of failure to comply with the order.

On October 18 last year, the high court observed that the records did not reflect whether the money had been properly utilized or had gone waste.

Title: PMC board approves RTPS counters in all circles
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

PATNA: The Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) board on Tuesday approved altogether 12 proposals amid a spat between mayor Sita Sahu and former deputy mayor Vinay Kumar Pappu over not including in the agenda development schemes like ‘Nali-Gali’ and ‘Har Ghar Nal Ka Jal’ schemes as well as installation of borewells in a few wards.

Pappu tore the agenda copy to shreds and asked the ward councillors to boycott the meeting. He told this newspaper that the empowered standing committee at its meeting held in November 2019 had also approved the inclusion of development schemes in only those wards in which the councillors support the mayor.

“We will not accept such favouritism. The development schemes should be implemented in all wards,” he said, adding that the PMC board meetings had been postponed several times over the past few months.

Mayor Sahu, on the other hand, said the meeting could not be held due to the engagement of municipal commissioner and other officers in other official works.

Refuting the allegations of favouritism in sanctioning development projects, Sahu said: “If he had some issue, he should have raised it in the meeting. Tearing the meeting agenda would do no good. Such behaviour will not be tolerated.”

Amid the chaos, the ward councillors passed all the agendas, including setting up RTPS (Right to Public Services) counters in all five circles of PMC.

Besides, approval was given to a proposal for termination of contract of two private firms, which provided around 2,000 sanitation workers in Bankipore and Patna City circles.

The mayor said the two other empanelled agencies would look after these two circles, unless more agencies are outsourced for cleaning and other sanitation works. “Other proposals approved in the meeting included setting up workshop in all six circles for maintenance and repair of twin garbage tipper vehicles,” she said.

The other proposals included segregation of wet and dry waste at secondary garbage point, Jal-Jeevan-Hariyali, maintenance of electric crematorium, providing basic amenities on the Ganga riverfront and plan for maintenance of interstate bus terminal among others.

Title: PMC to reply on Boring Canal Road vending zones
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

PATNA: The Patna high court on Tuesday sought reply from the Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) on provisions for creating vending zones on the covered drainage in the middle of Boring Canal Road from Hartali Mor to Rajapur pul.

The bench of Chief Justice Sanjay Karol and Justice Mohit Kumar Shah was hearing a PIL filed by one Raj Kumar Agarwal, who pleaded that the drain would not be cleaned even if required and get chocked if vending zones are created over it. He also submitted that there was no provision under The Street Vendors Act, 2014 to provide such a place for roadside vendors. The space was earlier used as parking space for vehicles.

The court granted four weeks’ time to the corporation to reply after the petitioner asked when was the notification issued and if any map had been approved for creating vending zones there. He further asked the PMC when any such committee was formed for taking the decision.

State’s reply sought on leprosy patients: The Patna high court on Tuesday directed the state government to file a counter affidavit apprising it of the action taken for the well-being of leprosy patients living in hutments at Ram Nagar in Khagaul under The Persons with Disabilities (Equal opportunities, protection of rights and full participation) Act, 1995.

A division bench of Chief Justice Sanjay Karol and Justice Mohit Kumar Shah was hearing a PIL filed by an NGO, which pleaded for an alternate arrangement for the leprosy patients living in miserable condition in temporary hutments at Ram Nagar Kusht Ashram as they were being asked to vacate the area by circle officer for the construction of an overbridge there.

The high court directed the state government to file its reply before the next hearing on February 4. If the order is not complied with, the director (empowerment of persons with disabilities) of social welfare department would have to physically appear before the bench. Gautam Kumar Kejriwal appeared for the petitioner while Prashant Pratap represented the state.

At least 40 leprosy patients with family members reside in the area beside a drainage for the last several years. They have been asked to vacate the place because an overbridge is to be constructed there

Title: Int’l meet to promote CSR
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Hyderabad: In an attempt to provide a platform for deliberations in the field of corporate social responsibility (CSR) and to discuss government's efforts in encouraging CSR activities, the Institute of Public Enterprise ( IPE ) will conduct 6th International CSR conference on Jan 30 and 31.

"The conference will focus on how CSR is driving business performance. Awards will be given for CSR efforts at grassroot levels. More than 40 companies will participate," said R K Mishra, Director, IPE in the city on Tuesday. TNN

Title: Banks approve reduced fees for UPI, RuPay
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Digbijay Mishra & Rachel Chitra | TNN

Bengaluru: Banks have decided that they will not charge a part of the fees on Unified Payments Interface ( UPI ) and RuPay card transactions as long as the merchant discount rate ( MDR ) remains zero following the government announcement, three people aware of the matter said. After a letter from the Indian Banks’ Association (IBA) on removing entire fees on these transactions, which would have meant significant revenue loss for its owner National Payments Corporation of India ( NPCI ), the two parties have reached an understanding for now.

The move was discussed and approved in the NPCI steering committee meeting on Monday, said the sources mentioned earlier. TOI reported in its January 24 edition, saying IBA had asked NPCI to remove multiple charges like interchange fees, payments service provider ( PSP ) fee and switching fees. “Interchange will be zero is what was decided in yesterday’s meeting. NPCI is still reviewing other fees, but it is against making those fees to nil,” one of the people mentioned earlier said.

For context, a bank, which used to get MDR from merchants for facilitating the payments, would pay interchange fees to the issuer bank and then pay a switching fee to the network — NPCI — along with a fee to PSPs like PhonePe or GooglePay. NPCI, according to sources, is unwilling to make additional fees like switching and PSP fees to zero as it will hit its revenue, and growth of UPI, which has clocked over 1 billion transactions per month since October 2019.

This comes at a time when e-payments firms are reeling under pressure due to zero MDR and are looking at the government for a breather. But it might only come “after a few weeks or months”, sources involved in discussions with the government on the matter added. The move will impact the fast-paced growth of digital payments infrastructure in India and the ease of use in promoting digital payments as the key revenue channel of PSPs will be hit. As reported on January 10, annual revenue loss could be to the tune of Rs 1,800 crore due to zero MDR.

Banks could also look at other avenues to shore up revenues as well by passing the cost to consumers. “It is possible that the banks might try to make up for the revenue loss from zero MDR by increasing charges on cash withdrawals. The RBI only mandates that the first three transactions in six metro locations are free. In non-metros it’s first five. The charges on other transactions are left to the individual bank’s discretion,” said an IBA official. Most banks already have stopped ATM expansion and might also allocate less money towards PoS (point-of-sale) expansion. With MDR becoming zero, it was inevitable that the interchange fee also becomes zero, industry experts said after IBA’s letter last week. “This is how it works — nearly 60% of MDR goes towards the acquiring bank (the bank facilitating the transaction) and 40% of MDR towards the issuing bank (the bank issuing the debit card). And of this, the issuer bank pays 15% as the interchange fee. So paying the interchange fee becomes an additional cost or loss for the issuing bank if MDR is zero,” says Balasubramanian V, president, merchant and terminal business of payments service provider FSS. Banks will continue to pay switching fees, he added.

Title: Sensex tanks 188 pts over Wuhan woes
Content: Mumbai: Spooked by the spread of coronavirus from Wuhan , China and its likely impact on global trade, the sensex lost another 188 points on Tuesday to close below the 41K level for the first time in three weeks. The fears about the likely impact of coronavirus also spooked other Asian markets. Korea’s benchmark index was the most affected while the Chinese market remained closed under government orders.After opening higher, the sensex lost ground towards the close of session to touch an intraday low of 40,870 points and closed about 100 points off that level at 40,967. The Nifty too closed 63 points lower at 12,056. After the global trend of risk-off trades, meaning not buying high-risk assets like equities and derivatives, in India too foreign funds remained big sellers with a net outflow of Rs 1,358 crore, while domestic funds were net buyers at Rs 712 crore, BSE data showed.According to an SBI report that draws parallels with the spread of 2003’s SARS epidemic in South Asian countries, the impact of the new epidemic on trade is yet to be estimated. However, it noted that the novel coronavirus has spread at a much faster pace than SARS, which had affected global trade by about $57 billion at current rates. “The impact of the outbreak on China will be severe as Wuhan is the hub of transport and industry for central China,” Soumya Kanti Ghosh , group chief economic adviser, SBI, said in the report.In Tuesday’s trade, Bharti Airtel, Tata Steel and RIL were the top losers while strong buying in HDFC and Bajaj Finance cushioned the fall. Of the 30 sensex constituents, 21 closed in the red while nine closed with gains.

Title: HDFC Bank to add 125 new branches in TN by 2022
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Chennai: Privately-owned HDFC Bank, on Tuesday, announced plans to add 125 more branches in Tamil Nadu in the next two years. “We will follow our national strategy of placing over 50% of new branches planned in semi-urban and rural space, and aim to mark our presence in Tier-3 places such as Mannargudi and Ambasamudram. This move will create employment opportunities to 1,000 to 1,500 people,” said R Suresh, zonal head of Tamil Nadu, HDFC Bank. However, the bank said it had no plans to add any new ATMs with these new branches. It has installed over 100 Cash Deposit Machines in the state so far. The private bank’s Tamil Nadu business holds a market share of 9%. The bank has about 284 branches and 1,172 ATMs in the stateTN as of December 31, 2019. The Bank also stated that it has achieved a business milestone of Rs 1.5 lakh crore in the state as of September 30, 2019, comprising about Rs 89,000 crore advances and Rs 62,000 crore deposits.

Title: Goa: Opa treatment plant may face water scarcity
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

The new 27MLD water treatment plant at Opa, which was commissioned recently, may face water scarcity for anoth... Read More

PONDA: Those dependent on the new 27MLD water treatment plant at Opa , which was commissioned recently, may face water scarcity for another year.

With the new plant, water drawn from the Khandepar river has increased. However, the river may not get raw water from the Ganjem water scheme over the Mhadei river if the PWD further delays permission for road cutting from Ganjem to Usgao to lay a pipeline that would pour the water from Ganjem directly into the Khandepar river.

PWD minister Deepak Pauskar said that he has already cleared the file and chief minister Pramod Sawant has also directed PWD authorities to clear it immediately. “WRD would get the permission very soon,” he said.

For the last several years, Ganjem water had been released into a rivulet flowing to Khandepar. However, some of the water was lost due to evaporation in the summer and ground seepage. The WRD had, therefore, planned to pour the water directly into the Khandepar river by underground pipeline to avoid the loss.

“Under the project, the work for laying the pipelines from Usgao to Khandepar has been going on, but the work has been delayed as PWD is yet to give permission for the road cutting,” a source from WRD said.

During summers, the water level of the Khandepar river dips and WRD pours about 35MLD water into the river besides releasing the stocked water from the bandharas along the Khandepar and Kalay rivers, and mining pits in Codli . Around 48MLD water is released from the Selaulim dam as well.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: Five more from Hyderabad kept in isolation
Content:
A central government team during its visit to Fever hospital on Tuesday

HYDERABAD: Five more people from Hyderabad were put in isolation at Fever Hospital on Tuesday. Of the five other cases that were reported in the past few days, two have tested negative, while the other three are being monitored at home as they have not shown any symptoms after initially reporting fever.Health authorities said that the five latest cases are people who returned from China last week and walked into the hospital with complaints of fever. Names of the cities they visited, have however, not been disclosed.They have currently been kept under observation. Depending on their symptoms, officials said, it will be decided whether their swab samples will be sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) Pune for testing for the novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV).Dr K Shankar, superintendent Fever Hospital, said: “Three members of a family — husband, wife and their daughter — returned from China a week ago. They came to the hospital around 2.30pm and have been put under observation in the isolation ward. They have reported with cold and fever and are stable. We are closely monitoring their condition if their symptoms are persistent we will take their swab samples and send for testing.”Apart from the three, two more people who had visited China in the last week approached the hospital authorities on Tuesday evening and was put in the isolation ward. With the five new suspected cases, the total number of people who had been suspected for Coronavirus in the city have touched ten now, of which five have already been declared clear.Those cleared are being monitored by rapid response teams and surveillance teams of Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) in the state.Meanwhile, one of the person who had travelled to Wuhan and was previously admitted to the hospital but tested negative, came back with symptoms of gastric problem. The patient was tested and sent back on Tuesday evening.

Title: Rakesh Jhunjhunwala comes under Sebi lens for insider trades
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Rakesh Jhunjhunwala

MUMBAI: Billionaire investor Rakesh Jhunjhunwala , some of his family members and associates are being investigated by Sebi in connection with their purchase of a stake of about 7.7% in Aptech in 2016, for suspected insider trading. The family has management control in the IT education company and the stake for which the people are being investigated was purchased between January and September of that year.

Jhunjhunwala, along with his brother Rajesh, wife Rekha, sister Sudha and mother-in-law Sushiladevi Gupta were summoned by Sebi last week. According to BSE data, while Jhunjhunwala had purchased 7 lakh shares of Aptech between August 9 and September 7, 2016 through off-market transactions, his wife had bought nearly 5.3 lakh shares and his brother bought 2.5 lakh shares. It also showed a transfer of 14.9 lakh shares of the company from Aptech Investments to Rekha, classified as inter-se transfer, meaning the transaction was between related parties.

Other than Jhunjhunwala and his family members, a close associate of the CEO of his investment firm RARE Enterprises was also called by Sebi, along with some employees of the firm, sources confirmed.

It was in 2005 when Jhunjhunwala had first bought into Aptech and thereafter he continued to increase his stake in the company. As of December 2019, he, along with his family members and associates, had a 49.4% stake, BSE data showed.

Jhunjhunwala, known for his stock-picking skills, is best known for his winning bets on Titan and Crisil. Recently he also bought into the struggling lender Yes Bank.

Title: Bihar government okays Rs 10 lakh loan for EBC entrepreneurs
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: The state government on Tuesday reworked three schemes to benefit the extremely backward castes (EBCs), including payment of Rs10 lakh to the willing entrepreneurs from these sections to start their choice business ventures.

Cabinet secretariat department principal secretary Deepak Prasad said the cabinet approved the proposal to increase the range of annual family income from the existing Rs1.50 lakh to Rs2.50 lakh for the EBC students to make the post-matric scholarship available to them.

Under the third scheme, the hostels for EBC students would now be constructed in six more districts — Lakhisarai, Samastipur, Darbhanga, Khagaria, Siwan and Vaishali, Prasad added.

Giving the details of the scholarship and hostel related schemes, welfare department secretary Prem Singh Meena said at present 2 lakh EBC students belonging to families with Rs1.5 lakh annual family income were getting the post-matric scholarships. With the increase in the income bracket to Rs2.50 lakh, there would be 25% more beneficiaries. While the revised scheme would be implemented from the current financial year itself, the students concerned would file their applications online for processing their claims.

Meena also said under the Jannayak Karpoori Thakur Chhatravas Yojana, hostels for the EBC students have been constructed in 28 districts, of which those in 26 districts had already become functional, and two other hostels were nearing completion. The bed capacity of each hostel is 100. He said the Bihar Bridge Construction Corporation Limited has allocated Rs26.09 crore for the construction of new hostels in the six remaining districts under the corporate social responsibility (CSR) fund. Against that, the sanction has been given for the utilization of Rs12.75 crore under CSR fund of the bridge corporation.

On the other hand, industries department director P K Singh said Rs10 lakh will be paid to the willing entrepreneurs from the EBC sections as part of the scheme already existing for the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. As much as 50% of the sum would be granted as subsidy, while the remaining 50% as loan. While the subsidy is payable in three instalments, the recovery of the loan amount would start one year after the payment of the last instalment of the subsidy amount, Singh added.

Title: Light rain likely today in Patna: Met
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

The clouds will start getting clear from Friday,” said a Patna Meteorological Centre official (File photo)

PATNA: Patna and few other parts of the state received light showers on Tuesday and weathermen have claimed that showers are likely to occur on Wednesday as well.

The daily weather bulletin issued by the Patna Meteorological Centre on Tuesday evening stated that light rainfall occurred at one or two places in the state during the last 24 hours. It further pointed out that rainfall with thunderstorm was likely to take place at few places in all the 38 districts on Wednesday and one or two places on Thursday.

Weathermen attributed the prevailing rainy spell to a western disturbance and claimed that its impact would be seen in the state till Thursday. Western disturbances are low-pressure areas or extratropical storms originating from the Mediterranean Sea, Red Sea and Caspian Sea, which cause snow and winter rainfall in northwestern Indian subcontinent.

“Most weather observatories in Bihar recorded either light showers or dry weather with cloud cover on Wednesday. Rainfall may continue to occur on Thursday as well. The clouds will start getting clear from Friday,” said an official at the Patna Meteorological Centre.

As far as temperature is concerned, the Met office has predicted rise in night temperature by two to four notches during the next 48 hours and decrease by two to four notches during the next two to three days.

Title: Bhitiharwa to Patna march against CAA from Jan 30
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

PATNA: Several political parties, trader unions and members of civil society would join the protest march against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) from Gandhi Ashram at Bhitiharwa in East Champaran on the death anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi on January 30, said All India Congress Committee (AICC) secretary Shakeel Ahmad Khan on Tuesday.

The protest march will be led by former Jawaharlal Nehru University Students’ Union (JNUSU) president Kanhaiya Kumar and Shakeel under the banner of NPR-NRC-CAA Virodhi Sangharsh Morcha.

Addressing a presser here on Tuesday, Shakeel said the protest march would conclude at Gandhi Maidan in Patna on February 29. “Many eminent Gandhians will also join the march at Bhitiharwa. It is important that our voices should be heard against the law that will bring no good to the country,” he said and added: “The Centre passed this citizenship law to divert attention from important issues like degradation of education system, rise in unemployment and economic slowdown in the country.”

The protest has been named as ‘Save Constitution, Save citizenship Maha-rally, Our country Our Constitution, A Journey From Bapu Dham to Gandhi Maidan’.

Many prominent personalities, including social activist Jignesh Mevani, JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh, ex-Congress MP Priya Dutt, Tushar Gandhi, the great-grandson of Mahatma Gandhi, Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad and actress Swara Bhaskar, will join the march on February 29.

Shakeel said the Centre spent Rs16 crore on the NRC process in Assam. “If the central government spend that much money only in one state, how much they will have to spend on NRC process across the country. The country will have progress and growth, if the same amount is utilized for development works,” he said.

The Congress leader said the citizenship law would not only oppress the Muslims, underprivileged and Scheduled Castes, but also tarnish the country’s secular character and composite culture. “It is a fight of all the democratic Indians to save the Constitution,” Shakeel said.

Title: Gandhar weaves magic of classical singing legacy
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Vocalist Gandhar Deshpande performs at Kaptanwada in Mahal, on Tuesday

Nagpur: From taranas, bandishes and aalaps to sargam, young vocalist Gandhar Deshpande was at his best as he weaved the magic of Gwalior, Jaipur and Agra gharana gayaki with ease on Tuesday.

The audience soaked in Gandhar’s singing on the open lawns of Kaptanwada, Zenda Chowk, Mahal.

Groomed by vocalist parents Ram and Archana Deshpande since the age of five, Gandhar began the performance by invoking Lord Ganesh. He then presented two bandishes in raag Yaman, ‘Jiya manat nahi’, a blend of high and low-pitched aalaps that effectively described the melancholic mood.

The young artiste then sang a bandish ‘Nanadi ke bachanwa seh na jaye’, in the same raga, which was followed by a sargam. He later presented ‘tant aanga’, a matra after samay which only sitarists practise on the musical instrument. But the vocalist impressed with his vocals and won accolades.

He presented a tarana ‘Der na der na tanana’, composed by his father. He enlivened the atmosphere with the presentation of ‘mishra raag’, a blend of two ragas, ‘Rageshri and Bahar’ whose essence he got from his father as it was his topic for PhD. He sang a mellifluous bandish, ‘Ae bahar aayi’ and ‘Sagan ghan’.

Gandhar gave a devotional touch to the programme with ‘Abir gulal udhalit ranga’ and ‘He surano chandra vha’, originally sung by legendary Jitendra Abhisheki.

He concluded the recital with a nirguni bhajan in raag Kalingan, taken from raag Bhairav. It was pleasant to hear ‘Shunya gadh sheher sheher ghar basti kon sota kon jaage’.

He was accompanied by Sandesh Popatkar on tabla, Shyam Oza on harmonium, and Sharvari Naik and Rudra Dubey on tanpura.

In 2017, Gandhar had collaborated with Justin Tracy, an American western musician, for ‘Mumbai Night’ album which was selected as an entry to the prestigious Grammy awards.

“I chose the ragas and taranas composed by my father. Nagpur will always be close to my heart and I will perform here when the chance comes,” he said.

Title: Central Bank posts Rs 155cr profit in Q3
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Mumbai: Central Bank of India has reported a net profit of Rs 155 crore for the quarter ended December 2019 compared to a net loss of Rs 718 crore in theyear-ago period.

This is the third successive quarterly profit reported by the public sector bank. The lender’s MD and CEO Pallav Mohapatra said he was hopeful the institution would get out of the lending restrictions placed by the RBI by March 2020. One of the requirements for exiting RBI’s prompt corrective action ( PCA ) framework, which bars the lender from disbursing unsecured loans, is that it should reduce its ratio of bad loans.

In October-December 2019, the bank’s deposits increased to Rs 3.08 lakh crore and its CASA ratio improved to 45.49%. The lender is targeting to raise Rs 200 crore by selling real estate properties in the ongoing quarter. It is also looking to garner another Rs 60 crore from sale of its entire 20% stake in Indo-Zambia Bank.

The bank’s net interest margin (NIM) improved to 2.92% from 2.74 %. Trading profits on investments rose to Rs 284 crore from Rs 139 crore. According to Mohapatra, this was possible because of the bank’s decision to move funds from the money market to bonds.

Mohapatra said the bank was following a two-fold strategy to improve ratio of bad loans — the first was to improve recoveries from non-performing assets (NPAs) and the second was to increase the loan portfolio. As part of its strategy to grow credit portfolio, the bank was actively purchasing loans from non-banking finance companies (NBFCs).

Title: Goa: District planning body holds meet after five years
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Fatorda MLA and former deputy CM Vijai Sardesai said that the meeting was a ‘political farce’ and ‘a ritual ne... Read More

MARGAO: With the district planning committee (DPC) holding its meeting after five years and at the fag-end of the tenure of the 14th Finance Commission, several MLAs who attended the meeting called into question the efficacy of the meeting.

Chief executive officer of the South Goa zilla panchayat, Agnelo Fernandes, said that 47 out of 88 panchayats have submitted their annual development plans to the DPC which have to be complied and submitted to the planning commission. He said he would now request the Goa Institute of Public Administration and Rural Development to provide assistance in constituting the district-level plan.

Fatorda MLA Vijai Sardesai, speaking to reporters after the meeting, called it a “political farce” and “a ritual needed to be completed”.

“The DPC has to be held at the beginning of the five-year period. The DPC is an eyewash as the government has failed to devolve any powers to the zilla panchayat bodies,” Sardesai said.

The former deputy chief minister said that the failure of the zilla panchayat in getting the government devolved funds and power to the district level panchayat bodies “fortified” his stand that the elections to zilla panchayats shouldn’t be held on party lines.

“The adhayksha of the zilla panchayat is from the ruling party. So if he were not to be a stooge or a member of the ruling party, he would have fought to see that powers are devolved, and that annual plans are submitted by the panchayats to the DPC, and ensured that there is no murder of the 73rd amendment to the Constitution in Goa. Because he is a member of the ruling party, he becomes a silent spectator to the murder of democracy,” he said.

Curtorim MLA Aleixo Reginaldo Laurenco and Sanguem MLA Prasad Gaonkar also expressed their reservations over the outcome of the meeting. Curchorem MLA and power minister Nilesh Cabral advocated the need for preparing constituency-level development plans by taking into confidence panchayats concerned and municipal bodies.

Title: Fly to 4 new destinations from Indore this summer
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Indore: Lucknow, Pune, Kishangarh (Ajmer) and Jodhpur are among the list of new destinations that have been proposed by airlines for flight operations to and from Devi Ahilyabai Holkar Airport.

Daily flights at Indore airport is expected to increase to 108 and more as seven airlines have reserved slots under upcoming summer schedule.

Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) has released the proposed summer schedule for the year 2020.

The airlines have also reserved slots for additional flights on Delhi, and Mumbai routes under this proposed schedule, which will be effective from March 29 to October 24, 2020, said official sources.

The number of flights to Delhi is expected to increase up to 17 as compared to existing 13 departures a day. Indore-Mumbai route is also expected to have 8 flights every day as compared to six in current schedule. For Ahmedabad, daily flights are likely to be reduced by one. Currently, there are five flights operating on this route and it is likely to go down to four.

Indore airport currently sees daily flight movement of 84 scheduled flights with connectivity to around 12 domestic and one international routes.

Airport director Aryama Sanyal said that it is a proposed schedule for airlines, and it can be changed, if needed, before a final schedule is approved and released by DGCA.

“The daily scheduled flight movement at Indore will go up to 108 if the same is approved by DGCA. Also it will depend on the airlines to start operations on allotted slots,” the director told TOI.

She also said that ‘Fly Big’ – a private firm that earlier dealt in aircraft simulation is also expected to start flight operations on two routes including Indore-Bhopal and Indore-Jabalpur. “If all goes well, the airline would start operations from next month,” she added while talking to TOI.

Title: Citing ‘excessive work pressure’, two SIs in Bareilly resign to take care of their ‘lonely’ wives
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Bareilly: In a surprise move that left Bareilly police astonished, two of its sub-inspectors put in their papers citing “excessive work pressure which makes even availing weekly offs quite difficult”.

In their letters to deputy inspector general (Bareilly range) Rajesh Pandey, the officers, Jaipal Singh and Naresh Bhatnagar, stated that they “want to take care of their wives who are leading a lonely life” since their children are settled outstation.

After failing to persuade them, the DIG, who has given them 15 days to revisit their decision, has accepted their resignations. The officers are in their late fifties and have more than a year of service left.

On Tuesday, the SIs, along with their wives, visited the DIG office and submitted their resignation letters. In the letter, said police sources, the officers stated that “due to excessive work pressure in a 24x7 job, availing even weekly off is quite difficult, and thus, they have no other option than quitting their services to take care of their spouses, who feel lonely” since their children are settled outstation and the cops remain busy performing their duty.

A native of Salamatpur village under Didauli police station limits in Amroha district, Singh joined police services as a constable in 1980. The father of three sons, Singh lives with his wife here as their three sons — the eldest one is a surgeon; the second son, an engineer, is working for a reputed multinational software firm; and, the youngest one is a senior railway officer — are settled with their families in different cities.

Similarly, Bhatnagar, a native of Gadhiya Rangin village in Shahjahanpur district, has two children. His daughter teaches at an engineering college in Ghaziabad and the son is pursuing engineering.

Explaining how helpless he felt when his wife fell ill and needed to be hospitalised last year, Bhatnagar told TOI, “At that time I need leave, but we cannot avail sick leave for the ailing wife. Now, she needs proper care and that is the reason why I decided to quit my service.”

Singh, on the other hand, feels it’s time for him to live a comfortable life with his wife, who feels lonely. “I have no liabilities. My sons are well settled. They are living with their wives in different cities. My wife lives alone all day at home. In the police service, I cannot spare much time for my wife. Thus, I decided to take retirement early.”

DIG Pandey, however, said, “I have given them 15 days to reconsider their decision after having discussions with their families. But, as they are adamant on their decision, I have accepted their resignations for now.”

Title: CBI warns against fake job scheme
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Hyderabad: CBI has asked people applying for the agency’s recently announced internship programme to not believe in fraudulent advertisements and emails pertaining to the programme.

“Certain instances of fraudulent advertisements and emails relating to the Central Bureau of Investigation Internship Scheme have come to the agency’s notice. These are being spread on platforms to attract young professionals by referring to the internship scheme as an employment opportunity in the CBI,” a statement issued by the CBI stated.

CBI also said that during the internship period, selected candidates have to make their own arrangements for stay and travel and the scheme does not involve any permanent placement with CBI.

“If anyone comes across fraudulent information pertaining to selection or employment with CBI through the CBI internship scheme, please inform the CBI at: sptrgacd@cbi.gov.in,” CBI release stated.

The internship programme is meant for 30 Indian graduate and post graduate or research students, preferably specializing in law, cyber security, data analysis, criminology among others.

Title: Permission sought for pro-CAA meet
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Hyderabad: The Akhand Bharat Sangarsh Samithi, Bhagyanagar, has sought permission from police to organise a pro-CAA meeting at Charminar on February 2. A representation was given to Hyderabad police commissioner Anjani Kumar seeking permission to hold the meeting from 4 pm to 9 pm.

In the letter, Ale Bhasker Raaj, convenor of the samithi, said programmes that are being conducted by their samithi are meant to educate people on the laws and policies of the government. He said that political parties were wrongly interpreting CAA .TNN

Title: IIT Hyderabad develops drug carrier to treat fungal diseases
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

IIT Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: Researchers from the Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad have developed an essential-oil-based drug carrier system to treat fungal infections without running the risk of inducing drug resistance.

The research paper published in the international peer-reviewed journal Materialia, highlighted that the medication can counter fungi that have developed resistance to conventional anti-fungal drugs.

“Given the prevalence of fungal infections such as vaginal infections, diaper rash, athlete’s foot, and nail fungus caused by the Candida family of fungi, drug resistance can be life-threatening,” said Mudrika Khandelwal, who led the research.

She also added that the IIT Hyderabad team turned to natural products to solve this problem.

“Herbal essential oils and their ingredients have excellent antimicrobial action against all types of Candida fungi,” said Shivakalyani Adepu, one of the researchers. “The problem with essential oils and their components is that they are sensitive to temperature, light, and pH, and decompose easily.”

The research team said that a way to overcome this problem is to design a suitable carrier system that can protect the oils and active principles from these factors, and yet, release them in a controlled manner so that anti-fungal action can be fully harnessed.

The new controlled-release design achieved 99.9% fungi-static action within 12 hours, with only half the concentration of ingredients, thus enabling small dosages for treatment.

Title: Water supply to be disrupted in capital
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Water supply to several areas in the city will be disrupted as the 86 million litres a day (mld) and the 74 mld plants at Aruvikkara will be shut down on February 1 and 2 as part of the last phase of renovation works.

The 74mld plant will be shut from 2pm on February 1 to 2am on February 2 while the shutdown of the 86 mld plant will be shut till 6am on February 2. The water supply is expected to normalise only by the night of February 3.

Kerala Water Authority (KWA) has informed that the first three shutdowns were successful. It has replaced electrical panels and new pumps at the 86 mld treatment plant. KWA will now be able to send additional 10 mld water to the city.

KWA will provide partial supply to areas such as Medical College during the shutdown. Supply will be provided to Regional Cancer Centre, Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute for Medical Sciences & Technology, in tankers.

KWA has also arranged vending points in Vellayambalam, Aruvikkara, PTP Nagar, Choozhattukotta and Attingal-Valakode areas to collect water in tankers.

In addition to its tankers, KWA has also arranged tankers of corporation, police, Army and CRPF to tackle drinking water woes during the shutdown. It has also installed kiosks in areas which will be affected by the shutdown.

KWA control numbers are 8547638181, 0471-2322674, 2322313 (Thiruvananthapuram), 9496000685 (Aruvikkara). Vending points can be contacted at 8547638181 (Vellayambalam), 9496000685 (Aruvikkara), 8547638192 (PTP), 8289940618 (Choozhattukotta) and 8547638358 (Attingal-Valakode).

In areas such as Kowdiar, Peroorkada, Pippinmoodu, Sastamangalam, Kochar Road, Edapazhanji, Kanaka Nagar, Vellayambalam, Marappalam, Pattom, Medical college, RCC, Sri Chithra Medical centre, Kumarapuram, Ulloor, Prasanth Nagar, Akkulam, Cheruvaikkal, Pongumoodu, Sreekaryam, Chempazhanti, Kariyam, Parottukonam, Nalanchira, Mannanthala, Kesavadasapuram, Paruthipara, Muttada, Ambalamukku, Vazhayila, Kudappanakunnu, Jawahar Nagar, Nanthancode, Dewasom Board junction, Poudikonam, Kazhakoottam, Kariavattom, Technopark, Manvila, Kulathoor and Pallipuram will experience water supply disruption from 2pm on February 1 to 6am on February 2.

The shutdown will be from 2pm on February 1 to 2am on February 2 in areas such as Thirumala, PTP Nagar, Marutumkuzhy, Pangodu, Kanjrampara, Vattiyoorkavu, Kachani, Nettayam, Malamukal, Kulashekharam, Valiyavila, Kodunganoor, Kudamanbhagam, Punnakkamugal, Mudavanmugal, Jagathy, Poojappura, Karamana, Nemom, Vellayani, Pappanamcode, Thrikkanapuram, Kaimanam, Karumam, Kalady, Nedungadu, Attukal, Iranimuttam, Thampanoor, East Fort, Vallakadavu, Kuriathy, Chalai, Manacaud, Kamaleswaram, Ambalathara, Poonthura, Beemapally, Valiyatura, Sreevaraham, Muttathara, Thiruvallam and Nelliyodu.

Title: 45-year-old man gets 25 years of jail for raping four-year-old girl in Budaun
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Bareilly: Three months after a four-year-old girl was raped at a village in Budaun, a POCSO court has sentenced a 45-year-old man to 25 years of imprisonment. The man had raped the girl on the day of Diwali last year.

The girl’s father in his police complaint on October 28 last year said, “On October 27 last year, my girl was playing outside her house. However, a local, Amarpal, took my daughter to a secluded field behind my house and raped her. Amarpal was drunk. After the girl returned home, she narrated her ordeal to us.”

Following the crime, an FIR was registered against Amarpal under IPC sections 376-AB (rape of girl under 12 years of age), 363 (kidnapping) and relevant sections of POCSO Act. The court found Amarpal guilty.

Additional district government counsel Madan Lal Rajput said the court of special judge Rama Shankar Singh has announced 25 years of imprisonment for Amarpal. The court also imposed a fine of Rs 50,000 on Amarpal who is a daily-wage labourer.

Title: Deshmukh’s travelogue window to world: Critic
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Dignitaries release Col Dr Narayan Deshmukh’s book ‘Deshatanachi Shatpavli’ on Tuesday

Nagpur: Geographical details of the world are known to people, but cultural and historical aspects need to be highlighted in books centred on travel, said writer and critic VS Jog at Press Club, Civil Lines, on Tuesday.

He was speaking at the launch of ‘Deshatanachi Shatpavli’, written by Dr Narayan Deshmukh, who retired as a colonel from American Army Reserve.

Senior journalist Shailesh Pande chaired the programme. Publisher of the book Chandrakant Lakhe and Deshmukh’s wife Rohini were present.

Jog said, “Deshmukh has effectively portrayed the aesthetic significance of each country he visited in the book. Information and the language of the book is such that it helps you visualize the place without visiting it.”

“The words used by Deshmukh create a pictorial embellishment of the journey. Starting with the correct definition of countries’ peculiar names to the historical background of those places, the book has a lot to offer,” he said.

Pande said, “This is a book that caters to the needs of people in venturing into the field of travel. Having stayed abroad for over 50 years, Deshmukh has served Marathi language by penning this book. It is a delight to read his writing. His efforts underline the value of going beyond the horizons.”

Senior journalist Vinod Deshmukh said, “The writer has beautifully expressed his travelling episodes in Marathi. He is pride of Maharashtra. I am sure he will complete the goal of visiting 100 countries and write his third book.”

Writer Deshmukh said, “Most of the itinerary details not available on the internet can only be acquired by travelling. This book is a medium to bring hidden facts about the countries before readers.”

Having served as a doctor nearly for 50 years, Deshmukh is a globe-trotter. In his second book, he has chronicled his experience of visiting 93 countries in Asia, America, Africa and Europe. He has set for himself the goal of visiting 100 countries.

Lakhe proposed a vote of thanks.

(Reporting by Manshika Vaikkath)

Title: TRS MPs to raise GST arrears
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Hyderabad: TRS has decided to raise the pending GST arrears which the Centre owes to Telangana, pending projects and fund allocation in forthcoming parliament session.

Party MPs have decided to act on CAA, NRC and NPR in both the Houses as per the stand taken by CM K Chandrasekhar Rao. Addressing MPs at a parliamentary party meeting on Tuesday, TRS working president KT Rama Rao said Centre was focusing on CAA instead of economic slowdown.

Telangana is yet to get GST arrears to the tune of Rs 1,135 crore from the Centre. “Though Niti Aayog has recommended fund allocation to Mission Bhagiratha and Mission Kakatiya, the Centre has not extended finanical support to the programmes,” KTR said. TNN

Title: Thiruvananthapuram: Toll plaza construction to begin in two months
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Image used for representational purpose only

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: With the completion of major works, including the Chackai flyover, in the Kazhakoottam-Mukkola stretch, National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) is now set to start the work on construction of a toll plaza in one or two months. The agency is planning to start toll collection in the stretch in four months.

Though NHAI has initially proposed toll plaza at Akkulam , it has been shifted on the request by state government. A staggered toll plaza will come up at a location between Thiruvallam and Vellar.

The state government had opposed the plan to set up the toll plaza at Akkulam as a number of daily commuters in city will have to pay toll. As the toll plaza was shifted to Thiruvallam side, only users of national highway will have to pay the toll. As per rules, a toll plaza should be constructed beyond a distance of 10km from municipal or local town area limits.

Sources said the toll plaza’s construction will begin after NHAI approves the toll rates for various vehicles.
