Vadodara: A controversy broke out on Tuesday when the measurement of the land allocated for a public-private partnership realty project was to be conducted by government and Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) officials. Inability of an official to attend the measurement led to the row.

The measurement of land for the Agora City Centre project Sanjaynagar in Sama was ordered by the district collector after a series of representations by VMC’s opposition Congress corporator Ami Ravat.

Ravat has claimed that the project had used 44,010 sq m land instead of 39,685 sq m as mentioned in the tender. She and other environment activists have also alleged that a retaining wall for the project was built in the course of Vishwamitri river.

Collector had ordered that the land should be measured in the presence of Vadodara executive magistrate (north), district inspector of land records (DILR), city survey officials and the tow planning department of VMC. However, sources said, the executive magistrate could not attend the measurement due to other pressing official engagements.

Ravat said that the executive magistrate could have sent a representative so that the procedure could have been completed. “The order was given after we submitted evidence and made several representations. We will do so again,” she said.

Title: Prominent Agra jeweller, wife tortured, robbed and murdered
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Muklesh (L), Lata Gupta

AGRA: A prominent Agra jeweller-- also the chairperson of local jewellers’ association-- and his wife were tortured for hours before being murdered at their home by unknown assailants, who decamped with cash and valuables worth lakhs of rupees on early Tuesday morning.

According to their relatives, Muklesh Gupta (62) was found lying with a wire tied to his leg, suggesting that the robbers tortured him to extract information on the valuables kept in the house before strangling him to death at their home in Agra’s Harsahaye Khedki colony.

The incident sent shock waves in the region. Muklesh’s was the oldest and richest jeweller family in city’s Shamshabad area. As the news spread, the entire Shamshabad market was shut down. Local leaders, including MP and MLAs along with ADG of Agra zone Ajay Anand, IG Agra range Satish Ganesh, SSP Babloo Kumar rushed to the crime spot.

The couple-- Muklesh and his wife Lata Gupta (58) -- are survived by three daughters, Priyanka Gupta, 38, Geetika Gupta, 35 and Deepika Gupta 32, and all of them are married.

The couple’s murder came to light at around 8am on Tuesday, when their septuagenarian maid, Somvati, saw them lying dead on the first floor and alerted the neighbours and distant relatives of the couple, who live in Harsahaye colony.

Speaking to TOI, Vivek Gupta, 49, the nephew of the couple who lives just two homes away from victim’s, said, “Muklesh was electrocuted and strangulated to death, as his left leg was tapped with wire and he was given electric shock by assailants, probably to extract information about the cash and jewellery. Lata’s neck was stabbed with a sharp instrument and her body was lying in a pool of blood.”

Vikas Gupta, 52, another nephew of the victim, said, “Like every day, Muklesh shut his jewellery shop at around 5:30pm and returned home. Later, at around 7pm, he went to local Dauji temple for evening prayer. By 8:45pm he returned home after visiting his friend’s mobile store. We suspect that as soon he left for temple, the assailants entered into his home and killed Lata after she refused or resisted to share the cash and jewellery information.”

“Muklesh’s foot was still in shoes when we saw his body. He never entered into the living area wearing shoes, which suggests that he was attacked and dragged inside the room by assailants as soon he entered into the house. The robbers might have tortured him entire night before decamping with several lakh worth jewellery and cash along with licensed pistol,” Gupta said.

According to a police source, “There were four CCTV cameras in the victim’s house. But the assailants took away the digital video recorder (DVR) with them. We believe someone known to the jeweller has executed the heinous crime.” Meanwhile, forensic teams have collected finger prints sample, and other evidences from the spot.

ADG Anand said, “Investigating team has received some crucial lead in the incident and soon the accused involved in the crime would be arrested.”

Autopsy of the two victims found asphyxia as reason for death.

IG Agra Ganesh said, "Based on the victim's elder daughter Priyanka Gupta's written complaint, an FIR was lodged under IPC section 394 (robbery) and 302 (murder)." It comes 12 days after the jewelers’ association in nearby Meerut threatened a complete shutdown over rising incidents of crime against them.

Title: Big Temple consecration in Tamil, Sanskrit: State to HC
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Madurai: The Tamil Nadu government on Tuesday informed the Madras high court that importance is given to Tamil at the consecration ceremony of the Brihadeeswara Temple (Big Temple) in Thanjavur, and it would be performed both in Tamil and Sanskrit as per agama. The court was hearing a batch of petitions relating to the conduct of the ceremony.

A petition was filed by G Thirumurugan before the high court Madurai bench seeking to conduct the ceremony in Tamil. Following this, several petitions were filed seeking to conduct the ceremony in Tamil and petitions seeking to conduct it as per agama dictum.

In the counter affidavit, the Hindu religious and charitable endowments (HR&CE) department stated that the yagasalai pujas which are to be performed from February 1 to 5 and maha abishekam which is to be performed for the deities on February 5, includes the practice of Thirumurai Parayanam (Panniru Thirumurai, Abhirami Anthathi, Thirupugal) which is done in Tamil.

The same religious and customary practices of the temple which was followed while performing the consecration ceremony in 1980 and 1997 would be followed in the forthcoming ceremony which is to be held on February 5. The petitioners who seek to perform the ceremony only in Tamil have not produced any proof to show that the ceremony was performed only in Tamil alone, the state said.

In its counter, the Thanjavur Aranmanai Devasthanam stated that Tamil Thirumurais has a prominent place in the pujas performed at the temple and regular visitors could not dispute this fact. It also stated that Tamil is also given a prominent place in the consecration ceremony. When the kodimaram was installed, the Thirumurai was sung. Several othuvars attached to attached to Madurai Alavoi Annal Arakattalai and students from Chidambaram Alavoi Annal Arakattalai have been assigned to spiritual work during the ceremony. A separate invitation was printed giving particulars about the list of othuvars. Hence, there is no substance in the hue and cry raised by the petitions. Taking note of the submissions, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran adjourned the case to January 29 (Wednesday). A petition was filed seeking to grant injunction to the ceremony stating that the temple management was organising it without obtaining permission from the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). After the counsel appearing for ASI informed that they had granted permission, the judges closed the petition.

Meanwhile, agriculture minister R Doraikkannu met chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami in Chennai on Tuesday and extended an invitation to him to participate in the Thanjavur Big Temple consecration ceremony.

Title: In Chandrapur for tiger sighting? Also explore the deep mines
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Bhatali open cast mine

Chandrapur: Tourists visiting Tadoba Andhari Tiger Reserve can now also explore the deep coal mines in Chandrapur district through guided tours. Twelve tourists, all students of Bamboo Research and Training Centre, on Monday went deep inside the Bhatali open cast mine to have first-hand experience of deep coal mining.

This was made possible by ‘Mine Tourism’ launched by district administration, in collaboration with Maharashtra Tourist Development Corporation (MTDC) and Western Coalfields Limited (WCL). Guardian minister of Chandrapur, Vijay Wadettiwar launched the scheme on Republic Day.

TATR has now become an international tourism destination thanks to the good tiger sighting in the reserve. Hundreds of feet deep pits of different coal mines along the road to Tadoba often arise intrigue among tourists. Looking in to the interest tourists show in these mines, district collector Kunal Khemnar in November 2019 had asked MTDC to explore opportunities in mine tourism.

Official sources informed that interested tourists can visit Mahakali underground coal mine and Bhatali open cast coal mine on Monday and Thursday. The charges for the visit are not fixed yet but will be finalized soon.

MTDC will start online booking for Mine Tourism from February 1. Dugarpur underground mine and other mines in the area are likely to be added to the itinerary.

Mine tourism was first launched in Nagpur district in December 2016.

Title: Mangaluru: Barcode for homes to make door-to-door waste collection efficient
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

MANGALURU: The Mangaluru Smart City Limited (MSCL) will soon introduce a new barcode system for efficient implementation of solid waste management (SWM) in all the 60 wards of Mangaluru city.

The MSCL has already introduced the system on a pilot basis in Mannagudda ward, where all the 2,000 houses will be given barcodes. All door-to-door waste collection vehicles will have to scan the barcode at the gates of houses, so that the city corporation can track its movement on a real-time basis. The system will be introduced in all the 60 wards soon.

At a meet the press programme organised by Dakshina Kannada District Working Journalists Association, MSCL managing director Mohammed Nazeer said the process of issuing barcodes for homes has already begun. “We have already given barcodes to nearly 600 houses. The barcode scanning system for door-to-door collection has already begun on a pilot basis in one ward. We have plans to introduce the system in all the 60 wards of the city corporation,” he said.

At present, 132 vehicles used for solid waste management are being tracked through GPS. A command and control centre (CCC) is being set up at a cost of Rs 74 crore to make public administration and services more efficient. In addition to traffic management, air quality monitoring, transport management and disaster management, the centre will also monitor the movement of all vehicles used for SWM. The MSCL has plans to make all buses enabled with GPS and link the data with the CCC. The centre will also have features to monitor all public utility vehicles like ambulances and other vehicles, he said.

The MSCL has plans to erect 15 smart poles at major junctions in the city. Smart poles will have solar panels, street lights, traffic signals, public address system for administration, LED display for major announcements, cameras, wi-fi access points and a weather sensor system in it. Citizens may also use the smart poles to communicate with the authorities through an SOS button attached to it, he said.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Don’t panic, stay informed and alert, says Gujarat government
Content:
Civil Hospital reserved one room of its Isolation ward for patients with suspected coronavirus on Tuesday

GANDHINAGAR: Attempting to allay fear and panic among people over the coronavirus scare, the state government on Tuesday said that there is no need for people to fear, but advised citizens to stay informed and alert about the virus.Based on the data shared by the government of India, eight persons who travelled from China to India recently – four from Ahmedabad, two from Vadodara and one each from Anand and Junagadh – have been screened. They will be kept under observation for the next 28 days although none have shown any symptoms of coronavirus.Jayanti Ravi, principal secretary, health & family welfare, while addressing media persons said, “Not a single case of coronavirus has been registered in Gujarat or any part of India, so there is no need to panic. The state government is taking all necessary preventive actions and citizens need to stay alert and take precautions.” She said civil hospital Ahmedabad has been nominated as the base hospital and the CM, deputy CM and the chief secretary have reviewed the situation.Ravi said that all the persons who arrived from China are healthy and show no symptoms of coronavirus. “All have been screened and their health will be tracked for the next 28 days as a precautionary measure. If required, they will be shifted to isolation wards,” Ravi said.Self-reporting kiosks have been installed at the Ahmedabad and 12 other airports in the state, where passengers arriving from China or elsewhere can report on their health status. All districts have been asked to set up facilities where people can seek assistance. “A medical team will be placed round the clock at the Ahmedabad international airport along with an ambulance. Besides, we have kept an ample stock of PPE kit, N95 mask, triple layer mask and other required materials,” Ravi said.

Title: Kolkata: Cops give finishing touches to Tallah Bridge diversion plans
Content:
Around 40-50 cars ply on Tallah Bridge even after its partial shutdown

KOLKATA: The partial closure of Tallah Bridge has not taken the load off the wobbly structure entirely. Even now, around 40-50 vehicles use it per minute. Belgachhia Bridge — with almost double the flow — will now handle a part of the extra load along with the Lock Gate flyover. The challenge will not be an easy one, especially between February 1 and 4 — the trial phase.Lalbazar says its preparation to handle such a huge flow of traffic on alternative roads is in its final stage. The nerve centres, said top cops, will be Chiria More, which will act as a temporary control room on one side, and the Shyambazar five-point crossing from where the vehicles will move on to alternative routes.In all, cops have identified 12 traffic points that will be under constant vigil in the initial week. Five of these points — Chiria More, Shyambazar crossing, the BT Road-Lock Gate flyover meeting point, Belgachhia Metro station and Galiff Street-KVV Avenue crossing — have kept cops worried.“Chiria More will receive a lot of our attention. Depending on the pressure on various roads, diversions will be implemented. Cossipore Road will see police deployment on the same lines that we usually had on BT Road. Sergeants will be moving up and down to clear congestion. No illegal parking will be allowed. Most importantly, we will also have good presence on JM Avenue and KVV Avenue, roads where otherwise we have skeletal presence during office time,” said joint CP (traffic) Santosh Pandey.Police said they were banking on the Shyambazar traffic guard to bail them out. “We have enough resources at this guard. The Ultadanga guard will pitch in as well. Since we will use signage well ahead of the actual diversion points, we will also seek help from Bidhannagar police and Barrackpore police. For this to happen, we will also depend on those men from other traffic guards who have been posted here over the past two months and who know the geography of the area well,” said an IPS officer. With trucks banned in the area till the alternative railway level crossing is ready at the Chitpore yard, more men would be available in the morning, he added.“We will take the challenges as the come. We will tweak plans as and when required. We are depending heavily on the level crossing across the railway yard at Chitpore. The final inspections are over and we expect it to come up soon,” said DCP (traffic) Rupesh Kumar. Cops will also put emphasis on the movement of ambulances for RG Kar Hospital through Paikpara-Tara Shankar Sarani.Police are offering four alignments for buses moving from south to north. There are three options for those moving south. The big decision is to make Lock Gate flyover one-way, the first time that even buses will be allowed to use this route. “We are expecting the state transport department to issue us the final route alignment for each route. We are in touch with the bus owners. We are also communicating with Ola and Uber. We have asked them to use the Ultadanga Main Road-Bailey Bridge and Ghaznavi Bridge instead of progressing towards Belgachhia,” said an officer.

Title: Complete poll process for chairperson of Narikudi panchayat by lots: HC
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Madurai: Taking serious note of the incident where ballot sheets were torn during the indirect election conducted for Narikudi panchayat union in Virudhunagar district after the election of chairperson ended in a tie, the Madras high court has directed to complete the process by drawing of lots instead of conducting fresh election on January 30.

In her petition, S Kaleeswari, a resident of A Mukkulam in Virudhunagar district and DMK member, said she was elected as councillor of ward 3 of Narikudi panchayat union. She decided to contest for the post of chairman in the panchayat union as the seat was reserved for women belonging to scheduled caste community.

There are 14 wards in the panchayat and the election ended in a tie as she and the other candidate secured seven votes each. When the returning officer was planning to conduct drawing of lots as per Tamil Nadu Panchayat Election Rules, the members of the ruling party ransacked the office due to which the election was postponed. She noted that the Aruppukottai deputy superintendent of police Venkatesan sustained cut injuries on his hand during the violence. Hence, she moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to complete the election process by drawing of lots.

When the petition was heard on Tuesday, senior counsel Veera Kathiravan, who appeared for the petitioner submitted that the returning officer had mentioned in his complaint that all the ballot sheets were torn by the ruling party when they were planning to conduct drawing of lots. Stating that democracy is in peril, he submitted that if a fresh election is conducted, then it would pave way for horse-trading.

Additional advocate general K Chellapandian submitted that since all the 14 ballot sheets were destroyed, drawing of lots could not be conducted due to which fresh election was notified for the union.

Taking note of the submissions, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran observed that they cannot encourage such unlawful activity. The judges also observed that since the returning officer had mentioned in his complaint that the election ended in a tie, it would amount to declaration and therefore the ballot papers are not required for drawing of lots. Hence, they directed the state election commission to complete the election process for electing the chairperson of Narikudi union by drawing of lots at 11am on January 30.

While hearing the petitions with regard to conducting election for Thiruppuvanam panchayat union in Sivaganga district and Kovilpatti panchayat union in Tuticorin district, the judges directed to videograph the process and to provide adequate police protection on January 30.

The court also dismissed the petition which challenged the notification dated January 21 which was issued to conduct indirect election for Watrap panchayat union in Virudhunagar district on January 30. The petitioner stated that though the election process was completed, the results were not declared following the violence.

Title: 5-year-old twin girls drown in water tank
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Jodhpur: Two twin girls aged five years drowned in a water tank near their house on Monday afternoon. The incident was reported to the police late Monday evening, after which the post-mortem was conducted and the bodies of the girls were handed over to the family on Tuesday morning.

Though considering the accident, there was a suspicion on how and why would the girls go to the water tank in such a cold weather but the family members did not express any suspicion.

According to the SHO (Rajiv Gandhi Nagar) Balraj Singh Mann, Pukhraj Sankhla lived with his family close to his agriculture farm in Chokha area.

“On Monday, his five-year-old twin daughters Divanshi and Dipika, returned from school and went to the water pond in the farm with the family members unaware. After sometime, some children reached the pond and saw both the girls had drowned and informed the family members,” said the official.

All in the house rushed to the spot, took the girls out and rushed to the hospital, where both of them were declared brought dead. According to the family members, the girls go to the tank very often but on Monday, the level of water was bit high in comparison to other days.

Title: Haryana man arrested for smuggling and selling adulterated liquor in Agra
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: Sikandra police of Agra arrested a man who smuggled Indian made foreign liquor (IMFL) in the city to repackage and sell the adulterated liquor in slum areas.

Identified as Rajendra Kumar of Faridabad , Haryana, the accused was caught from a dilapidated church near NH-2 while refilling used liquor bottles with adulterated liquor which he, along with his aide Gorkhi, had made by mixing IMFL and spirit.

“Rajendra and Gorkhi used to sell repackaged adulterated liquor near slum areas. During the raid, Gorkhi managed to escape but our team caught Rajendra and seized 336 IMFL bottles along with 140 repackaged adulterated liquor bottles, three litres of spirit and a Delhi-registered sedan in which liquor was smuggled and sold,” SHO Arvind Kumar of Sikandra said.

Meanwhile, Sikandra police also arrested a Palwal, Haryana resident Raj Kumar who was wanted for the past four years in smuggling of 210 cartons of liquor in Agra.

Title: Trash cleared from Kukatpally locality after TOI reader posts photo on app
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Hyderabad: After residents of Kukatpally Housing Board Colony (phase 2) complained about heaps of garage lying unattended in their locality on the TOI Citizen Reporter app, Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) swung into action and cleared the garbage.

“The issue had not been addressed for three months. Despite repeated complaints, the garbage was lying unattended. I had aired the grievance in the civic body’s mobile app too, but in vain. So, I thank TOI for highlighting the issue and GHMC for clearing the trash,” said Shiva Krishna, the citizen reporter who highlighted the issue on the app.

While clearing GHMC officials also found a lot of debris under the garbage. The heap of trash had concealed the debris underneath. So, officials are also inspecting the area to catch the offenders.

“The garbage has been removed. To clear the debris, we have approached Ramky Group, who will transport it to the recycling plant,” said V Mamatha, GHMC zonal commissioner of Kukatpally, adding, “The area will also be inspected to check for construction activity. If we catch hold of the offenders, they will be penalised.”

GHMC officials, along with the citizen reporter, inspected the area to check for other grievances. “The sanitation official of Kukatpally called me. I mentioned to him about the other grievances in my locality as well,” said Shiva Krishna.

GHMC officials gave residents of Allwyn Colony phase 2 their mobile numbers. “We interacted with residents and gave them our mobile numbers, so that they can approach us whenever needed,” said a GHMC official from the sanitation wing.

A senior citizen said that the piled-up garbage was resulting in mosquitoes and cattle menace. He also complained about stray dogs. “The cattle and stray dogs further scatter the garbage leading to a lot of inconvenience. Finally, our woes have come to an end,” said the senior citizen.

While GHMC’s chief veterinary officer Venkateshwar Reddy promised appropriate measures to control stray dogs, GHMC chief entomologist, Rambabu, said they would take steps to curb mosquito menace.

Title: Anganwadi workers’ agitation intensifies; medical team sent to examine fasting workers held captive
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

The women protesters were allegedly upset at the medical team for arriving at the site without “adequate prepa... Read More

DEHRADUN: High drama was witnessed at Parade Ground on Tuesday when a medical team deployed for conducting tests of the fasting anganwadi protesters was held captive by them for a few hours.

The women protesters were allegedly upset at the medical team for arriving at the site without “adequate preparations for conducting pathology tests." However, a few moments later, an ambulance equipped with all the medical facilities arrived at the spot.

Notably, this comes a day after the state government issued notices to the protesting workers to get back to work or face action.

Agitating workers meanwhile said that they are now in a do-or-die mode. “We are risking our lives to meet our demands but the health department probably has not understood the seriousness of our protest and instead sent a team of doctors without any proper equipment for pathology tests. We held them captive for their careless attitude towards the health of anganwadi workers , who look after the health of the state,” said Rekha Negi, president, Anganwadi Karyakartri Sevika Karmchari Union.

Meanwhile, the authorities at Government Doon Medical College Hospital (GDMCH), who sent the doctors' team to monitor the health condition of the fasting workers, told TOI, “We are following all the medical protocols. The team had run out of battery of its glucometer, and apart from that, everything was available. The workers are demanding that the medical team visit them at least four times a day which is practically not possible, as we have thousands of serious patients to be attended to per day at the hospital. It is unethical on the part of anganwadi workers to harass our medical staff on duty.” said Dr KK Tamta, medical superintendent, GDMCH.

The workers have been protesting for the past 50 days, demanding Rs 600 daily wage and regular employee status.

However, the state women and child development minister, Rekha Arya, has claimed that their demands have mostly been met.

Title: Gujarat: Corona isolation ward set up at SSG Hospital
Content:
A section of the swine flu ward at the SSG Hospital premises has been converted into corona isolation ward

VADODARA: The state-run SSG Hospital in Vadodara has set up a special corona isolation ward to treat any suspects showing symptoms of the deadly coronavirus , even though not a single suspected case has been reported in the state.A section of the swine flu ward at the Hospital premises has been converted into corona isolation ward.“There were instructions from the state health department besides advisory from the World Health Organization,” said medical superintendent R N Daveshwar, adding that health officials had a conference with all private and government doctors of Vadodara district a couple of days ago on how to prevent and treat the virus. The isolation ward has been set up as part of state’s preparedness as some students from Gujarat are currently stuck in Wuhan city which has been quarantined with all routes in and out of the city closed or regulated due to the outbreak.“Also, there are Chinese companies around Vadodara. The ward has been created as part of preparedness but there is nothing to panic,” Daveshwar said.The isolation ward has 12 beds. “We also have another ward which has 60 beds where we can admit those patients whose condition is not so serious. The total capacity is 72 and if necessary, we can enhance it further,” he said.

Title: UP: 700 AMU students booked for jamming arterial road
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

The protest ended after an assurance from the police and administration that the arrested student would be rel... Read More

AGRA: Aligarh police has registered an FIR against 700 unidentified students of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) for violating prohibitory orders by blocking a road near Chungi gate in the city on Sunday evening. The blockade by the students continued till 2 am.

The students had gathered on the road and staged a sit-in to demand the release of a former varsity student, who was arrested for shouting slogans against the VC along with some other students at the official Republic Day function. During the protest, the students shouted slogans against UP Police and demanded immediate release of Mujtaba Faraz.

The protest had ended after an assurance from the police administration that the arrested student would be released soon. He was subsequently released on a bail on Monday.

Civil Lines circle officer Anil Samaniya told TOI that 600-700 students have been booked under section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) for violating prohibitory orders and section 341(wrongful restraint) of IPC at the Civil Lines police station.

According to the FIR, the students had been informed about section 144 of CrPc, but they willfully defied it and shouted slogans against CAA/NRC.

Meanwhile, an AMU former student, Vakar Naga, who was one of the 52 persons named in the FIR in December 15 violence on the campus, was remanded to judicial custody for 14 days on Tuesday.

Police had registered three FIRs in December 15 violence and initially arrested 26 persons, including seven AMU students. A day later, they all were released on conditional bail.

Title: HC seeks CBI stand on Jagan’s pleas
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Hyderabad: Justice G Sri Devi of Telangana high court on Tuesday sought to know from CBI its stand on the pleas moved by Andhra Pradesh chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy. Jagan was seeking exemption from physical appearances before the trial court in the quid pro quo case filed by CBI against him.

CBI counsel K Surender sought two days to file his counter. The judge gave CBI time till Friday and posted the case to February 6 for further hearing.

There is a hearing this coming Friday and the CBI court judge had refused to dispense with the presence of the AP chief minister, said senior counsel S Niranjan Reddy, while appearing for Jagan. He sought an interim relief from the high court.

Title: ‘No Indian student affected by virus’
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

S Jaishankar in the city on Tuesday

Vadodara: External affairs minister S Jaishankar on Tuesday said the central government is planning to send a plane to coronavirus-affected Wuhan in China to evacuate Indians stuck there.

Jaishankar also said that no student from India has been found to be affected by the virus till date.

“Indian Embassy is in constant touch with the Chinese government. To evacuate Indians we are planning to send a plane to Wuhan. Our efforts are on to bring our people back. It will take some days. I urge people to trust the government on this,” Jaishankar told media on his arrival at Harni airport in the city.

“No Indian student has been found to be affected by this virus. Parents need not worry about their children.” said Jaishankar, who is a Rajya Sabha MP from Gujarat.

Jaishankar was on his way to Kevadiya and was received by officials and elected representatives at the airport.

Relatives of several persons stranded in China have ben demanding that the Union government ensures that they return at the earliest.

Title: Swachh survey: As deadline nears, corpn targets over 1L
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Madurai: With just a few days left for denizens to give their feedback for the Swachh Survekshan 2019-20, officials from Madurai Corporation are targeting at least one lakh people for the survey as the window, which opened on January 4 ends on January 31.

Teams led by officials from the health and engineering wings of the corporation have been tapping colleges and companies, where they can find a large number of people. On Tuesday, students of Meenakshi government college were motivated to give their feedback. Officials said that public are being sensitized before they give their feedback. So far, more than 70,000 people have given their feedback, and officials have set a target of covering one lakh people. Madurai will have to compete with 49 cities in the country for the Swachh rankings 2019-20. From TN, only Chennai and Coimbatore feature in the list other than Madurai. Officials said that Coimbatore has already crossed the one lakh mark, while Chennai is lagging far behind than Madurai in terms of citizen feedback . City health office in-charge Dr Senthil Kumar told TOI that the number of feedback will only mean awareness level among people on the survey and cleanliness activities taken by the local body. Rank will be determined based on whether the feedback sent is positive or negative. Feedback alone will not determine the rankings. Those who give the feedback will be contacted for confirmation and there will also be physical visit by a team to corroborate it.“We are sensitizing people on the feedback and only motivating them. Feedback can be given only after giving one time password sent to their mobile phone. We are doing it in a fair manner without influencing people,” Kumar said.

Madurai Corporation has not fared well in Swachh rankings so far. In the 2018-19 overall rankings Madurai secured the 201st spot, slipping from the 123rd spot it had got the previous year. Officials said the corporation was one among the first local bodies, which has successfully completed individual household latrine scheme. They said that it will help the rankings in a big way this year. Residents can record their feedback through SS2020 VoteForYourCity app, or Swachhata app, or www.swachhsurvekshan2020.org website, or helpline number 1969.

Title: Sheth MJ Library to be solar powered, fully AC: Mayor
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

AHMEDABAD: The AMC, which runs the Sheth MJ Library near Ellis Bridge , has decided to give a corporate look to the library and make it fully air-conditioned. The eight-decade-old library will have the latest sound system and a bar-coding system for the members so that they can get the books issued without any help from the staff.

“We have decided to install rooftop solar panels to meet the energy requirements of the library which runs from 7am to 10pm,” said mayor Bijal Patel while talking to media persons here on Tuesday. She said a provision for this will be made in the civic body’s budget for 2020-21.

According to the mayor, the kid’s section of the library will be spruced up to the liking of the children. “The capacity of the reading room will be enhanced by 150 seats and the hall will be made air-conditioned,” she said.

Apart from these steps, the mayor said that the civic body will organize a heritage week during which books on our heritage will be on display. “Several events will be held during the heritage week,” she added.

Title: Judicial custody of accused extended
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Jaipur: The judicial custody of the two accused in the Pratap Nagar double murder case has been extended till February 10. The accused husband and the hired killer were sent to judicial custody two weeks back after they were arrested on January 10 for the murder of mother-son duo.

The accused husband Rohit Tiwari and the hired killer Saurabh Chaudhary were produced in court on Tuesday which ordered for extension of their judicial custody, confirmed police officials.

Tiwari had planned the murders of his wife Shweta and infant son Shreyam while Saurabh executed this plan on January 7 by bludgeoning both the victims to death.

Tiwari wanted to start his life afresh and was allegedly having marital issues with his wife since the beginning of their marriage. Just two days before the murders, Tiwari had brutally thrashed his wife and even texted her family saying that he would kill her. Shweta’s body was found inside her flat while their son’s body was found dumped in the forest area across the boundary wall of the residential complex are where the family resided.

The circumstantial and digital helped the cops connect the dots. TNN

Title: Burglar decamp with cash and jewellery worth Rs 50L
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Nashik: Valuables and jewellery worth Rs 50 lakh were stolen from the house of a city-based businessman in Sarkarwada area of the city on Monday night.

The police have booked a case against an unidentified suspect and are investigating the case. The businessman’s bungalow, near Raosaheb Thorat hall, is at walking distance from police commissioner’s office. The incident took place between 8pm and 9pm when the businessman had gone out with his family for a walk.

According to the police, the complainant had properly locked and secured his house. Hemant Somavanshi, senior police inspector at Sarkarwada police station, said the burglary took place in just 60 minutes.

“The burglars entered the house by opening the door of the bungalow with duplicate keys and took away the safe kept in one of the rooms of the bungalow. The safe had Rs 1 lakh cash and gold and silver jewellery worth Rs 49 lakh,” Somavanshi said.

When the businessman returned home, he saw the main door was open and the safe kept inside the bedroom was missing. Following this, he lodged a complaint with Sarkarwada police.

“There were no guards or closed-circuit television (CCTV) cameras on the premises of the bungalow. The criminal involved must have apparently kept a watch on the bungalow before committing the theft,” the officer said.

While no one has been detained so far, police said domestic servants of the complainant would also be interrogated. “We would check for CCTV cameras installed in the area to identify the suspects,” the officer added.

The detection rate of house break-in cases in the city is extremely poor. From January 2019 to November 2019, police had registered 242 cases of house break-ins of which only 55 were detected.

Title: Hyderabad News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Shamshabad lake precincts in mess

The sewage problem at Kamuni Cheruvu at Shamshabad is leading to breeding of mosquitos and pigs at the lake. Those residing in surrounding areas have begun to suffer from various diseases. We request the concerned officials to clean the lake and fence the entire water body so that no one throws garbage into it. The lake also needs a sewage treatment plant

— Mohammad Abrar

Chaos at Yousufguda junction

Traffic movement at Yousufguda junction is becoming more and more chaotic each day. Due to the Metro Rail pillar right in the middle of the road and lack of traffic signals, that intersection has become unsafe for commuters. Few days ago, I even saw a couple of motorists engaging in verbal a duel with each other. A proper traffic plan is required in the busy junction.

— Samar Gupta

Potholes, garbage rule arterial roads

Arterial roads in Sainikpuri have been ignored for long by the authorities. The roads have turned into a dumping site for residents of adjoining areas. The uncollected garbage has led to an increase in the number of stray dogs as well. Some of these dogs are extremely aggressive and chase commuters on two-wheelers, especially at night. In addition to this, the roads are full of potholes and during rain, most apartment basements are flooded due to improper drainage. I request the authorities to kindly address our concerns.

— Keshav Rajendran

Residents choke on trash stench

Waste has been piling up at the main circle at Santoshnagar, Saidababd, for several days. As authorities are not cleaning the area, the mosquito menace has increased by leaps and bounds. The overflowing dustbin is also causing unbearable stench. I request the authorities to look into the matter.

— Jalalshavali

Title: No roads, poor sanitation: City slums await basic amenities
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

A spot visit by TOI to Kabari Basti, a slum locality, revealed that dwellers of the settlement do not get regu... Read More

Dehradun: In the biting winter chill, the absence of even the basic facilities has made the lives of slum dwellers in the city all the more miserable.

A spot visit by TOI to Kabari Basti, a slum locality, revealed that dwellers of the settlement do not get regular piped water supply, toilets are scarce in the area, and the stench emanating from the nearby Rispana river is unbearable.

“There is no drainage facility in the area and DMC’s door-to-door garbage collection facility hasn’t reached here yet. The motorable road culminates at PWD office and doesn’t reach our slum,” Samundri Devi, a Kabari Basti resident, said. She pointed out that to add to their woes, residents are also at risk from snake bites. "Recently, a child died of snake bite.There are big bushes here where snakes hide and snake bite incidents had become frequent. So, we requested DMC officials to clear the bushes but were snubbed by them. Thereafter, we pooled in money and cleared the area ourselves,” Devi said.

Bhoora Ahmed, ward councillor of Lohiya Nagar (Kabari Basti), when contacted, claimed that the DMC has been indifferent to the issues raised by residents. "There is not much co-operation from the local MLA as well. But despite all odds, I am trying to work for my area,” Ahmed alleged.

The residents of Lunia Mohalla, another slum settlement near Clock Tower, are also facing similar issues. “The stench from drains here makes it difficult for us to breathe. The roads in our locality are completely damaged and hinder free movement of vehicles and even pedestrians. Many shopkeepers encroach upon public space leading to further congestion,” said Aishwarya Kapoor, a resident.

When queried about these issues, Santok Nagpal, ward councilor of Lunia Mohalla, told TOI, “We are trying to repair drainage facilities here as current structures can’t handle the burden. As for the roads, they will be constructed very soon.”

Meanwhile, Kailash Joshi, health officer, when asked to respond to the concerns of residents, said, “We are working on the issues. Soon, we will ensure regular cleaning of these wards and sort out their other issues as well.”

Title: 3 members of tribal family get buried under mud, die
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Done

Nashik: Three members of a tribal family died after they accidentally got buried under mud at their farm in Borgaon Rokadpada of Surgana taluka — around 65 km from Nashik.

The incident took place at 12.30 pm on Tuesday. The deceased have been identified as 25-year-old Dinesh Khandvi, his 17-year-old brother Manohar Khandvi and their uncle Govind Khandvi — all residents of Rokadpada.

Diwansing Vasave, the police inspector of Suragana police station, said, “The men were in the farm digging mud for their house. They had formed a pit, and the trio was digging deeper. Suddenly, the heap of mud they had dug up and collected on the side of the pit collapsed and fell on them — burying them in the process,” Vasave said.

Locals from the village and two other family members present at the spot did their best to get the trapped men out, but it took them around 15 minutes.

Dinesh and Manohar died of suffocation, while Govind, who was seriously injured, was taken to the Nashik civil hospital for treatment. “He (Govind) died while undergoing treatment at the hospital. Apart from the fracture on his leg, he must have suffered internal injuries that led to his death,” said Vasave.

Borgaon Rokadpada is around 15-km from the Suragana police station and by the time the police team reached the spot, Dinesh and Manohar had already died.

“The deceased were digging mud to use it for their existing house. They had also brought a tractor in the farm to transport the mud to their home. The Khandvi family is into farming,” the officer said.

“Five people had gone to the farm. They were all digging for mud on the hilly patch and loading the tractor. While the three victims were buried under the mud, the remaining two were outside the pit. This saved their lives,” he added.

Title: Seven corpn drivers honoured for 25-year-long incident-free career
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Madurai: Seven drivers working for the corporation and in service with the city corporation for more than 25 years were honoured by corporation commissioner S Visakan for never having been involved in any accident throughout their career. Each one of them were given a 4g gold coin in the recently held the Republic Day celebration. Similarly, 25 drivers who completed 10 years successfully without any incidents were also recognized.

According to sources, there are 48 permanent drivers, 65 drivers on consolidated pay and more than 200 drivers on contract with the Madurai corporation.

S Sivakumar, a garbage truck driver who joined service in early 1990s, said that the recognition has motivated him a lot and brought cheer from his family members, for an otherwise thankless and routine job. He said that it was patience and discipline while at the wheel which helped him in his incident free career spanning close to 30 years.

K Jegadeesan, driver for the corporation commissioner, said the honour has not only motived those who received the recognition, but the entire crew. They vowed that they will be more responsible on the road, he said. Jegadeesan, secretary of Madurai Corporation Drivers Welfare Association, has driven septic tankers, water tankers and garbage trucks, before he was made driver for VIP vehicles. Before taking the wheel of commissioner’s vehicle a year ago, he was the driver for the mayor.

“While driving VIP vehicles, we feel more responsible and vigil on the road. One should know situation of the VIPs while ferrying them in order to take them to the destination at the right time. One has to be thorough on city roads and locations. Since I was born and brought up in the city, it was not a challenge,” he said.

R Raja, R Ganesan, G Manoharan, K Manoharan and K Ravichandran are the other five recipient of 4g gold coin on Republic Day.

Drivers say that apart from discipline and concentration, proper maintenance of vehicles are also key for accident reduction. It is the duty of the drivers to make sure the vehicles are serviced on time and is in condition for the crowded city roads, they said.

Title: Gujarat a hub for production, export of potatoes: PM Narendra Modi
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Vijay Rupani and other dignitaries at the event

GANDHINAGAR: Gujarat has become a hub for production and export of potatoes over the past two decades, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said on Tuesday while addressing the third edition of the Global Potato Conclave 2020 organized at the Mahatma Mandir in Gandhinagar, via video-conferencing.

“The area under potato cultivation increased by 20% in the past 11-12 years in India, however, in Gujarat, the same rose by a significant 170%. The production of potatoes went up due to policy initiatives in addition to modern and sufficient facilities for irrigation,” Modi said. “Government’s initiatives such as Sujalam Sufalam and SAUNI Yojana brought irrigation facilities to areas affected by drought.”

The PM said that the Union government has taken all efforts to take the Gujarat experiment of potato production at a pan-India level. He called for a new policy with dedicated research agenda to promote potato as a sub-sector.

“Potato as a crop has utility in a variety of food products. It is time we encourage potato sub-sector with the new policy and a research agenda. At the root of this policy and research agenda should be the fight against hunger and poverty with a goal to secure global food security,” said Modi.

The Prime Minister also underlined the importance of holding the Global Potato Conclave 2020 in Gujarat, since the state is catching up fast in potato production.

Modi also highlighted the several efforts by the Union government to double farmer’s income by 2022. “It is a target you all are capable of achieving. It is through combined efforts of the government as well as the farmers that India ranks among the top three countries in production of food grains and other items,” he said.

He also emphasised on creating modern and widespread network including farm to food processing to distribution, to make agriculture profitable.

“The government is also promoting farm-tech based startups so that farm database could be used for smart and precision agriculture. This will help farmers in ensuring the right use of water, fertilizers and pesticides, reduce input cost and make farmers more competitive in the global market,” said Modi.

The Prime Minister also laid special emphasis on the need to develop seeds that use less water, are more nutritious and have better shelf-life and productivity.

Title: Agra varsity teachers protest against “corrupt” VC for misusing funds
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

AGRA: Teachers of Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University staged a massive protest against vice-chancellor Arvind Kumar Dixit on Tuesday for allegedly withdrawing Rs 1.5 crore from the account of teacher’s welfare fund (TWF) in violation of norms.

Under the banner of Agra University Teachers Association (AUTA), teachers with placards in their hands marched over 1-km stretch on MG Road and raised slogans against the VC. Later, they handed over a memorandum addressed to governor Ananadiben Patel and chief minister Yogi Adityanath to additional city magistrate Vimal Kumar. The AUTA protest caused a traffic jam on MG Road.

The teachers’ association leaders accused the VC of financial irregularities and demanded that action must be taken against him. Besides, the TWF fund that was withdrawn should be transferred back to the account.

Meanwhile, more than 1,000 teachers of government-aided colleges in Agra and seven other nearby districts remained on strike as a mark of protest against the university administration.

Nishant Chauhan, AUTA general secretary, said, “On January 3, the VC in violation of norms, transferred Rs 1.5 crore from the TWF account to the main account in violation of norms. We want the state government to investigate the entire matter. The fund mandated to be used only for welfare of teachers should be deposited back in the account. Besides, action should be taken against the VC for financial malpractices.”

Earlier on January 20, AUTA had handed over a memorandum to the varsity administration to return the fund withdrawn from TWF within three days. However, the VC did not take any action.

Federation of Uttar Pradesh University Colleges Teachers Association president Virendra Chauhan, who also participated in the protest march, said, “The VC has no right to withdraw the TWF fund. It is a clear case of corruption. In case the funds are not returned, teachers will be filing an FIR against the VC.”

Varsity public relation officer, GS Sharma said, “TWF is generated from the fee provided to teachers for evaluation of answersheets. We had Rs 2.5 crore in the TWF account. Out of this, the contribution of government-aided teachers of Agra is only 10%. Presently, Rs 1 crore is available in the TWF account. The remaining Rs 1.5 crore have been utilized for the construction of a guest house for teachers on Khandari campus. Standard procedure was followed in utilization of the TWF fund and construction work.”

Title: 80% saplings planted on Borkhedi-Jamb section dead
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Nagpur: The tall claims of the ministry of road transport and highways (MoRTH) to have eco-friendly and green highways have been exposed on the 30-km patch of NH-44 (NH-7) between Borkhedi-Jamb, where over 80% of the saplings that were planted have died.

The plight of these plantations, done around two years ago by a private agency BVG, is gloomy. The bamboo tree guards installed to protect the saplings are lying shattered and at stretches in between these tree guards are without any saplings, indicating the plants died.

TOI has pictures of these saplings clicked on Monday evening and on the entire stretch, it seems that the saplings have not been watered and mortality has not been replaced with new ones.

“The poor plantations are against the MoRTH’s ‘Green Highways (Plantation & Maintenance) Policy — 2015 to develop eco-friendly highways with the participation of government agencies, NGOs, people, communities, farmers and private sector,” says district honorary wildlife warden Jaydeep Das.

“The MoRTH has been emphasizing on the need for landscaping highways to reduce the adverse effects of air and noise pollution and soil erosion, but looking at the poor greenery on the most congested Borkhedi-Jamb stretch, the promise of the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) seems to be a farce. NHAI may be planting trees but is not serious about their survival,” said Das.

As per the information received under the RTI Act, in 2012, the NHAI felled 70,508 trees in the 150km road radius from Nagpur to Deori, Amravati, Betul, and Pandharkawda. However, this figure doesn’t include huge tree felling on roads between Saoner-Narsingpur, Mansar-Seoni and Butibori-Wardha-Yavatmal as work on these stretches had not started then.

NHAI regional manager Naresh Wadetwar admits there were some issues with plantation and the agency involved will be pursued to replace mortality of saplings.

NHAI project director NL Yeotkar said, “There is the issue of mortality between 39-46km from Nagpur. Many of these saplings got burned in the fire. The agency has already started work on replacing the dead saplings on one side of the highway.”

However, while travelling on the said stretch on Monday, no labourers working to replace dead saplings were claimed by NHAI.

Das says, “NHAI is to be blamed for poor plantations. It is always in a tearing hurry when it comes to felling trees for road widening but the same enthusiasm is not shown for compensatory plantations. This is even though the Supreme Court has expressed serious concerns over tree felling for road, rail and other projects.”

Recently, the apex court bench headed by Chief Justice of India (CJI) Sharad Bobde observed that “The value of oxygen generated by a tree during its lifetime should be considered in determining the damage to the environment caused by its felling.”

Environment lawyer Manish Jeswani says, “As per the new MoRTH policy, 1% of the civil work cost has to be set apart for highway plantation and its maintenance. This fund is transferred to NHAI to maintain separate fund account called ‘Green Highways Fund’ only for this purpose.”

Title: For 3 days, vehicles zip through Paranur without paying toll
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Chennai: For the third day in a row, vehicles crossed Paranur toll plaza on Chennai’s outskirts without paying user fee as the facility damaged by angry commuters is yet to be repaired.

Back-of-the-envelope calculations suggest this entails a revenue loss of at least Rs 70 lakh. It might take another three days to repair the damage caused when passengers of a state-owned bus ransacked the toll plaza after one of its employees attacked the bus crew during an argument over paying toll.

Motorists are, however, happy that they can zip through without much of a wait. “It is frustrating to wait for 20-30 minutes everyday. Vehicles queue up for more than a kilometre during weekends and festive seasons,” said A Mani, a private bus driver. “We thought it will become better after FASTag was made mandatory. But entering FASTag lanes has become difficult now.”

More than half the vehicles haven’t subscribed to FASTag (digital toll collection system) and pay fee by cash. But only two of six lanes accept cash. So vehicles attempting to enter these two lanes drive across and block those with FASTag, Mani added.

The toll plaza, set up in 2005, has so far collected Rs 609 crore, according to official data. Despite collecting more than what was invested (Rs 540 crore), the rates haven’t been cut, complain motorists.

S Yuvraj of Tamil Nadu Sand Lorry Owners Federation claimed the concessionaire agreement signed with the contractor had expired but toll collection continued.

Title: Eight from Mahisagar stuck in China
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Vadodara: Eight students from the Mahisagar district in Gujarat are stranded in China. Family members have made appeals to the government to ensure their return to India.

Those from Mahisagar, who are presently staying at various locations include Vrund Patel, whose details had come to light on Monday. The others include three students each from Lunawada and Virpur talukas of the district and one from the Santrampur taluka.

The parents of these students have approached officials as well as elected representatives to ensure they are brought back at the earliest. Some parents even posted messages in the social media seeking help.

The reports of the union government planning to send a plane to bring back those stranded in China has come as a major relief to these parents.

Union foreign minister S Jaishankar had said this during a stopover in Vadodara while going to Kevadiya Colony.

Title: Police crack down on diesel autos for violations
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Madurai: The city police have booked more than 200 diesel autorickshaws, operating as share autos, for various violations including seat alteration, without fitness certificate, overloading, without permit and insurance in a special drive carried out on Tuesday.

At least 20 autos were impounded for serious violations and were shifted to the Armed Reserve ground, while the others were released after levying respective owners with fine amount. Officials from both law and order and traffic wing involved in the special drive, carried out in various parts of the city simultaneously from morning to noon.

A police officer said that all inspectors and sub-inspectors issued with electronic device for spot fine were involved in the exercise.

Later in the day as a group of driver, shaken by the stringent action, tried to approach the the collector’s office.

The city police withdrew the drive and instead took the drivers to a marriage hall where they sensitized them on the rules to be followed. “After an array of activities carried out in the past one-week time including awareness activities on the sidelines of the 31st road safety week observation, we found that diesel autorickshaw drivers violate traffic rules blatantly. The drive was carried out to streamline them,” an official said.

A recent RTI reply obtained by the general secretary of the Madurai Consumer Protection Centre G Muniasamy exposed that there are only seven permitted share autos in the city, while there are 12,223 permitted autos in the city. Activists had said that there could be more than 16,000 autorickshaws in the city as many are being operated without permit and taking permit to operate elsewhere.

Title: 70 AMU students demand release of Sharjeel Imam
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Sharjeel Imam. Reuters photo

AGRA: Nearly 70 students of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) on Tuesday gathered at the university canteen, demanding the release of anti-CAA activist and JNU student Sharjeel Imam , who was arrested on charges of sedition, from Bihar’s Jehanabad district earlier on Tuesday.

Imam was booked for allegedly delivering an “anti-national” speech on the AMU campus on January 16 by Aligarh police. The former IITian was wanted by police of several states, including Uttar Pradesh, Assam, Manipur, Arunachal Pradesh and Delhi.

Spokesperson of the university, Shafey Kidwai, said that the administration condemns such activities on the campus and will take strict action against the organiser. “University is not supporting any anti-national activity on the campus,” he said.

Aligarh DIG Akash Kulhary said an FIR will be registered after reviewing the CCTV footage, which has been asked for from the AMU administration.

Title: Govt alerts dist health dept on Coronavirus
Content: Nashik: The directorate of health services of the state government has instructed the district health department to strengthen its screening, diagnosis and treatment system against novel coronavirus (nCov) that broke out in China.Civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale confirmed about the directives received by the district health department for taking preventive measures against coronavirus.Jagdale said that all hospitals in the city and district have been instructed to provide information about severe acute respiratory infection and influenza like illnesses under which children below five years of age may suffer from pneumonia and others may grapple with sudden fever, cough, sore throat and breathlessness.He said that the national virology institute based in Pune is equipped with the machinery to check if a person is affected by any virus.Further, the health department has been instructed to spread awareness about coronavirus and the methods to contract the virus or any kind of infection. These methods include proper way of washing hands, disposing bio-medical waste, etc.The department has also been instructed to ensure that ventilator systems and life-saving machinery is kept at stand-by at hospitals.Health officials said that there is no specific medicine for coronavirus and that the treatment is the same one that is used for treating influenza.They also said that medical superintendents of all rural hospital as well as medical officers at the primary health centres have been alerted about the measures to be undertaken if they come across patients with influenza like symptoms.

Title: Girls to outshine boys at MSU convocation today
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Vadodara: Girls will once again outshine boys during the 68th annual convocation ceremony of M S University which will be held at the university’s convocation ground on Wednesday afternoon.

A total of 12,042 students will be conferred degrees during the convocation ceremony this year. Of these, 7,183 are girl students while 4,859 others are male students.

Even in terms of gold medals, girls will outshine boys. A total of 165 gold medalists will be conferred 280 gold medals during the day. Of these, 107 girl students will bag 175 gold medals while 58 boys will take home 105 gold medals.

Chairman of University Grants Commission professor Dhirendra Pal Singh will be the chief guest during the convocation ceremony which will be presided over by MSU chancellor Shubhangini Raje Gaekwad.

Ahead of the convocation ceremony, MSU felicitated the gold medalists through pre-convocation ceremony - 'We are proud of you' organized at Dhanvantri, the official residence of MSU vice-chancellor (VC), in presence of their parents.

During the ceremony, where chairman of Gujarat Public Service Commission Dinesh Dasa was chief guest, the university felicitated two of its illustrious alumni – retired chief secretary of Gujarat government and IAS Dr J N Singh and eminent scientist Dr Dishant Pancholi, a Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar prize recipient.

Singh recollected his days as a student at the university. “There have been several times when I have received gold medals at other institutes where I studied. But never did any VC or chancellor invite us to their official residence,” he said.

Recollecting his association with the Department of Political Science and Faculty of Arts, Singh said that he received all the required guidance. “This university has tremendous legacy which was created by Sayajirao himself. Its present is equally illustrious. In future, it should rank amongst topmost universities,” he said.

“There are 84.56 lakh citations of works done by scholars of US, which contributes 36 % to global GDP. In the case of China, there are 40 lakh citations and it contributes 22 % of the world trade. Similarly, citations of works done by scholars in Japan and Germany are 8.6 lakh and 8.9 lakh. While Japan contributes 8.8 %, Germany contributes 6.6 % to the world trade. Our country on the other hand counts for 4.3 lakh citations while its contribution is 4 % of the global trade,” he said, while stressing on the need to promote research in the country.

Title: Eight held for murder during clash in Theni
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

Eight people have been arrested on Tuesday in connection with the murders of one of the two victims of the communal clash that took place in Theni district on Monday. A clash between people from the Piramalai Kallar and Kambalathu Naicker (both OBC) communities broke out in Kailasapatti village leaving Jeyabal, 55, and Perumal, 70, dead.

The eight arrested in connection with the murder of Jeyabal have been identified as ‘Bullet’ Murugan, Surendren, Nagaraj, Radhakrishnan, Arun Murugan, Sivakumar, Abimanvu and Selvakumar. No arrests have been made in Perumal’s murder yet. Officials said the men have deserted the villages fearing arrest.

A higher official said that no physical injury was found on Perumal’s body. Although they have registered a murder case, the cause of his death will be known only after the postmortem report is made available.

On Tuesday, south zone IG K P Shanmuga Rajeswaran and Dindigul Range DIG K Joshi Nirmal Kumar visited the village. Theni superintendent of police E Sai Charan Tejeswi told TOI that the situation was under control after the incident and around 200 police personnel have been deployed to maintain normalcy.

The clash broke out between the two intermediate castes as an outcome of small issues brewing between them for long. Jeyabal from the kallar community was involved in the selling of ganja, which did not go well with those from the naicker community, who formed a larger chunk in the village.

Title: Sri Lankan navy arrests eleven TN fishermen
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Madurai: Sri Lankan navy has apprehended 11 fishermen from Rameswaram along with a fishing trawler belonging to them on Monday for poaching in Sri Lankan territorial waters.

The navy was on a regular patrolling in the sea to prevent Indian fishermen from entering and fishing in Sri Lankan territorial waters.

According to fishermen in Rameswaram, more than 600 trawlers left the jetty for fishing on Monday. One of them has been seized by the navy and the crew arrested.

According to an official statement by the Sri Lankan navy, they apprehended 11 Indian fishermen during a routine patrol and seized a trawler belonging to them along with their fish catch for poaching in Sri Lankan territorial waters off the Delft Island. The apprehended fishermen were escorted to their naval base SLNS Elara, from there they will be taken for legal action against them after conducting a medical test.

Sri Lankan naval officials stated that due to the navy’s routine patrols in the island’s waters, the number of trespassing Indian fishing vessels has comparatively reduced.

Title: Gujarat: Man arrested for hacking daughter's Facebook account
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: A 55-year-old man was arrested by the cyber cell of Dwarka town police for allegedly hacking into the social media account of his own daughter and putting up abusive posts.

Mayur Vadgama, who lives in the private township in Mithapur , was traced from the IP address after his daughter had lodged a complaint on January 10 stating that some unidentified person had hacked her account and posted abusive things.

PSI BV Vagadiya of cyber crime cell told TOI that Vadgama's daughter had a love marriage about a year-and-a-half ago, but he was not happy as she had gone against his wishes.

Vadgama had created a fake Facebook account and posted pictures of her husband with expletives , police said. He works in the private company in Mithapur

Title: HC directs corpn to act against illegal construction
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Chennai: The Madras high court on Tuesday directed the city corporation to take appropriate action against unauthorised construction put up by a private school in George Town and report compliance by March 16.

The first bench of Chief Justice A P Sahi and Justice Subramonium Prasad passed the order on a contempt plea moved by social activist Traffic Ramaswamy seeking action against the authorities for failing to obey the court order dated June 4, 2019, and take action against the illegal structure put up by Terapanth Jain Vidyalaya School at Sowcarpet.

When the plea came up for hearing, counsel for housing development department submitted that the department decided on the revision application moved by the school as per the court order and rejected the same.

Therefore, the petitioner cannot claim contempt against the authorities.

To this, counsel for the petitioner submitted that though the revision application moved by the school has been rejected, so far, no action has been taken to remove the unauthorised construction. When the bench sought to know why the corporation has not proceeded further, corporation counsel submitted that de-occupation notice has been issued to the building owner.

Recording the same, the bench observed that the corporation need not show leniency to the school and directed it to proceed in accordance with the law and report compliance. In case, the school challenges the rejection of review application, then the authorities shall take action as per the proceedings of the challenge, the bench said.

Title: Police announce measures to decongest traffic at Dwarka
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Nashik: The city police on Tuesday announced a series of measures to de-congest overcrowded zones in the city, including the Dwarka circle.

A team of the senior police officials led by police commissioner Vishwas Nangare-Patil as well as National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) officials conducted an inspection of the Dwarka circle.

Police restricted movements of all heavy vehicles, including the pick-up vans, trucks, tractors used for ferrying vegetables to Panchavati via the Dwarka circle with immediate effect. With this, all heavy vehicles proceeding towards the circle from the Nashik Road area would be diverted to Takali Road via the Fame traffic signal, Janardhan Swami bridge, Tapovan, Aurangabad Road and Dindori Road.

“A large number of heavy vehicles pass through Dwarka circle every day. We are optimistic that restricting movement of these vehicles would reduce the traffic chaos at that circle,” said police.

The police have also decided to relocate bus stands near the circle. The bus stands will be shifted at a specific distance from the circle so that there is no overcrowding of passengers at the circle.

“There is movement of vehicles on the various service roads near the circle. We have decided to divert the traffic on these service roads to other internal roads to reduce the traffic burden on that circle,” said police officials.

Police have also decided to set up traffic signals at the Dwarka circle. They said that they would write to Nashik Municipal Corporation to set up these signals as soon as possible.

“We have also taken a decision to deploy a dozen traffic police constables at the busy chowk to manage the traffic,” added police officials.

The Dwarka circle witnesses traffic snarls on a daily basis, especially during peak hours as roads merge at this circle from seven directions.

NHAI has shelved its plans for the construction of a flyover from Sarda Circle to Datta Mandir chowk in Nashik Road via Dwarka Circle to ease the traffic congestion.

Title: India’s green battle needs more concrete steps & warriors
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

By: Usama Hazari

Global warming is knocking at India’s doors. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) says India will be one of the first few countries to be completely destroyed by climate change. Our entire water system is under threat, our cities face the fear of turning into gas chambers with zero groundwater, poisonous rivers and coastal regions being drowned. Also, there is the possibility of mass migration because of climate change with half a billion people becoming climate refugees.

Yet, we seem to be dragging our feet on the issue. Despite knowing that India is the world’s fifth most polluted country and the third largest emitter of greenhouse gases across the globe, we aren’t doing enough to save our environment. Around 68% of carbon emissions in India come from the energy sector, but instead of investing in green energy/renewables the government is making things worse by privatising the energy sector, chopping down trees wherever possible and not bringing strong regulations on carbon emissions.

Look at Telangana . While the government here has initiated projects like Haritha Haram, it is, unfortunately, not enough. Mindless mining of coal, lack of investments in research and development (of green energy) and senseless deforestation are proving to be counter-productive and nullifying the efforts made in the name of Haritha Haram.

If you look at Hussainsagar, everyone knows that it is heavily polluted, almost poisonous, and all efforts to clean it has been nothing but an eye-wash. It doesn’t matter how many times you clean the lake – or any lake for that matter — unless you stop pollutants from entering them, nothing will work. The government has to be tough enough and order industries to treat their industrial waste before releasing it into water or air. If nothing is done now, soon, even passing by the Necklace Road will become unbearable and harmful to our health.

If the chief minister really wants Telangana to be habitable for the future generation, he will have to implement a more solid climate action policy, something like a Zero Carbon Emission Bill or a Green New Deal. The people of Telangana need to stop voting for parties that don’t provide us with a green manifesto.

Just because the situation seems hopeless now, we cannot stop fighting. So, let’s come together and build a formidable army of green warriors so that we – and our generations to come – can breathe easy.

The writer is a BA (Mass Communication) student at St Mary's College. He's an active member of the environment group, FridaysForFuture, and runs an unregistered NGO, Phoenix, comprising city youth that works on climate, social and economic issues.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Two kg gold burgled from house, shop of businessman
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Around two kg of gold jewellery and Rs 2 lakh in cash were reportedly burgled from the house and jewellery store of a businessman at Marthandam in Kanyakumari district in the early hours of Tuesday. However, Marthandam police registered an FIR stating that 120 sovereign gold jewellery was burgled.

The burglaries took place in the house and the jewellery store of Pon Vijay of Madathuvilai. The incidents took place when Vijay and his family members were sleeping on the ground floor of the house. Burglars sneaked into the house through a door on the first floor and stole around 50 sovereigns of gold jewellery and Rs 2 lakh in cash. They also took the keys of the jewellery store located at a prominent location in Marthandam.

The burglars entered the jewellery store around 4am. CCTV footage from the store shows a man, who had covered his face with a monkey cap, taking away jewellery.

“The owner is taking stock of the valuables. We will know the exact quantity of the stolen jewellery only when he lodges a complaint,” said deputy superintendent of police of Thuckalay sub-division M Ramachandran.

Kanyakumari district superintendent of police N Shreenath visited the spot and conducted inquiries. Fingerprint experts and a police sniffer dog were also pressed into service.

Talking to reporters, SP Shreenath suspected the hand of someone closely associated with the family of committing the heist on Tuesday as they clearly knew the availability of the key and the shop. “They had taken the key from the house and opened the shop,” he said and added that they have got some clues and working on it.

It may be recalled that around 100 sovereigns of gold jewellery were stolen from a jewellery shop in Marthandam by a man wearing helmet in December. Since the case is yet to be cracked, jewellers have expressed concern.

On the continuance of such crimes in the region, Shreenath said that it is not enough to have CCTV cameras installed. He advised owners to connect the cameras to their mobile phones and an alert mechanism so that they could monitor it round-the-clock whenever there is disturbance or movement of strangers.

Title: Minor raped by father, maternal uncle in Mehsana
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

Title: YCMOU signs 3 MoUs to start new courses
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

NASHIK: The city-based Yashwantrao Chavan Maharashtra Open University ( YCMOU ) has signed three more memorandum of understandings (MoU) to add three more courses to the list.

Recently, the varsity had also established MoU with the city Traffic Education Park under the varsity’s Centre for Collaboration & Special Initiative (CCSI). The National Association for the Blind, Rambhau Mhalagi Prabodhini and Parth Knowledge Network Pvt Limited (PKNPL), Mumbai are the varsity’s new education partners for different courses.

Prakash Atkare, head of the department of CCSI, YCMOU said, “The open university has decided to recognise the courses that are run by these organisations. This will give university recognition to the diplomas or certificates.”

According to Atkare, the students across the state will now be able to take the courses from the varsity’s study centres from the next academic year. The National Association for the Blind is doing a two-year diploma course in Perfumery in affiliation with the Vaze College, Mumbai.

The course is designed by the college for the visually challenged people and nearly 25 students have already enrolled in it for the academic year 2019-20. The college will be responsible for counselling and admissions of the students and will play the role of a study centre of YCMOU, Atkare told TOI.

Rambhau Mhalagi Prabodhini a Thane-based institute has eight students enrolled for the postgraduate diploma in Leadership Politics and Governance. “The students can enroll for this course from the next academic year that begins in June. The syllabus is designed by the institute to help students prepare for the competitive examinations,” added Atkare.

Another course with PKNPL is a three-month online certificate course in Trust Management. The course is being designed by YCMOU and aims to educate the students about the acts, roles, and responsibilities of Maharashtra Public Trust Act as well as provide a hands-on exposure on the Charity Commissioner portal. The course will increase the chances of a student to get a job in the management trusts, said Atkare.

With the help of the MoUs, the students will get the diploma/certificates containing the seal of the organisation and the Open University.

Title: Kevadiya to get skill development centre
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020
