Shah further said that India was expecting to do good business after the Hong Kong market started to recover from a break in the violent anti-government protests there. “However, with the virus threat looming large, we fear that demand for diamonds may diminish,” he said.

According to the GJEPC, the export of polished diamonds to Hong Kong declined 8.45% at $7.41 billion from $8.09 billion between April-December-2019.

Industry sources said Chinese consumers are purchasing diamonds between 30 cents to 2 carats, whereas the U.S consumers are buying jewellery of the diamonds in small sizes below 30 cents.

Managing director of Dharmanandan Diamonds Private Limited, Hitesh Patel said, “Market looked bright in Hong Kong and China after the US-China trade war and long-standing anti-government protests slowed down. However, now we have a virus to combat. We have asked our employees in Hong Kong not to visit China till things settle down.”

Title: Heritage building of VS to be renovated
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Ahmedabad: The heritage building of the VS Hospital, which was set up in 1931, will be renovated. The old building houses six wards.

Addressing a press conference here on Tuesday, mayor Bijal Patel said the budget for the hospital was cleared on Tuesday. She said the civic body has decided to reduce the establishment and non-establishment costs of the hospital.

“The heritage building needs renovation. The existing structure, which will become 90-year-old in September 2021, will be given a facelift but the its original structure will remain intact,” she said.

Patel said Sheth Chenoi Maternity Ward will also be renovated with addition of the latest equipment and infrastructure.

In the budget of the administration, the management had proposed a cut of Rs 19.5 crore in the establishment cost.

Reacting to the budget, Rupa Chinai, who belongs to the donor family, said that the AMC should give in writing as to how it intent to run the 500-bed Sarabhai and Chinai Hospital.

Title: India may invite Australia for Malabar naval exercise with US & Japan
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

If Australia comes on board, it will be for the first time the ‘Quad’ countries will come together for the hig... Read More

NEW DELHI: India is considering inviting Australia to take part in its trilateral Malabar naval exercise with the US and Japan this year, which if it happens will mark the first time the “Quad” countries will come together for the high-voltage combat manoeuvers on the high seas after a gap of 13 years.

There is “a move by India to include Australia” in the 24th Malabar exercise, which will be held in the Bay of Bengal in July-August after the monsoons, but “the final decision is yet be taken”, said sources on Tuesday.

Australian diplomatic sources, on being contacted by TOI, said, “We have a very strong bilateral defence relationship with India. We would be glad to consider all opportunities to engage with the Indian military”. An Australian warship, Anzac-class frigate HMAS Toowoomba, incidentally, is also currently in Mumbai on a four-day visit.

The move to include Australia in Malabar, if it actually translates into reality, will come after India also agreed last year to upgrade the “Quad” dialogue to the foreign minister-level from the earlier joint secretary-level meetings. On the sidelines of the UN General Assembly in New York last September, the four ministers had discussed shared interests in building a free, open and stable Indo-Pacific, with an eye firmly on an aggressive and expansionist China.

India, of course, will have to keep the “China factor” in mind. China had strongly objected to the India-US Malabar exercise in the Bay of Bengal in 2007 when it was expanded to include Japan, Australia and Singapore as well, firm in its belief that a multilateral naval construct was emerging to “counter and contain” it in the region.

This had led India to restrict Malabar to a bilateral one with the US for several years -- Japan was included only when the exercise was held in the north-western Pacific in 2009 and 2014 -- before finally agreeing to make Japan a regular participant from 2015 onwards.

India has traditionally been against any militarization of the Quad to avoid needlessly antagonizing a prickly China. Similarly, New Delhi has also made it clear the US should not “conflate” the Indo-Pacific with the Quad, stressing the centrality of Asean in the former.

If Australia is indeed called for the Malabar, it will be a breakaway from the self-imposed restraint. India, of course, is bilaterally expanding its military ties with Australia. India, for instance, had for the first time in mid-2018 dispatched four Sukhoi-30MKI fighters, a C-17 Globemaster-III and C-130J “Super Hercules” aircraft, along with 145 personnel, to take part in the multilateral “Pitch Black” exercise in Australia.

In April last year, India and Australia also conducted their biggest-ever naval exercise called “AusIndEx” to “build inter-operability” off the Visakhapatnam coast, which was followed by the “2-plus-2 dialogue among the defence and foreign secretaries of the two countries in December.

Title: Facing monkey menace, villagers get ‘under the skin’ rather than ‘bear’ it
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Bareilly: They had no choice. Their village was overrun by over 2,000 monkeys and their repeated pleas with the forest department ignored. All they could have come up with was this rather silly-sounding idea – dressing up two local residents as bears to scare the simians. First, the measure was unconventional and inadequate for a village with a population of 5,000. Secondly, it made them the laughing stock in the neighbouring areas. But for some reason, the plan worked.

The incident occurred in Sikandarpur village of Jalalabad block in Shahjahanpur district.

Village head Ram Lalit Verma, who conceived the idea, told TOI, “We have made a roaster and every man in the village has to wear the bear costume by turn and roam around to keep the monkeys away. A relative who lives in Jhansi told me about the idea. We watched a demonstration before collecting money and buy three bear costumes from a makeup artist for Rs 1,700 each.”

Following the drill, the number of monkey attacks have drastically come down, claim the villagers.

Earlier, 150 cases of monkey bites were reported from the village. The simians were especially targeting children.

When villagers approached the forest department, officials expressed their inability to capture monkeys because of lack of funds.

Shahjahanpur sub-divisional forest officer MN Singh said, “The monkey population is increasing rapidly in the district. We are unable to do much because of lack of funds. Catching a monkey would cost nearly Rs 600 and last time we got funds was in 2018 when we had called a rescue team from Mathura. At present, we can only grant permission to people to catch monkeys on their own or through some NGO and we will help them release the monkeys in forest areas.”

On the villagers’ bear trick, the SDO said, “We will visit Sikandarpur village and check if this bear trick is really working. If so, we would suggest similar action in other villages.”

Title: ‘70% workers outsiders as locals don’t want to work’
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Panaji: The majority of those working in industries in Goa are from outside the state as locals don’t want to do that kind of work, teacher and social worker Sulakshana Sawant said on Tuesday.

“Seventy per cent of the employees of industries here are not from Goa because we (Goans) don’t want to work in factories,” Sawant said, adding that employers who want their businesses to flourish, but aren’t getting the workforce from Goa, are left with no option but to employ workers from elsewhere. Sulakshana, who is chief minister Pramod Sawant’s wife, was speaking as the chief guest at the launch of the women’s North Goa forum of the Goa Livelihoods Forum.

She urged women to change their mentality, and not consider any job below their dignity. Despite multiple schemes encouraging farming, people in Goa keep their lands fallow, said Kamakshi Pai, general manager of the regional office of the National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (Nabard). “One major problem is getting labour. We depend on labour from other states. We ourselves are not interested in working in the fields, and over a period of time, we have lost our agricultural prowess. We have land but have lost our skills,” Pai said.

Nabard hosts several agri-skills programmes and has been promoting horticulture, urban farming, vertical gardens, hydroponics and terrace gardening, she said.

“Nabard is interested in women and in the youth of today. We do a lot of skill and capacity-building programmes for women. The selection of schemes is very important and one must take up an activity that suits you,” Pai said.

Unemployment frustrates the youth and leads them to high-risk behaviour, project director of the Goa AIDS Control Society Dr Siona Gomes, said, referring to the mining ban. “They’re mentally upset and that leads them to substance abuse. They get into high-risk behaviour and their vulnerability of contracting HIV is heightened,” she stated, adding that the society works to impart skills to HIV-positive people, as well as to eliminate stigma and discrimination in society.

The society is working on bringing down the number of new cases of HIV down to 200 this year, she added.

Title: Band, baaja and bovines to lead this Surat baraat!
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Abhilasha and Rohit Garodia

SURAT: This may appear to be skin to the ‘cow jumped over the moon’ rhyme, but Surtis, particularly the invitees to this Februray 3 wedding will have to jostle for space with three unique guests while blessing the bride and groom at the saath-pheras. Beware, they may munch on a few flower petals too!

Taking exclusivity to newer heights, a Surti couple in Vesu will exchange vows in front of their chief guests — two cows and a calf!

In case you are not moo-ved, here are the details. Rohit Garodia, 29, who is pursuing PhD in business administration will marry Abhilasha, 28, a chartered accountant in the typical Hindus vedic tradition including presence of the cows. What’s more, the baraatis will be led to the wedding venue at Maliba Party plot in Vesu by the two-and-a-half cows — all dented and painted in natural colours and decorated with flower and red cloth, befitting baraatis.

While the bovine will put their best foot forward first at the venue, they will be followed closely by the bride and the groom. Wait. There’s more: Cows to have a separate arrangement near the wedding mandap to enable them ‘moo’ their blessings in front of the people.

“We staunchly believe in our Hindu culture where cow is revered as a mother. In ancient Hindu culture, cow is called ‘kamdhenu’, a provider of all nourishments in life. So when we consider her as gaumata, what better can it be than a mother being the chief guest in a son’s wedding?” the groom, Rohit Garodia said while talking to TOI.

He said it was a joint family decision to invite the cow guests and also keeping true to vedic tradition, design the marriage invites in Sanskrit.

The wedding will also be an example on green conscious as the invitations have been made digitally and sent through WhatsApp and email to save paper, the groom said, adding food will be served in steel utensils only. We have ordered more than 5,000 kulhars, in which guests will be served water and other refreshments, he said.

Groom’s father, Rampal Garodia, a textile businessman said, “Both the families are from the same profession and have been friends for a long time. It was our wish to marry our children in accordance to the vedic culture. The presence of cow will make the entire ceremony pious.”

Title: Neta’s car lifted from outside CDO’s house in Gomtinagar
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: The hatchback car of a political leader from Mau was stolen in Gomtinagar on the intervening night of Monday and Tuesday. Earlier this month, nine SUVs were lifted in the city. This is the sixth incident where a four-wheeler has been lifted from Gomtinagar.According to the FIR lodged by Pradeep Singh (28), a resident of Mau, the white hatchback (UP 54 AE 5758) was registered in Mau about one year ago in the name of his uncle Anil Kumar who is a political leader there. The car was lifted from outside a house in Vikrant Khand.Singh said he had reached the city at 5pm on Monday and parked his car outside the house of a close friend, who is a chief development officer, and lives in Vikrant Khand. Singh had locked the car around 11pm and gone to sleep. The next morning, when he went out around 6am, the car was missing. He scanned the area but didn’t find it. Singh then called the police through UP 112 and lodged an FIR at Vibhuti Khand police station.He said that documents related to a court case, a land registry and those of the vehicle itself were kept inside the car. Singh added that scores of vehicles were parked on the road, therefore, Singh sensed no threat to his car.Vibhuti Khand SHO Rajeev Dwivedi said, “We are verifying the statements given by the complainant and also scanning CCTV camera footage in the area.”

Title: Project Roshni fails to provide tech edge to BBMP schools, may be nixed today
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

The project had envisaged bringing digital TVs, artificial intelligence and virtual reality to BBMP classro... Read More BENGALURU: The ambitious Rs 500-crore Project Roshni that sought to rope in Tech Avant-Garde (TAG) to deploy technology in classrooms and enhance the quality of education in BBMP schools is likely to be scrapped on Wednesday. The civic agency and its partner are blaming each other for the endeavour failing to see the light of the day one and a half years after its launch. “Roshni is far from fulfilling its objectives due to the indolence of civic authorities,” said Ali Sait, CEO of TAG. However, a senior BBMP official said Sait is the one citing various excuses and creating hurdles for the project. “Initially, it was the state of school buildings, then it was the painting, later it was the electricity and then elections. The list of excuses he provided is endless. Sait doesn’t seem too interested in starting the project,” added the official. Vrushabendra Murthy, special commissioner, said: “Sait’s favourite excuse is that BBMP has not kept its word on providing the infrastructure. But if they are ready to spend Rs 500 crore, they can also use the money to upgrade infrastructure.” Sait, however, said BBMP officials appeared to be suffering from amnesia. “They don’t remember anything we have done. I myself have taught teachers and children in a Malleswaram BBMP school on using the software . In an Austin Town school, we provided smart boards but they’re all broken now,” he said. Sait said he’s placed orders for smart tablets in Taiwan and they will reach India soon. He added the Palike should have spoken to him directly instead of complaining to others. BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar said several NGOs come to the agency citing CSR initiatives of multinational companies and take up projects but none actually executes them. “Once these NGOs get a letter from the Palike, they use it to raise money from MNCs, but nothing happens on the ground,” Kumar said, adding this is what’s happened in the case of TAG and Project Roshni. “We’ve given them a day’s time to discuss and revert. Else, the project will be scrapped on Wednesday,” he asserted. Where’s the software? TAG had promised us everything, including artificial intelligence to augmented reality and machine learning, but the ground reality is different...They claim to have spent Rs 18 crore on the project in 2019-2020, but where is the software? Our students are not using it — Vrushabendra Murthy , special commissioner, BBMP May have to compromise on tech All the gadgets are being put together in Taiwan and we need to bring them here, which costs money. If BBMP wants us to use the project money on building infrastructure, we will have to compromise on technology — Ali Sait, CEO, Tech Avant-Garde No computers, laptops We’ve been taught how to use the teaching software but don’t have laptops and computers to use it — Principal of a BBMP school in west B’luru

Title: GHMC to build storm water drains across Secunderabad zone
Content:
Last year, heavy spells of rainfall had exposed the lack of infrastructure in various parts of the twin cities... Read More

SECUNDERABAD: As part of its plans for monsoon preparedness, the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation ( GHMC ) will construct five storm water drains and take up desilting work at six locations in division 29 of Secunderabad zone.Last year, heavy spells of rainfall had exposed the lack of infrastructure in various parts of the twin cities. Secunderabad, in particular, bore the brunt of this as overflowing sewage chocked manholes leaving residents vexed.Now, the GHMC recently sanctioned Rs 5.50 crore for storm water drains and Rs 85 lakh for de-silting work. According to officials, new storm water drains will come up at five locations – Street no 8 in Boudhanagar, near Kauser Masjid, Indiranagar, Bapan Basti and Amber Nagar.“Last monsoon, all these areas faced inundation resulting in damage to roads and drainage network. Considering the gravity of the situation, we have called tenders to construct storm water drains at the five locations,” said Secunderabad zone executive engineer for division 29, Pramod Kumar.At Kauser Masjid, the GHMC is trying to revive a 50-year-old storm water drain which is currently in a dilapidated condition. Whereas, in other areas, the GHMC is trying to create new channels.Apart from this, the civic body is also taking up desilting work at six locations which includes – Addagutta, Tarnaka, Lalapet, Mettuguda, Seethaphalmandi and Boudhanagar. “We are taking up desilting work at 9.5 kms of drainage network in Secunderabad zone. We have to complete the work before May 31 in order to prevent sewage overflow during the coming monsoon,” said Kumar.GHMC said it is likely to conclude the work by March-end. Officials said that further inspections will be undertaken to identify other areas where repair work is required to avoid waterlogging and inundation. Residents said there are several other areas such as Malkajgiri, Bowenpally, West Marredpally among others which also need attention.“Every time it rains, we have to wade through waterlogged roads. For years we have been submitting representations to improve storm water drains in our area. But very little has been done,” said Suresh Kumar, a resident of Malkajgiri.

Title: Elopement of couple leads to bitter fight, three arrested
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

SURAT: Three persons were arrested by Amroli police for allegedly abusing and thrashing each other over the ‘elopement’ incident here on Tuesday. One of the arrested accused is the textile businessman, who had run away with his son’s would be mother-in-law, a few days ago.

The other two accused were related to the woman. The elopement created a huge controversy leading to cancellation of the marriage of the runaway couple’s children.

The three accused were arrested after a call for help was made to police control room by one of them. They were arrested as a preventive action to ensure they don’t create further trouble. Both the parties have lodged separate complaints against each other. Police have registered a non-cognizable offence and started investigation.

Police investigation revealed two persons had come to the businessman’s house in Amroli to return the clothes and jewellery given to the bride by the groom’s family. As per tradition of the community, groom’s family sends gifts to bride during engagement and before marriage. One of the person was relative of the bride and had come from Navsari while the other was the mediator through whom the marriage was arranged.

A heated argument started when the duo reached the businessman’s house. They threw the bag containing clothes and jewellery at the businessman, who locked the duo in a room. The duo then called police control room and soon cops arrived at the spot and detained the three.

“We have registered a non-cognizable offence and arrested them as a preventive measure. Two persons had come to return jewellery and clothes given to the bride when the dispute started,” said a police officer at Amroli police station.

Title: Keshava Rao meets SEC, says he has a right to vote in Telangana
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Keshava Rao

HYDERABAD: Rubbishing charges made by Congress that he is still a Rajya Sabha MP from Andhra Pradesh , MP and TRS secretary general K Keshava Rao said he exercised his voting right in Tukkugda municipal chairperson’s election since he was allotted to Telangana in 2014.

Rao claimed a notification was also issued in this regard. He said he was originally allocated to AP, while another MP KVP Ramachandra Rao was allotted to Telangana. “We both gave letters to Centre seeking a swap, which was okayed by the government,” he said.

“It was endorsed by Union minister Prakash Javadekar and a gazette notification was issued,” Keshava Rao told mediamen after meeting TSEC chief V Nagi Reddy on Tuesday. He said he was even registered as an ex-officio member in GHMC earlier.

“KVP gave a letter of his consent seeking transfer to AP. So, he cannot be allowed to vote in Nereducherla. KVP does not even have a normal vote. How would two MPs be allowed to vote as ex-officio members,” he said. On the Rajya Sabha bulletin, which still shows him as an MP from AP, Keshava Rao said he has no idea on the origin of the mistake and only the Rajya Sabha secretariat should be able to clarify on this.

When asked to comment on abolition of the legislative council in AP, he said it was not proper to say that continuing a legislative council was a waste of money. “There is a need for council also,” he added.

Title: Karnataka: HC cites CAA, grants bail to Bangladeshi woman
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: The high court has granted bail to a 37-year-old Bangladeshi woman from the Christian community on the strength of Citizenship (Amendment) Act 2019.

The court cited Section 2 of the amended Citizenship Act 1955, according to which minorities from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan who entered India on or before December 31, 2014 should not be treated as illegal immigrants, while granting her bail.

Allowing the petition filed by Archana Purnima Pramanik, an illegal immigrant from Bangladesh, who claims to be staying in India since 2003, justice John Michael Cunha on Monday directed her to furnish a bail bond for Rs 2 lakh to the satisfaction of the investigating officer and cooperate with the probe.

The judge observed the allegations made against her must be proved in a full-dressed trial. Archana was booked for obtaining documents such as PAN and Aadhaar cards and also fraudulently obtaining an Indian passport on March 28 last year. Based on a complaint filed by the assistant passport officer, Archana was arrested on November 7, 2019 and her bail petition was dismissed by a sessions court on December 4, 2019.

Born on March 23, 1983 at Tanore, Rajshahi district of Bangladesh, Archana came to India in 2003 to pursue a career in nursing. After obtaining a diploma in general nursing and midwifery at Ranchi in 2006, she worked in many reputed hospitals.

In 2010, she got married to Rajashekaran Krishnamurthy and the marriage was registered at Ranchi. After the wedding, she moved to Bengaluru and obtained PAN, Aadhaar and voter ID cards.

On April 1, 2019, Archana applied for a visa to Bangladesh for herself and her son. During her journey on May 20, 2019, they were detained at Kolkata airport and released later. However, the regional passport office issued a notice revoking Archana’s passport and she was arrested by RT Nagar police on November 7, 2019.

Title: Telangana: Siddipet man fined Rs 15,000 for chopping tree
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

After Harish Rao’s call to safeguard trees, officials are taking a serious view of any resident trying to dest... Read More

HYDERABAD: A resident of Siddipet was fined by the authorities to pay Rs 15,000 for chopping a tree in the town. Another resident, who cut down a tree branch in front of his house, was also not spared by Siddipet municipality officials and told to pay Rs 2,000 penalty.

So far, the municipality has collected Rs 2.14 lakh from fines from violators for felling trees or chopping tree branches. S Balachari of Bharathnagar axed a neem tree on the roadside and was told to pay a hefty fine of Rs 15,000. Another resident of the town, Raghupathi Varma, had to pay Rs 2,000 for cutting the tree branch.

With instances of people being penalised for chopping trees increasing, municipal authorities are now granting permission to cut trees in rare cases after ascertaining the situation. Horticulture officer Samalla Ilaiah told TOI that permission was accorded in five instances where construction of houses was taking place. “Those who remove a tree will have to plant more trees after the house is constructed in addition to paying the requisite permission fee,” Ilaiah said.

A resident Donthula Sowjanya, who lives close to the house of finance minister and Siddipet MLA T Harish Rao , sought permission from the officials to axe a tree on their plot before taking up construction of a house. Permission was granted after collecting Rs 5,000 fine. “The fee amount will also depend on the age of the tree,” Ilalaih said.

With Harish Rao asking officials to safeguard trees, which were planted in the last few years as part of Haritha Haram, and other trees, municipal officials along with police are taking a serious view of any resident trying to destroy trees or branches.

Title: Laxman: TRS wins are undemocratic
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Hyderabad: BJP president Dr K Laxman on Tuesday claimed CM KCR and municipal minister KTR had “made a mockery of democracy” by securing the posts in urban local bodies in an undemocratic manner. The BJP chief alleged that TRS had indulged in various tactics to win the elections such as violation of elections norms, distribution of money and misusing official machinery. “The BJP not only fought elections against TRS, Congress and MIM but also strongly faced irregularities by opposition parties, particularly TRS in the municipal polls,” he said. TNN

Title: TRS wins Neredcherla civic body, miffed Cong mulls legal option
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Hyderabad: Amid high drama and a walkout by Congress councillors, TRS on Tuesday won the hotly-contested chairperson and vice-person elections for Neredcherla municipality. The municipality had gotten a hung verdict with both TRS and Congress bagging seven wards each in the 15-ward municipality while CPM managed to win one seat.

In total, the Congress managed to get 10 votes for the top post — seven wards, two ex-officio votes and the CPM’s vote. Until Monday night, TRS too had 10 votes — seven wards and three ex-officio votes. However, they added a fourth ex-officio vote on Tuesday with the support of party MLC Subhash Reddy. The Congress said the TRS’ move was in violation of election rules.

With officials refusing to remove Subhash’s despite objections from Congress, party workers staged a walkout even as officials began the election process. The election was held in absence of Congress workers and TRS secured posts for both chairperson and vice-chairperson.

Telangana Congress president N Uttam Kumar Reddy said the party was examining legal options as they claimed the TRS’ move was in violation of orders by municipal administration department and state election commission. “There are certain matters with the high court which I cannot disclose... I will raise the issue in Parliament and also bring the issue to the notice of Chief Justice of India,” Uttam told reporters in Hyderabad. Earlier, the TPCC president along with MP KVP Ramachandra Rao had been taken into custody by police after they had staged a dharna in front of the Neredcherla municipal office following the walkout.

“After two members were sworn in and a third swearing in was going on, the TRS MLA started throwing a tantrum and election officer postponed the polling. Then KTR got into action and exerted pressure on the state election commission to add TRS MLC Subhash Reddy’s name to voters list this morning. This symbolises the manner in which municipal elections were held,” Uttam said. “Despite Congress having a majority in Neredcherla, TRS and state election commission brazenly misused government power and manipulated the election,” he added.

TRS functionaries, on their part, said Congress was free to go to court. “The Congress brought KVP from Andhra Pradesh into the voter list after the councillors’ oath... Uttam is frustrated and is not able to digest the defeat,” TRS ex-officio voter B Venkateshwarlu said.

Title: BBMP garbage trucks to get a wash after trips to landfills
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Garbage trucks are a common sight on city roads

BENGALURU: It’s not uncommon for Bengalureans to endure the stench emanating from a garbage truck in the neighbourhood or at traffic signals. But this nauseating experience could soon be a thing of the past. The Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP) is all set to make it mandatory for compactors (garbage trucks) to get a wash after offloading trash at dumpyards.

To start with, a compactor cleaning unit will be set up at Mittaganahalli landfill, Bengaluru east. Water sourced from the leachate treatment plant at the landfill will be used to clean the compactors. “The idea is to ensure these trucks don’t stink, at least when they are parked or are on their way to lift garbage,” BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar told TOI.

Bengaluru generates around 5,000 tons of garbage per day and the same is transported to landfills in around 500 compactors. Currently, the trucks return from the landfills without being cleaned. The cleaning unit will be set up in such a way that once the compactor unloads the trash, it will be sent out only after a wash.

Businessman Sajjan Raj Mehta, who often travels by a two-wheeler, said the move will bring much respite to motorists. “The compactors aren’t maintained in a hygienic manner. If I get stuck behind a compactor, my immediate reaction is to overtake it as fast as I can in order to avoid the foul smell. Almost every rider in Bengaluru does the same thing the moment they notice a garbage truck.”

Traffic police too welcomed the move. “There have been instances where bikers have met with accidents in the haste to get away from garbage compactors,” a traffic constable said.

Vasant Raju, who commutes to work on a bike, felt the initiative was long overdue. “There have been instances when I had to speed just to escape the foul smell from compactors. I think it’s a great start,” he added.

After the Mittaganahalli landfill, the cleaning project will be rolled out at Hullahalli and Marenahalli landfills. “We will gradually expand the initiative. Following the landfills, we will come up with similar units at the seven other waste processing centers in the city,” said BBMP special commissioner Randeep D.

The BBMP chief said the Palike intends to implement the same system for builders “We will tell them to ensure their concrete and mud trucks are washed on the project site in order to reduce dust on roads.”

Title: BBMP developing single-window clearance system for highrises
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Photo used for representational purpose only

BENGALURU: Securing prior approvals for construction of highrises in the city could soon become a breeze. With BBMP developing a software, which will put in place a single-window clearance mechanism, builders will be spared the trouble of visiting multiple civic agencies for approvals.

“The Building Plan Approval System (BPAS) software is in its final stages and we will launch it soon,” said BH Anil Kumar, BBMP commissioner. The software is expected to be operational in a month.

“The software will allow an applicant to fill a form online, which will then be sent to all other civic agencies for approval. The application fee will be decided based on the land value,” he added.

The move comes in the backdrop of the World Bank deciding to also consider Bengaluru and Kolkata while arriving at India’s ease-of-doing business rankings. Till now, it had been considering only New Delhi and Mumbai. The BBMP’s single-window clearance system is expected to push up India’s ranking, which is currently 63.

The work on BPAS began after Kumar, mayor M Goutham Kumar and other Palike officials recently visited the Municipal Corporation of Greater Mumbai (MCGM). MGCM has an online no objection certificate (NoC ) approval software through which all the required approvals are routed and people are said to be more than happy with the system. “The approvals are granted real-time and people are able to keep track of their applications,” said mayor Goutham Kumar.

“Soon, we will be implementing the same technology in BBMP. More than 10 agencies, including BWSSB, BESCOM, GAIL and BDA have to grant approvals for construction of highrises and this only delays things,” explained Anil Kumar.

According to another senior BBMP official, zonal officers have the power to sanction buildings less than 15 metres high, but anything above needs clearance from BBMP central office.

“In the current process, at least 90 days are lost in getting approvals from various agencies. Through BPAS one can get all the required approvals within 10 days,” said Anil Kumar.

Under BPAS, a date will be fixed for officials from various civic agencies to jointly visit the site for inspection. BPAS will also have a provision for ‘deemed approval’. If a civic agency doesn’t grant approval or raise an objection within the stipulated time, the project will be deemed to have got all clearances and any liability will fall on the civic body.

“The various civic agencies involved in granting approvals will have to get their act together, failing which they’d be held responsible for any violation,” said a senior BBMP official.

Confirming that all civic agencies are on the same page on BPAS, Anil Kumar said: “We are holding meetings with officials of other civic agencies and discussing the modalities.”

Title: Goa staring at Rs 3,400 crore loss due to mining closure: Report
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Stoppage of iron ore mining in Goa has impacted revenues worth over Rs 3,400 crore and the livelihoods of seve... Read More

PANAJI: Unemployment and retrenchment due to mining closure has not only devastated families economically, but is also threatening the social fabric of the state besides negatively impacting the confidence of investors, the Goa Livelihoods Forum has stated in its Livelihoods Report 2020 released at an event on Tuesday.

Stoppage of iron ore mining in Goa has impacted revenues worth over Rs 3,400 crore and the livelihoods of several dependent segments have been affected due to ceasing of mining activities. It has left industry stakeholders without any alternative sources of income.

“Not confined to only the mining talukas, income and savings have been severely hit, exceeding well over 40% in most of the caseslt,” the report stated.

“The stoppage of mining in the state has not only caused revenue damage and job loss within the state, but has also led to major loss of investor confidence, which would have a long-term negative impact on Goa’s economy,” the report stated.

Regional and rural areas may experience severe economic upheaval where unemployment has been known to induce substance abuse, the report said.

Criticising the Supreme Court’s verdict, the forum stated, “In the national debate on mining, both in courts and civic societies, the voices of these people are lost.”

“The decision has directly impacted more than 60,000 households and three lakh livelihoods in the state. The ban has stopped potentially 20 million tonne of iron ore exports. It has disrupted an entire ecosystem of downstream, upstream and allied industries, including logistics suppliers, individual truck owners and barge owners as well as equipment suppliers,” the report stated.

Over 90% of the responses indicated the loss of livelihoods as the most significant factor worrying the communities. The strongest negative predictor of the acceptance of mining was the impact on the environment followed by the impact on agricultural and tourism sectors and impact on living cost.

“Majority of the respondents in the mining belt stated that they hoped that the state and central government come together to resume mining by any means as necessary in the next few months as another year without any source of livelihood for them would result in a socio-economic catastrophe on them from which there would be no return,” the report stated.

Title: Coronavirus in Bangalore: Two more suspected novel coronavirus cases in hospital
Content:
Representative image

BENGALURU: Two more people suspected of exposure to novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) were admitted to Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases (RGICD) on Tuesday.Both had travelled to China last week and arrived at RGICD, complaining of symptoms of the virus.In all, four suspected cases are currently under observation at RGICD. Another patient, whose test results came negative, has been discharged. Samples of the patients have been sent to National Institute of Virology, Pune for testing.On Tuesday, the state health department conducted an awareness programme on coronavirus for private and government hospital doctors.Between January 20 and 28, over 3,275 passengers have undergone thermal screening at Kempegowda International Airport (KIA) to detect exposure to 2019-nCoV. No positive cases have been detected so far. Among those screened, three had visited the affected city of Wuhan in China’s Hubei province.Passengers arriving from Singapore, Hong Kong and Kuala Lumpur are being screened at KIA and help desks have been set up at international arrivals.

Title: Bengaluru: Duo bought, sold bikes on OLX, used them to snatch chains
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Two people who allegedly bought bikes and scooters on online marketing portal OLX to snatch chains have been arrested in the city. Police said the arrests have helped them crack nine chain-snatching cases.

Friends for seven years, Rama Murthy, 33, a resident Chikka Banaswadi and Karthik, 35, a resident of Electronics City, worked as labourers before starting a business venture that flopped, leaving them with huge debts. The duo decided to take to chain-snatching after reading about the crime in newspapers.

They watched YouTube videos and trained themselves for a month. Acting as agents, they would buy bikes from OLX and later post ads on the same portal to sell them off, but only after using the two-wheelers for five to six days to snatch chains at different places.

Police said the purchase and sale operation was nothing but a sleight of hand: the vehicle’s documents would remain in the name of the original owner and even if police managed to find out the registration number of the vehicle used to commit the crime, the trail wouldn’t lead to the culprits. Investigators said the duo was caught for the first time, but they confessed they were into chain-snatching for nine months. However, their failed attempts outnumbered successful ones. Police have recovered three two-wheelers and 307g of gold ornaments worth Rs 15 lakh from the duo.

Title: ‘Pepper spray’ snatcher duo held
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Secunderabad: Sleuths of CCS Malkajgiri and Medipally police on Tuesday arrested two persons involved in a snatching case last month.

Police recovered a 30 gram gold chain from their possession. The accused were identified as Pappula Bhanuvikas and his associate Sakinala Manasa. Both are childhood friends.

The victim, a 54-year-old housewife from Medipally’s had come back from the bus stop when the duo visited her house asking for some drinking water.

When the woman went inside to get the water, they attacked her with pepper spray while she was in the kitchen and robbed her gold chain from her neck.

According to police, the duo would operate in newly-developed colonies and targeted women who were alone in their house.

They would then use pepper spray on the victim and rob their gold. Bhanuvikas and Manasa were caught during a vehicle check at Boduppal Kaman.

Title: Make KTR’s call data public, says Cong
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Hyderabad: Congress on Tuesday demanded that call data of election authorities and municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao be made public. “The call data of election officials involved in Neredcherla polls and that of ministers — KTR and G Jagadish Reddy — will clearly expose that they had colluded to ensure victory of TRS,” Congress election committee chairman Marri Shashidhar Reddy said. TNN

Title: ‘BJP colluded with TRS, MIM in Nalgonda’
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Hyderabad: Congress MP Komatireddy Venkat Reddy on Tuesday said TRS won the Nalgonda municipality chairperson post with the help of BJP and MIM. He said Congress enjoyed majority in Adibhatla municipality also, but TRS doled out huge money to win both posts there.“If needed, we will also go to court against the TRS violating election norms to win municipal chairperson posts...,” he said. TNN

Title: Still oppose Metro car shed at Aarey: IIT-Bombay professor
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Shyam Asolekar said that he stands by his decision to oppose Metro card shed at Aarey

MUMBAI: Though the Metro-III car shed at Aarey is a done deal, Shyam Asolekar, professor at Centre for Environmental Science and Engineering, IIT-Bombay , said he stands by his decision to oppose it.

Asolekar, along with Rakesh Kumar, director, National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, who were appointed members of the technical advisory committee by the Devendra Fadnavis government to find an alternative site to Aarey, had filed a dissenting note on locating the car shed there.

At a seminar titled ‘Urban Climate Resilience: Aarey and Mumbai City’ at Mumbai Press Club on Tuesday, Asolekar said he wrote the dissenting note as he believed in it.

In the note, both Asolekar and Kumar said the proposed car shed site at Aarey was right next to Mithi river forming its catchment. “If the car shed is constructed, then during monsoon the water rentention ability of the plot will be lost to concretization. Hence, all the excess run-off water will find its way in Mithi, which will increase the risk of downstream flooding in Chakala and the international report,” read the note.

Asolekar said the trend globally was to counter every argument to protect the environment by saying there is a technological solution. “Technology cannot offer solutions for all environmental degradation. When taking up monumental projects we need to instead ask what is good for the environment. What we should not do and what should not be used,” he said.

Technology, said Asolekar, is not the solution for environmental destruction. “Social engineering and a business model based on equitable justice is the only way to get over confrontations and avoid environmental degradation.” He recounted the revival of a lake around Jaipur’s Amer fort not only brought in a variety of birds but also revived the local economy. Maha Vikas Aghadi government has appointed a new committee headed by additional chief secretary Manoj Saunik to suggest an alternative site.

Title: BBMP council proposes two per cent cess
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Property owners may have to pay 2% of their property tax in the form of land transportation cess from financial year 2020-21.

On Tuesday, the BBMP council decided to collect 2% cess and inform the government that it would be used for maintenance of roads, drains and streetlights. The council decision will have to be cleared by the urban development department.

The collection of 2% property tax as land tranportation cess was allowed by an amendment to the KMC Act, in 2013. The council had on June 2018 approved the proposal to reintroduce collection of LTC in order to provide better infrastructure for vehicles in the city.

“BJP leaders opposed the cess then, stating it would burden taxpayers. But how are they agreeing to it now,” asked Abdul Wajib , leader of the opposition, adding, “Now since there are no funds, they have decided to collect the cess.”

BBMP had earlier refused to hand over LTC to the directorate of urban land transport. “All the facilities are provided and maintained by the Palike. Why should we give the money to some other agency?” wondered council member Muneendra Kumar .

Title: SEC lobs ex-officio members voting issue into government’s court
Content:
K Keshava Rao

HYDERABAD: The din over allowing five ex-officio members — Rajya Sabha MP K Keshava Rao and four others — to utilise voting rights in the poll to elect Tukkuguda municipal chairperson took a new turn on Tuesday with Telangana State Election Commission (TSEC) lobbing the issue in the municipal administration department’s court.“Registration of ex-officio members and allowing them to vote in any municipality comes under purview of government — in this case, the municipal administration department. As far as Keshava Rao exercising his voting right, only the Rajya Sabha authorities can clarify on the matter,” TSEC secretary M Ashok Kumar told TOI on Tuesday.On the other hand, director of the municipal administration TK Sreedevi disassociated herself on the issue, saying it was the decision of the supervisory officer to allow the ex-officio members to vote. She said the local supervisory officer and adjudication officer (local municipal commissioner) will have to respond on the issue.A controversy broke out over granting voting rights to Keshava Rao, minister P Sabita Indra Reddy, MLCs — Nayani Narasimha Reddy, Yegge Mallesham and Katepally Janardhan Reddy — in Tukkuguda. Both Congress and BJP alleged that all the five ex-officio members were allowed to move from Badangpet municipal corporation to Tukkuguda and termed it illegal. Congress also questioned as to how Keshava Rao, who was allotted to Andhra Pradesh, was allowed to exercise his franchise in Telangana.Sources said all five ex-officio members were first registered with Badangpet corporation on January 25 as TRS was not sure about winning the mayoral post and where their votes could prove to be crucial. However, TRS got a shot in the arm in Badangpet with some members joining the party after they got elected on a Congress ticket. The ruling party felt there was no need of ex-officio members in Badangpet and moved them to Tukkuguda next day — January 26 — where the party did not have required numbers to win the chairperson post.As per section 5 of the new Municipalities Act-2019, an ex-officio member registered with a particular urban local body to exercise is vote is final and irrevocable. “The five ex-officio members gave in writing on January 26 to register their names in Tukkuguda to allow them to vote. As per the Act, they can register within 30 days and I allowed them. I was not aware that they were earlier registered in Badangpet and withdrew from there,” Tukkuguda commissioner R Gnaneshwar told TOI.Interestingly, Sreedevi and commissioner, TSEC, V Nagi Reddy had announced at a recent joint meeting that the ex-officio members were required to register by giving option of municipality where they were planning to utilise their voting right before 5 pm on January 25 and they cannot change the option. But, according to the Act, ex-officio members can give their option within 30 days from date of election in writing duly signed by them, specifying the municipality.Badangpet municipal commissioner C Satyababu refused to comment over the issue, saying that “it is a closed chapter.”

Title: Notice for resolution against governor admissible: Kerala assembly speaker
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Kerala assembly speaker P Sreeramakrishnan. (ANI photo)

Title: 10-year-old raped by 50-year-old uncle in Shahjahanpur
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: A 10-year-old girl, a student of Class III was allegedly raped by her 50-year-old uncle in a village in Shahjahanpur district on Monday.

Finding her alone at home, the uncle allegedly barged into the house and raped her. Upon returning home, the girl’s mother found her crying in pain and rushed her to a hospital, where doctors told her that her daughter was "sexually assaulted”. After regaining, the girl, too, told her parents about the crime.

An FIR was registered against the uncle and police are searching for him.

On Monday, the girl’s father and brother, both labourers, left for work and her mother went to a cow shelter in the village for making cow dung cakes, leaving her alone at home when her father’s younger brother barged into the house and raped her.

The medical examination of the girl was conducted a primary health centre (PHC) in Tilhar by emergency medical officer Dr Shalini on Tuesday and the report is awaited. The girl was, however, discharged from the PHC after her condition improved.

The mother told TOI, “Upon returning home, I found my daughter wriggling in pain. I took her to a doctor with the help of locals and informed my husband about her condition. Later, we came to know that my brother-in-law raped her. He is absconding. I have demanded stringent punishment for him.”

Additional superintendent of police (rural) Aparna Gautam said, “We have registered an FIR against the accused under sections 376 (rape) and 452 (house-trespass with intent to hurt) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and under relevant sections of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act. The girl is stable after treatment. We have deployed several police teams to arrest the accused at the earliest.”

Title: Dowry slur: Two women found dead, FIRs lodged in UP
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: In two alleged cases of dowry death, a woman was found hanging in Alambagh while another died after falling from her home’s terrace in Krishnanagar.

The families of both women alleged they were killed by their husbands for not fulfilling the dowry demand.

Two separate FIRs have been lodged with Krishanagar police station and Alambagh police station.

In the first case, Shagufta was found hanging in her husband’s home on Monday night. Her mother Wasima Bano lodged an FIR against Shagufta’s husband Mohammad Asif at Alambagh police station on Tuesday. Shagufta and Asif got married five years ago. Bano alleged Asif had been harassing her daughter for dowry after they got married. Asif had been demanding Rs 1.5 lakh, a motorcycle and e-rickshaw, Bano alleged and added that Asif and his family members killed Shagufta and hanged her.

In another case, Neha Srivastava died after falling from the terrace of her home in Krishnanagar. She was married to Alok Srivastava six months ago. Neha’s brother Prakash has lodged an FIR against Alok and her brother-in-law Dilip with Krishnanangar, accusing them of killing Neha for dowry.

On Saturday, Dilip informed Prakash about the incident and asked him to reach a private hospital in Krishnanagar where Neha was admitted. Neha died in the hospital. Prakash told police that Alok was an alcoholic and had been harassing his sister for dowry. He claimed Alok was drunk on the day of the incident and threw Neha off the terrace.

Police are verifying the allegations of the two families. But prima facie it appears that the two women were being harassed by their husbands and committed suicide, police said.

Title: Selfie with a tank, stay in a bunker at DefExpo
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Lucknow: The Defence Expo will give visitors a chance to get up close and personal with armoury like tanks and small arms. There will be 12 selfie points spread over the two venues—Gomti Riverfront and Vrindavan Yojana. People will be able to click photos with the T-90 and BMP tanks, a model of the Heptr chopper and sail boats, among other equipment.

One will also be able to experience a bit of a soldier’s life in harsh climates with a model of a field living bunker and suits worn by soldiers in Siachen also available for selfies.

An obstacle course is being created at Gomti Riverfront where visitors will get a chance to test their fitness by crawling under wires, crossing a ditch and climbing vertical ropes. A nuclear, biological and chemical suit wearing competition will also be held, while a reflex shooting range will allow visitors to test their shooting skills.

The defence ministry has said that over 989 exhibitors, including 165 foreign companies, have registered for the expo so far. This has surpassed the attendance at the 2018 DefExpo. The booked exhibition space has gone up by 58% to over 42,800 sqm compared to around 26,774 sqm during the last edition. Defence ministers and service chiefs of 18 countries have confirmed their participation at the event.

The inaugural ceremony for the expo is scheduled to take place on February 5. Live demonstrations by Indian Air Force and Indian Army and military equipment developed by DRDO will also be on display. The Corps of Signals will perform a daredevil show which is being touted as a major highlight of the event.

Title: Corporation to set up six material collection facilities
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Kozhikode: After the successful construction of super material recovery facility (MRF) centres, the city corporation authorities have now taken steps for the construction of mini material collection facility (MCF) centres under the Zero Waste project.

It will set up centres at six selected locations. The MCF centres will be coming up at the eastern side of health office circle office at West Hill, near NSS School, Puthiyapalam, veterinary hospital premises situated on Wayanad Road stretch, Elathur Industrial estate, Rahman Bazar fish market and Kampuram. The civic body will set up MCF centres having a space of 73.81sq m at four locations and 36.36sq m MCF centres at two locations.

The civic body will construct the centres at a cost of Rs 50 lakh adhering to the model provided by Kerala Suchitwa Mission. There will be nine compartments at the MCF centres to store the collected non-degradable waste from the houses and establishments. The MCF centres will store the non-degradable waste such as plastic, metals, glass items, e-waste, hazardous waste, footwear, leather, thermocol, till the civic body disposes of it.

The spots for the construction of the MCF were identified on the basis of locations identified by the corporation health inspectors in their respective health circles. The civic body will set up MCF centres at 10 more places in the next phase. The construction of super material recovery facility centres at Njeliyanparamba and West Hill Industrial Estate have been progressing on a war footing.

The civic body health officials have already commenced distribution of notices and user fee cards to house and building owners in the 75 corporation wards to encourage them to enrol their names with the civic body for the door-to-door collection of non-degradable waste.

K M Gireesh, project manager of Kozhikode corporation Zero Waste project, said segregation of non-degradable waste will take place at the source points itself. “The proposed MCF centres will be used to store segregated non-degradable waste before disposal,” he said adding that the construction of MCF centres will be completed within two to three months from the day of work commencement. “The zero-waste project will be expanded to all the corporation wards once the MCF centres are ready,” he said.

Title: Land owner booked for stealing government’s rubble
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Surat: A resident of Jujva village was booked at Valsad town police station on Sunday for allegedly stealing rubble worth Rs3 lakh dumped on his land to level it for parking during Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s visit in August 2018. The offence was registered after Gujarat high court asked police to investigate the theft on a PIL filed by a native of Valsad district.

Bipin Patel was booked for allegedly stealing the rubble dumped on his land by panchayat department’s road and building division. Modi was visiting Valsad to inaugurate an irrigation project and address a public meeting.

Due to non-availability of enough government land, Patel’s plot was used for parking of vehicles after taking his approval. Patel had written to the department to remove the rubble from his land after the event was over but it didn’t, Anil Patel, executive engineer, panchayat department, said in his complaint.

“An RTI activist alleged that the rubble was stolen and complained to local authorities and also approached the high court. Following the PIL, the high court asked police to inquire into the matter after which an offence was registered,” a police officer said.

Title: Medical student on vacation from China under observation
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Surat: Sidhhi Pandya , 18 , a medical student , arrived home in the city on January 13 to give surprise to her family on her birthday, but this has saved her from a nightmare as Wuhan city of China is battling coronavirus for the past few days.

Pandya, a second year student of MBBS at Hubei University, is now being examined daily by a government medical team to verify if she was infected with the deadly virus. She has been declared healthy and normal, but is likely to be kept under medical observation for a few more days. Members of her family are also being kept under watch by the health officials.

“We are subjecting the girl to daily medical checkup. Her health is normal at present but she is being examined regularly,” said a health official of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC).

Pandya did not inform anyone in the family of her arrival and had booked tickets from her savings in October 2019, and left Wuhan on January 12.

“All members of her family were surprised when she arrived. We were slightly unhappy about unnecessary spending, but now feel relieved as she was able to escape coronavirus there. We think she is lucky,” a family member said.

“I had some savings and wanted to celebrate my birthday on January 26 with my family. This is why I came here. I am worried for my friends who are still there. I wish they are safe. My friends told me that they were being helped with food and water by university teachers. But they and their family members are very tense,” Sidhhi said.

She said there were about 10 students from Gujarat in Wuhan and they are not being allowed to leave the city. Pandya was to return to Wuhan in February but her vacation is likely to be extended.

Health officials from Centre and state government contacted her soon after her arrival and informed her on the need to keep her under medical observation.

Title: Two arrested for killing birds in UP's Shahjahanpur district
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: Two persons were arrested and carcasses of birds were seized from their possession at Chachuapur village under Jalalabad police station in Shahjahanpur district.

According to forest officials, Jalalabad police received tip-off that two persons were poaching birds. When police reached the spot, they arrested Rijwan and Ismail Ansari. Police later seized the carcasses of seven birds and meat suspected to be of nilgai from their vehicle. Police also seized one gun and a vehicle from the accused.

Divisional forest officer, Shahjahanpur, Adarsh Kumar said, “Seven birds which were killed are Mulard, Common pochard and Spoonbill Egret. They are not migratory birds but are commonly found in the country. Police also recovered meat from them and it is suspected to be of nilgai. We are awaiting the postmortem report to confirm the animal.”

Police said both accused have been booked under relevant sections of Indian Wildlife Act. They were sent to jail after they were produced in a local court.

Title: Assembly session begins today, budget on February 7
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Kerala governor Arif Mohammed Khan in assembly. (ANI)

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The assembly’s budget session will begin on Wednesday with governor Arif Mohammed Khan’s address and finance minister T M Thomas Isaac will present the state budget for 2020-21 on February 7.

The House will pay tributes to (late) MLA Thomas Chandy on Thursday and there will be 10 days of business during the 18th session of the 14th Kerala assembly. A day has been set apart for legislation, to introduce the bills —Kerala Panchayat Raj Act (Amendment) Bill, 2020 and Kerala Municipality Act (Amendment) Bill, 2020— aimed to increase the number of electoral wards in local bodies.

Three days each have been earmarked for motion of thanks to governor’s address and for discussions on budget and the session will end on February 12. The House will not be in session on Friday, the day on which the crucial BAC (business advisory committee) meeting will be held to decide on Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala’s notice to move a resolution demanding the recall of Khan.

“The session will also witness the introduction of ‘e-Niyamasabha’, the programme for total digitization of assembly proceedings,” said speaker P Sreeramakrishnan on Tuesday. Arrangements have been made to present both the governor’s address and the state budget in digital format, he said.

Title: Tourism dept looks at docking Drishti’s Rs 1-cr bill
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Panaji: The tourism department has proposed that the total bill raised by Drishti Lifesaving for the last quarter of 2019 be reduced by one-third as there were less men deployed during the period due to the strike by lifeguards.

“The deduction suggested has been submitted for government approval after which the decision will be conveyed to Drishti,” an official said.

Drishti has raised bills totalling over Rs 1 crore for October, November and December 2019, an official said. On verifying them, the department found fewer lifeguards had been deployed on beaches during the period as many had gone on strike, he said. “Accordingly, the department has suggested a one-third reduction in the total bill raised,” the official said.

Over 100 lifeguards had gone on strike initially, demanding that their arrears be paid with immediate effect. Some had also demanded that they be employed by the government. Some lifeguards had continued to protest until recently. The tourism department has recently extended Drishti Lifesaving’s contract by two-and-a-half years.

The official said that the tourism department is set to sign a formal agreement with Karnataka Commercial Industries Pvt Ltd, a new beach cleaning agency appointed in September, for a period of three years at a cost of Rs 30 crore. The contract can be extended to two years subject to conditions.

Title: New teacher-friendly transfer policy to benefit 50k employees
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Lucknow: If you are a teacher in government-aided secondary school and your spouse is a UP government servant posted in another district, you can now rejoice.

The newly-introduced transfer policy has made arrangements to make lives of such teachers easy by shifting them to the place of their spouse’s posting. The policy is likely to benefit over 50,000 teachers.

According to the transfer policy released by principal secretary, secondary education, Aradhana Shukla, transfers of government-aided secondary teachers will be completely online.Online applications for this year will remain open from March 1-15.

With new policy in place, principals and teachers seeking transfer will no longer have to knock the door of their management to get a no-objection certificate.

The policy, aimed at ensuring equitable and demand-based distribution of teachers to protect academic interest of students and optimise job satisfaction, is based on a set of parameters including age, gender and performance.

Female teachers who are either widow, divorcee, or separated will be given preference. Male teachers who are widower and have one or more minor children, and/or unmarried daughters, will also be given extra weightage.

The transfer policy also takes care of differently-abled teachers.

Title: 71-yr-old man killed in hit-and-run in Vesu
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Jagdish Bangdiwala

Surat: A 71-year-old man was knocked down dead by a speeding autorickshaw on a road which connects UM Road to VIP Road in Vesu. The man was standing on roadside with his scooter when he was hit by the autorickshaw on Monday night. The autorickshaw driver fled after the accident.

Jagdish Bangdiwala, a resident of Vesu, had gone to mass diskha event along with his wife. Bangdiwala was admitted to a private hospital where he died on Tuesday. “His scooter was parked in the parking lot and it was brought out by a security guard. He was rammed by the autorickshaw even before he could start his scooter. He suffered head injury and heavy blood loss,” a family member said. Doctors at the private hospital stopped his bleeding and further examinations were planned once his condition became stable.

“Meanwhile, his heart stopped functioning after a few hours. We were told that on regaining consciousness he might have suffered a heart attack due to shock,” the family member added. An offence of hit-and-run was lodged by family members. Police have begun investigation and trying to identify the autorickshaw driver.

Title: BJP tweets offering razor to Omar, deletes it after outcry
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

New Delhi: BJP Tamil Nadu stirred an online controversy on Tuesday after it posted a tweet from its verified handle stating the party had sent a razor set to former Jammu and Kashmir chief minister Omar Abdullah . The tweet was deleted after online outrage . The post came after an image of Abdullah with a grizzled beard went viral online on January 25, when 2G internet services were restored partially in the Union territory, only to be snapped again.

On Tuesday, BJP’s TN unit tweeted, “Dear Omar Abdullah. It is very disheartening to see you like this while your corrupt friends are enjoying life outside. Kindly accept our sincere contribution, in case of any assistance, feel free to contact ur (sic) counterpart (Congress) for further help in this regard.”

The tweet was accompanied by a screenshot of the delivery receipt of e-commerce website Amazon addressed to Omar’s residence. The parcel contained a razor set. The tweet was criticised by several users, including journalists, as insensitive, following which it was deleted.

BJP state IT wing president R Nirmal Kumar is the admin of the party’s official twitter handle @BJP4TamilNadu that has around two lakh followers. Recently, he posted a tweet with a picture of saint-poet Thiruvalluvar in saffron robe, stoking a controversy. He also posted tweets related to the panchami land issue involving DMK mouthpiece, Murasoli office, and a few other controversial tweets targeting DMK chief M K Stalin.

Title: Budaun: Death of 63 sheep in one night a mystery
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Villagers alleged that a wild animal had killed them

BAREILLY: A shepherd received a shock of his life when he found 63 of his 125 sheep dead in Budaun’s Malpur Tatera village under Jarifnagar police station on Tuesday morning. All the 63 sheep had died over the night under mysterious condition. While villagers alleged that a wild animal had killed them, not a single injury mark was found on any sheep.

A team of forest department personnel who reached the spot, denied the presence of any wild animal as they not find any pugmark. The carcasses of the sheep have been sent for postmortem to ascertain cause of death.

According to police, Ganga Sahai and Satish of Sambhal’s Kashipur village had been grazing their sheep at Malpur Tatera village in Budaun for the past six months. They had kept 125 sheep in a hut there. On Tuesday morning, they found 63 dead sheep. Locals alleged that a wild animals came to Malpur Tatera village and killed the sheep.

On receiving information, a team of forest department reached the spot. Divisional forest officer, Budaun, Rajesh Kumar said, “Our team inspected the site and also searched the area. However, we did not find any pugmarks of a wild animal here. No injured sheep was found. We do not know the cause of death and are awaiting the postmortem report.”

Title: Labourers from Bihar to be trained in soft skills
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Panaji: The Goa chapter of the Bihar Foundation, which was launched by Bihar industries minister Shyam Rajak on Tuesday, will help impart training in soft skills to migrant Bihari labourers working in Goa.

Stating that 25% of all migrant workers in Goa are Biharis, Rajak said the objective of the Bihar Foundation is to bring migrant Biharis together and to help them better integrate with their place of migration. The foundation’s Goa chapter is the 21st in the world and the ninth in India.

Sarfaraj Alam, who will head the chapter, said the foundation will focus on training migrant Bihari labourers in soft skills.

“In many cases, labourers coming from Bihar do not know how to dress or behave. Many times, this leads to irritation against them in their place of migration. We want to train them in soft skills, etiquette, how to dress and how to behave,” Alam, who is a hotelier, said. He also said the foundation will work to improve the image of Bihar in the minds of people everywhere.

Rajak said the infrastructure in Bihar had improved tremendously in recent years and that Biharis are talented workers who work for the prosperity of their place of settlement. He also said Bihar has a culture of migration, which is where the idea of a Bihar Foundation was born. “We want to promote among them a sense of service and dedication towards their place of migration,” the minister added.

“Trade is also promoted through the Bihar Foundation and Bihar-origin investors living in different parts of the world will be able to explore investment opportunities in Goa,” Alam said.

Rajak, who is on a two-day visit to Goa, said he would interact with industry representatives and discuss the possibility of trade between Goa and Bihar. The minister also inaugurated an exhibition of seven stalls showcasing handicrafts from Bihar.

The minister said in present times, when climate change is high on people’s minds, there is a lot to learn from Goa. “Goa is still green despite a flourishing tourism industry here. We have a lot to learn from Goans about environment protection,” he said.

Title: Creating glass art from garbage landfills
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Palakkad: Glass has been a major attraction for people from time immemorial and Egyptians were the first to use glass containers in 5 BC.

Though many substitutes for glass were introduced, particularly plastic materials, glass continues to fascinate people.

A designer and builder of four decades , V P Chandran of Palakkad was trying to make valuable glass products from waste bottles, particularly the littered liquor bottles which became a big environment menace on the streets.

He had set up a workshop in his Scholar Design Centre and started research on developing various products from waste glass and after more than a year of tireless work he succeeded in developing many attractively designed items.

“Glass recycling is the processing of waste glass into usable products. To be recycled, glass waste needs to be purified and cleaned. Then depending on the end use, the local processing capabilities, might also have to be separated into different colours. Glass is ideal for recycling since none of the materials are degraded by normal use”, he said.

“During the thought process of utilizing the waste I decided to concentrate first on the used glass bottles which were found littered in garbage landfills and water bodies. A large amount of such used glass bottles was kept in various hotels, bars and clubs as the management had no idea of its effective disposal”, Chandran said.

His first step was collecting such glass bottles and segregating it manually.

Then they were cleaned and decontaminated and crushed into pellets.

These pellets were effectively used to manufacture various products like art pieces, furniture, wall decorative, tiles, partition materials etc.

He said that in the process the main bottleneck was to find a medium to effectively bind these glass pellets to derive the required compression strength and solidification properties.

After lot of research on the invention of glass and its development process he could arrive at a medium which had the best binding properties for glass pellets.

After finding the right medium, he had to do various trials, combinations and ratios to arrive at the best by-product in a cost-effective manner.

He used wooden planks and pieces which was a waste by-product after carpentry, combined them with the pellets, turned them into various furniture like stools, dining tables, wall panels etc.

Chandran said that he is now “trying to develop suitable machines to mechanize the process and get a patent for these process and products to make value-added products from polluting glass waste.”

Title: Joshi asks officials to make good use of Union govt’s projects
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Hubballi: Union minister Pralhad Joshi urged district minister Jagadish Shettar to convene a meeting of officials of different departments to make good use of projects sanctioned by the Union government in the recent years.

Pointing out lapses of the state government officials, he said there is a need to train them on how to issue building permission and expand infrastructure utilizing grants of the state and central governments.

“For instance, when the Union government came forward to construct outer ring road from Navalgund Road-Gadag Road-PB Road-Kalghatgi Road, state engineers prepared a blue print in which the proposed road was shown dividing Hubballi south station. When this proposal reached Delhi, an official checked on Google and found that there is a station through which the bypass passes. He returned the proposal to state officials. The irony is that officials took over two years to rectify this error. If this is the functioning style of the state officials, Hubballi-Dharwad will lose many facilities,” he rued.

Addressing the gathering at the inaugural ceremony of ROB on Tuesday, Joshi, mentioning low quality work of the railway under bridge at Desai Circle, said the slab is already destroyed. “How did the HDMC officials issue building permission for an apartment at 2-3 gunta site at Bhavani Nagar? While constructing this ROB also, they had forgotten to connect it to Circuit House” he said.

He said the Union government is investing Rs 100 lakh crore in infrastructure sector in the coming five years. “Out of this, Rs 50 lakh crore will be invested in railway infrastructure like electrification and line doubling. If trains are electrified, we can save on oil import. We are also planning to increase solar energy production from 125 gigawatts to 400 gigawatts. As a result, price of electricity will come down. Rate of road construction, which was 3kms per day, is now increased to 8kms per day and we aim to make it 10kms per day,” he added.

Title: Civic body orders survey of commercial high-rise buildings for fire safety
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

The survey has been ordered after a massive fire broke out at Raghuvir Celeum Textile Market on January 21

Surat: High-rise commercial buildings in the Diamond City have come under the scanner of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) after a massive fire destroyed Raghuvir Celeum Textile Market completely. The fire at Raghuvir Celeum Textile Market on Puna-Kumbhariya Road in the wee hours of January 21 gutted more than 600 shops and caused losses to the tune of over Rs200 crore. The civic body’s urban development and town planning department has ordered survey of commercial buildings for checking fire safety measures.

Official sources said the survey, which started on Tuesday, will cover more than 1,000 commercial high-rise buildings. Fire officials will be checking outer elevation at the buildings, entry and exit, parking facilities, entry gates and fire safety norms, including fire hydrant system etc.

Municipal commissioner Banchhanidhi Pani told TOI, “A detailed survey of high-rise buildings have been ordered to check their fire safety measures. We don’t want to take any chances of big fires in the city after the massive fire at Raghuvir Celeum Textile Market. The survey will be completed within 30 days. Special focus will be on outer elevation in commercial buildings. After the detailed report by the fire department, we will be taking necessary action against commercial buildings regarding changes in outer elevation and enforcing fire safety norms.”

Chief fire officer Basant Pareek said, “Along with mock drills in the textile markets for fire safety, we have kick-started a massive survey of commercial high-rise buildings. There are over 1,000 commercial high-rise buildings in the city and all will be covered within 30 days.

Title: UDF to form human map in Thiruvananthapuram on Thursday
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Congress working committee member AK Antony

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The UDF has planned to organise a human map in the state capital to protest against Citizenship (Amendment) Act on Thursday.

UDF workers from across the state will assemble at Putharikandam Maidan for the protest. Congress working committee member AK Antony will inaugurate the protest which will be attended by senior party leaders.

KPCC president Muallappally Ramachandran said the protest was being organised against BJP’s attempt to communally divide the country in the name of CAA. “Congress has been in the forefront of the agitation against the CAA in the country and all the opposition parties are rallying behind the party for the agitation against the BJP government at the Centre,” he added.

Title: Armyman on leave killed while cleaning pistol in Shahjahanpur
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

BAREILLY: An Army jawan who was on leave was killed while cleaning his licenced pistol at Simra Khera village in Jalalabad area in Shahjahanpur district on Tuesday morning. His family has claimed that he accidentally shot himself in the head. Police suspect he committed suicide.

The deceased, Vipin Pathak , was deployed in Bengaluru and was on a 28-day leave since January 17. He was rushed to hospital where doctors pronounced him dead.
