The minister sounded hopeful that the broad gauge project will prove to be a boon as it will offer better transport facilities to the people. This will boost economic activities benefiting the residents even in remote parts. Once economic activities pick up, the prevailing frustration among youths living under the shadow of Maoist terror will also be a thing of the past, he said.

Union minister of road transport & highways Nitin Gadkari said MahaMetro’s broad gauge would offer faster connectivity to mofussil towns like Narkhed to Bhandara, Gondia to Chandrapur, Ramtek to Bhandara and Saoner to Wadsa in Gadchiroli. “Metro trains on the broad gauge would run faster and would also be cheaper as the cost of running it is lesser,” he said.

State government under former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis had already initiated steps in this direction and it needs a decisive push now for the broad gauge to become a reality soon, said Gadkari.

State home minister Anil Deshmukh too highlighted the efficacy of taking the MahaMetro’s broad gauge to places like Saoner, Bhiwapur, Nagbhid and so on as it will help develop smaller towns in the region.

Title: Patient’s attendants assault guard at GMCH, arrested
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Chandigarh: Police on Tuesday arrested a woman and her father for allegedly thrashing a 52-year-old security guard at Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH), Sector 32.

Radha Rani, a resident of Ram Darbar, said she was deputed at the gynaecology ward around 10am. She said senior doctors were on a round and all attendants were stopped outside till the doctors checked the patients. In the meantime, a woman identified as Jaspreet Kaur and her father Sher Singh, both residents of Phase VII, Mohali, tried to enter the ward to give food to a woman patient. Radha stopped her. However, the woman and her father allegedly started arguing with her. When Radha refused them entry, the woman and her father allegedly hit her. Other guards rushed to the spot, rescued her and caught hold of the two. The two were arrested and later released on bail.

On August 29, 2019, an attendant of a patient had lost her cool when she was told to sit outside a ward in GMCH. The woman allegedly attacked a woman security guard and manhandled a woman cop as well.

Title: Make the Nilgiris litter-free, sings the collector
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Udhagamandalam: To create greater awareness among local residents and tourists about littering in public places in the Nilgiris, the Nilgiris administration has produced an audio-visual clipping for circulation. The song accompanying the 3-minute visual has been sung by collector J Innocent Divya and P Babu, project director, Tamil Nadu State Rural Livelihood Mission. It was released on Sunday.

“The audio-visual is part of our ‘Clean Nilgiris’ programme. Even at the first meeting of the representatives of the local body held recently, the focus was mainly on cleanliness of our surroundings,” said Divya, perhaps the first collector to render her voice for a song on awareness.

“It was a wonderful experience to sing a song on a concept which the Nilgiris is focusing on,” said Divya, who has learnt Carnatic music during her school days.

According to Divya, the audio was recorded in an hour at her camp office after her office hours. “The quality of the video will be enhanced further by incorporating more of nativity and involving local communities,” she said.

This is the first time an audio-visual product on littering has been developed by the administration, Babu said. “Since the past three months we have been planning this project. We thought if the collector renders her voice the reach will be more.”

He said the song was inspired by the Hindi number, ‘Pekho math’ awareness based song on littering.

Babu, who has penned the Tamil lyrics for the song, said the tune was taken from the Hindi song.

Interestingly, the music for the Hindi song ‘Pekho math’ was inspired by the Michael Jackson number ‘Beat it’.

“Besides posting it on social media, we are planning to screen it in theatres in Ooty and Wellington,” said Babu.

On March 8, 2019, a VCD was released by the Nilgiris administration on the Nilgiris titled, ‘I love Nilgiris’.

Littering is prohibited in the Nilgiris and it would attract a fine of Rs1,000.

On the highways road within the boundary of the Nilgiris district, dustbins are located every one kilometer to keep the forest areas litter-free.

Title: Houses of pvt money lenders raided
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Kolhapur: Initiating action against private money lenders in the district, the co-operative department on Tuesday raided houses of as many as 10 people from the Kotoli village in Panhala taluka for allegedly operating without valid licenses in the district.

Officials have seized blank stamp papers, registers and notebooks from the suspects along with some papers that can be used as evidences against them.

“We had received a complaint about private money lending business in the village with the money lenders charging exorbitant interest rates. Based on the complaint, we raided houses of 10 people on Tuesday,” said an official from the co-operative department.

“We appeal to people to come forward and lodge complaint with us if they come across such illegal activities in the district,” he said.

Title: 2 juveniles convert barren land into orchard
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Chandigarh: Two juveniles accused of heinous crimes have converted a barren land into an orchard in Sector 53, planting 150 fruit-bearing trees and nurturing them on their own.

Following the directions of a local court, the two — 15-year-old and 16-year-old — were attached with the UT forest department to undergo their punishment and reformation period of a year. The two were members of a gang that committed dacoities. The juveniles told TOI they had committed petty crimes and never knew they could gain confidence by working in the Sector 53 nursery.

“We have understood that we were in bad company. Now, in six months, we have created life here by nurturing and looking after trees, watering them, taking their care and watching them grow. Our efforts will help the environment and these trees will provide fruits to people. I have also got a part-time job enabling me to contribute financially to my family,” said one of the juveniles.

Abdul Qayum, deputy conservator forests, UT, said the department received directions from the court to make the two work in the field of environment and submit weekly report. “We were directed to reform them, give them tasks and teach them how to grow trees and flowers. The idea was to bring them into the mainstream and divert their minds of crime. We made them realise that being part of creativity is like serving mankind. They were given social work and they responded positively,” he said. The forest department provided them guidance, tools, space and saplings. They were asked to toil on their own on the barren land. Qayum said, “They have planted 150 various fruit bearing trees covering approximately 1,000 square meters of land converting. “When the boys came they were scared, could hardly speak and used to shiver, but now their body language has changed; they are confident,” he said.

The two boys had been serving their time under the supervision of Prabhunath Shahi at the nursery. Prabhunath said, “One of the juvenile is here for five months and the other for two. The first one has planted and nurtured 65 trees and the other planted 85 trees. They have shown a lot of improvement and positivity in their character. We motivated them daily and monitored their progress.” He said they have planted trees like amla, mango, guava, jamun, arjun, papaya, blackberry, desi mango and bel. They said that by doing this they have overcome their past life, he said.

Title: Women stand waist-deep in Krishna river seeking liquor ban in Karnataka
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Under the aegies of Madya Nisheda Andolan, women stand in Krishna river demanding liquor ban in Karnataka

BAGALKOT: Scores of women stood in waist to neck-deep cold water of Krishna river on the chilly morning of Tuesday at Kudala Sangama of Hungund taluk in Bagalkot, demanding a liquor ban in the state.

As part of the unique protest organised by Madhya Nished Andolan Karnataka , nearly 2,000 women from different walks of life congregated at Kudala Sangama and staged a protest, while 200 women took part in a “Jala-Satyagraha” holding placards and shouting slogans for over five hours.

The protest is part of the organisation’s week-long campaign seeking a ban on liquor in the state, spearheaded by women.

Speaking to TOI, campaign organiser Swarna Bhat said, “We have launched a week-long protest in Kudal Sangam which will continue till January 30.”

“More than 51 organisations are part of our campaign. Two months ago, chief minister BS Yediyurappa had assured that he will meet us to discuss our demands, but he has failed to act on it. We request the chief minister to meet our representatives immediately,” she said.

“Alcoholism has shattered the homes of these women, stolen childhoods, pushed the rural households into poverty. Government is turning a deaf ear to their demand and so, we have launched the campaign again...If the CM refuses to meet us again, we will intensify the campaign,” Bhat said.

“We want Karnataka to ban liquor in single phase, unlike Andhra Pradesh government’s plan to do it in phases,” she added.

The demand for total prohibition in the state is not new. Last year, the outfit had organised a padayatra from Chitradurga to Bengaluru demanding a ban on the sale of liquor in the state.

Title: Karnataka: Ramesh Jarkiholi asks BSY, BJP to hold to their promises on cabinet berths
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Ramesh Jarkiholi, Mahesh Kumatalli, Shrimant Patil and R Shankar, who quit the Congress and joined the BJP, of... Read More

BENGALURU: Ramesh Jarkiholi on Tuesday demanded that he and all the newly elected MLAs, who won the bypolls after defecting from the Congress and JD(S), be inducted into the cabinet — likely on January 31 — as promised by chief minister BS Yediyurappa.

"We are hoping all 11 MLAs will be made ministers," Jarkiholi said. "That is what the BJP and the CM promised us and we hope they will keep their promise." This is the first time Jarkiholi has spoken in public on cabinet berths, ever since reports surfaced of the party high command not being in favour of inducting all the turncoats into the council of ministers.

Jarkiholi also said fellow rebel AH Vishwanath should be given a ministerial berth.

Vishwanath, formerly of the JD(S), had lost the bypolls. Jarkiholi said the rebellion would not have succeeded had it not been for Vishwanath.

"Those of us who rebelled against the JD(S)-Congress coalition government got a shot in the arm when Vishwanath supported us," Jarkiholi said. "It is imperative that we support him," he said, even as he sought to distance himself from comments made by newly-elected MLAs ST Somashekar and D Sudhakar, who said Vishwanath cannot demand a ministerial post.

Meanwhile, the BJP issued another deadline — January 31 — to expand the cabinet. "In all likelihood, cabinet expansion will take place on Friday," said an aspirant for a berth. But several BJP functionaries are skeptical of meeting the new deadline.

"Till now, the CM has not been given the green signal by the high command. This is all I can say," said a senior minister in Yediyurappa’s cabinet, while insisting he wouldn’t be surprised if the exercise was postponed till the Delhi elections are over.

Former minister and independent R Shankar, who along with Mahesh Kumatalli and Shrimant Patil accompanied Jarkiholi to a trip to Nanjangud, Mysuru district, has upped the pressure on Yediyurappa to field him in the bypoll to the lone vacant council seat. "I am confident the CM and the BJP will honour promises made to me," Shankar said.

The former minister had joined the BJP during the rebellion, but was not given a ticket to contest the bypolls.

In Chikkamagaluru, deputy chief minister Govind M Karjol insisted he is prepared to step down if needed to enable new entrants into the cabinet. "I’m a disciplined solider of the party. If the BJP directs me to submit my resignation, I will do so and return my official car and take a bus to Bengaluru," Karjol said. He said anyone who doesn’t respect the party line will not grow. "It is imperative to toe the party line," he said.

Title: Bank employee accused of siphoning off Rs 1 crore from 1k accounts
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Roorkee: The employee of a nationalized bank in Laksar sub-division of Haridwar has been accused of siphoning off around Rs 1 crore from 1,000 accounts. The incident came to light when some account holders found a part of their savings missing and alerted the bank management. Police as of now has ordered the bank to conduct an internal inquiry into the alleged embezzlement.

According to sources, some account holders reached the Niranjanpur branch of Punjab National Bank (PNB) on Friday to withdraw cash and found that money was missing from their accounts. Angry customers gheraoed bank employees and reported the matter to police. An internal inquiry by bank officials revealed the role of a certain employee, who allegedly used the bank manager’s user ID and password to access several user accounts and transfer money from them to other accounts (other than his). Of the 1,500 accounts presently operational at the bank, money was found to have been illegally withdrawn from 1,000.

“We have started an internal inquiry into the matter. Prima facie, the role of a fourth class employee is suspected. We will prepare a report in the matter in two days,” said Narendra Singh, circle head of PNB.

Kashi Ram, one of the victims, said, “I was saving up for my daughter’s wedding in February. When I tried to withdraw money, I found that Rs 8.5 lakh missing from my bank account.”

Police are working with the local management of the bank and said that they will start to take action against the criminals once they received the bank’s internal investigation report. “We have asked the bank for some final details. We will take action against all the fraudsters, irrespective of the number of people involved,” said Swapn Kishore Singh, superintendent of police (rural), Haridwar.

Title: Reckless ATM thieves used to practise safe sex to quench lust
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Nagpur: The local crime branch team of Nagpur rural police were a stunned lot after cops stumbled upon scores of condom packets at the dens of Rajasthan-based ATM breakers in Wadi and Wardha during searches after their arrest on January 26 following a prolonged chase.

The four ATM breakers, who were handed over to Katol police, have been remanded in custody till February 4.

Sources from the rural police said the four ATM breakers — Bahadur Bawari, Shreeniwas Bawari, Gopalram Bawari and Toofan Bawari — used to go back to Rajasthan with the stolen booty. They also transferred substantial sums of money into the accounts of their relatives. Though the accused acted tough during interrogation, the cops managed to extract crucial information.

According to a source, the cops had conducted searches at their dens, immediately after their arrest with the anticipation of seizing the stolen cash as they had repeatedly struck at ATMs in the last three months with 10 offences getting registered against them in Nagpur district, city and Wardha.

“We found several types and brands of condoms. The accused may have splurged cash in red-light areas too after striking it rich. We also cannot rule out women being brought to their dens as condoms were found in both locations,” he said.

It’s learnt that Bahadur and his gang used to communicate in ‘code language’ like flashing of the headlights during the operation. “The gang never used mobile phones while committing thefts as they were once caught with the help of the tower location while communicating. The mobile phones were kept at home before they went to rob money from ATMs,” said the source.

The gang also tried to mislead cops by refusing to acknowledge each other. They even gave fake names to give the impression that they belonged to different communities. “After intense and sustained interrogation, they broke down and spilled the beans, including an instance of bribing a witness to make him turn hostile in one of their cases,” said a personnel from the rural police.

The rural cops are now trying to nab the absconding member who brought the gang to Nagpur district by luring them with the promise of showing them several ATMs at desolate stretches and also providing them logistics support, including finding a place to stay.

The accused opened stolen ATM machines with the help of an electric cutter at their dens.

Title: Work stopped again at Patanjali plant
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Start-stop SYSTEM

Nagpur: Once again, work on the Patanjali Group’s food park plant in Mihan area has been put on hold. The plant coming up in an area of 230 acres was dubbed the world’s largest food processing campus. Patanjali had announced a plan to launch products made with Nagpur oranges also from the unit here. The project is coming up in the non-SEZ area of Mihan.

Earlier in 2019, work on installing the machinery at the plant had been stopped for over six months from February. At that time Patanjali Ayurved managing director Acharya Balkrishna had told TOI that the company was facing financial issues as it had taken up a number of project at a time. However, the work would be revived soon, he had said.

The work has come to a standstill again since more than two months, said sources. Attempts to get a response from Balkrishna did not succeed. A message seeking his comments on the recent developments went unanswered.

Sources said machines worth hundreds of crore are lying in the area but the installation work is not being done. The company has constructed around 13 sheds but the installation of machines remains to be done. Recently, there were some job cuts in the unit too, said sources.

In September 2016, when a stone laying ceremony was performed by yoga guru Ramdev Baba, he had announced the plant would start within six months. A cheque of Rs10 crore was also handed over to buy another 7 acres land in the SEZ area. The SEZ plan is slated to cater to the international market. Sources said no work has begun in the SEZ site till date.

The company is supposed to get the food processing unit operational within 16 months of allocation of the land, with rainy season excluded from the deadline, said a source.

The non-SEZ land was granted through an auction, which had, however, led to questions as Patanjali was the single bidder in the process.

There was speculation that the Maharashtra State Cooperative Bank (MSCB) may grant a loan of over Rs200 crore for the Nagpur project. Later, the company was also in talks with a consortium of public sector banks to finance the project. A team of bankers had come down to Nagpur for an inspection too, said a source.

In 2017, Patanjali Group had stopped payment for a cheque of over Rs60 crore for acquiring land at Mihan, due to issues with Maharashtra Airport Development Company (MADC). The funds were later released.

Title: Chandigarh: Man held for duping bank of Rs 4.8 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: The cyber cell of the UT police has arrested a 32-year-old man for allegedly duping PNB of Rs. 4.80 lakh.

The accused, Tabrik Hussain Sheikh of Mumbai, sent a message to a bank clerk claiming to be Karan Hoon, director of an auto company. The accused asked about the rate of interest on fixed deposit of Rs 10 crore for five years. Later, Anurag received a phone call from the same number that he wanted to remit Rs 9.90 lakh through RTGS from his account but, he is out of station and is sending the number through WhatsApp.

After that Bank received a communication from the company informing that they have not given direction for remittance of alleged amount from their account. The PNB officials then realised the fraud and managed to hold Rs 5.10 lakh. The accused succeeded in withdrawing Rs 4.80 lakh.

Title: Karnataka: Ramesh Jarkiholi asks BSY, BJP to hold to their promises on cabinet berths
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Ramesh Jarkiholi, Mahesh Kumatalli, Shrimant Patil and R Shankar, who quit the Congress and joined the BJP, of... Read More

BENGALURU: Ramesh Jarkiholi on Tuesday demanded that he and all the newly elected MLAs, who won the bypolls after defecting from the Congress and JD(S), be inducted into the cabinet — likely on January 31 — as promised by chief minister BS Yediyurappa.

"We are hoping all 11 MLAs will be made ministers," Jarkiholi said. "That is what the BJP and the CM promised us and we hope they will keep their promise." This is the first time Jarkiholi has spoken in public on cabinet berths, ever since reports surfaced of the party high command not being in favour of inducting all the turncoats into the council of ministers.

Jarkiholi also said fellow rebel AH Vishwanath should be given a ministerial berth.

Vishwanath, formerly of the JD(S), had lost the bypolls. Jarkiholi said the rebellion would not have succeeded had it not been for Vishwanath.

"Those of us who rebelled against the JD(S)-Congress coalition government got a shot in the arm when Vishwanath supported us," Jarkiholi said. "It is imperative that we support him," he said, even as he sought to distance himself from comments made by newly-elected MLAs ST Somashekar and D Sudhakar, who said Vishwanath cannot demand a ministerial post.

Meanwhile, the BJP issued another deadline — January 31 — to expand the cabinet. "In all likelihood, cabinet expansion will take place on Friday," said an aspirant for a berth. But several BJP functionaries are skeptical of meeting the new deadline.

"Till now, the CM has not been given the green signal by the high command. This is all I can say," said a senior minister in Yediyurappa’s cabinet, while insisting he wouldn’t be surprised if the exercise was postponed till the Delhi elections are over.

Former minister and independent R Shankar, who along with Mahesh Kumatalli and Shrimant Patil accompanied Jarkiholi to a trip to Nanjangud, Mysuru district, has upped the pressure on Yediyurappa to field him in the bypoll to the lone vacant council seat. "I am confident the CM and the BJP will honour promises made to me," Shankar said.

The former minister had joined the BJP during the rebellion, but was not given a ticket to contest the bypolls.

In Chikkamagaluru, deputy chief minister Govind M Karjol insisted he is prepared to step down if needed to enable new entrants into the cabinet. "I’m a disciplined solider of the party. If the BJP directs me to submit my resignation, I will do so and return my official car and take a bus to Bengaluru," Karjol said. He said anyone who doesn’t respect the party line will not grow. "It is imperative to toe the party line," he said.

Title: Sugarcane crushing issue: Dist collector convenes meeting of millers
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Kolhapur: District collector Daulat Desai has convened a meeting of sugar mill owners on Wednesday to discuss the issue of delay in crushing of damaged sugar cane .

The millers have shown least interest in crushing the damaged crop despite several instructions from the collector in this regard. Farmers had earlier threatened to launch an agitation if the millers fail to crush cane and clear the land for taking up the next crop for cultivation during the rabi season.

When the crushing season began in Kolhapur district, it was decided that the millers would first complete the crushing of damaged canes. But, the millers did not pay any attention to the damaged cane for cutting and crushing. Enraged with this a delegation led by veteran leader ND Patil met Desai and asked him to take immediate steps in this regard.

Desai had warned of strict action against mills that fail to finish damaged cane crushing by January 15. Now, a special meeting has been called to discuss the issue.

According to sources, sugar cane grown over 1,97,946 hectare area in the district was damaged due to heavy rainfall and floods last year. The most damaged area was Shirol taluka. The farmers had demanded to cut cane from their fields and clear the fields so that they could take up rabi crops for survival.

Last week, a delegation led by Swabhimani Shetkari Sanghatana (SSS) state president Jalinder Patil held a meeting with Desai. During the meeting, Patil said that the sugar factories were not cutting the damaged cane despite his instructions to them in this regard.

Following the meeting, Desai then contacted the sugar commissonrate officials who said that a meeting in this regard will soon be conducted in the coming days.

Patil threatened that if the sugar mills fail to act on the collector's directives, the farmers will launch an agitation and shut down the mills until the damaged cane is cut and removed from the fields.

Title: Culling memories revive with NGO’s bid for Sukhna ducks
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Chandigarh: The isolated island in front of the Lake Club is a tragic reminder of that ghoulish, misty midnight of December 18 and 19, 2014, when more than a 100 domesticated geese or ducks were slaughtered at that spot to contain the dreaded avian flu, H5N1.

The killers were the workers of the health and forest department wearing puffed-up protective clothes and special masks.

The birds’ necks were dislocated, some were clubbed to death while others had their necks sliced in the midnight massacre.

Sukhna Lake was disinfected and closed to human activity for a month after that. But chilling memories has not stopped a section of local NGOs from lobbying hard with the UT administration to reintroduce domesticated geese or ducks at Sukhna Lake and thus again raise the spectre of risks to public and ecological health.

The H5N1 strain of avian flu is contagious to humans. The UT administration banned the reintroduction of domesticated birds in the Sukhna after the 2014 episode. But on a recent request by the NGO, Organic Sharing, seeking to release domesticated ducks once again, UT advisor Manoj Parida forwarded a plea to the concerned forests and wildlife department. Clarifying that no permission had been granted, the chief wildlife warden, Debendra Dalai, told TOI, “The matter is under examination.”

Rahul Mahajan, who runs the NGO, Organic Sharing, transplants trees that are downed, and is the owner of the popular chain of outlets, Durga Seeds, admitted to TOI that his “proposal was under the administration’s consideration”.

When informed of the risks to public health posed by his reintroduction scheme, Mahajan said he was “not aware”, but told TOI, “If such risks are there, we are ready to go in for other options such as keeping the birds in an enclosure away from the Sukhna waters, but still close by so that tourists can enjoy their presence. We would keep in mind all the health risks voiced by experts before going in for our reintroduction programme.”

Dr D D Kulkarni, former director and principal scientist, NIHSAD, and one who led the investigations and tests into avian flu at the national level for 3.5 years, told TOI, “It is risky to introduce domesticated geese or ducks into a wetland where migratory birds are regular visitors. After the turkey, it is domesticated geese and ducks which are most susceptible to avian flu. Migratory birds are routine carriers of flu viruses. But not all such migratory birds die or get sick from this virus and remain silent reservoirs. Nor is it that all migratory birds are virus carriers. One of the principal ways in which the virus is passed to other birds such as domesticated ducks are through faeces or discharges from the migratory birds. There is a possibility also of the avian flu virus spreading in the waters.”

Title: Docs remove bone stuck in man’s food pipe for 25 days
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Nagpur: On some occasions, pieces of bones in non-vegetarian food get stuck inside throat or food pipes. In such cases, the bones must be removed with the help of endoscope. Imagine the unbearable pain which people go through.

But a 60-year-old patient from Nagpur was living with a 1.25-inch piece of bone in the middle of his food pipe for nearly 25 days. He got relief from pain and was saved from life-threatening complications on Tuesday at Super Specialty Hospital (SSH).

“Eknath Sahare, a driver by profession, came to SSH on Tuesday complaining of severe pain in his throat. It had become difficult for him to swallow food or water,” said senior gastroenterologist Dr Sudhir Gupta. A team of doctors led by Dr Gupta later performed the endoscopy and removed the bone.

“We were surprised to know that Sahare was suffering from this pain since January 3. The patient is from a poor family and was thinking that the surgery would be very costly. Fortunately, at SSH, the surgery was performed for free,” said Dr Gupta.

One of the relatives of the patient said that he was trying household remedies for many days since January 3 and visited the doctor last week only. The doctor told him that he needs a surgery. But, the patient waited for one more week presuming that it would be a costly affair. Finally, he visited SSH where surgeries are performed for free on poor patients.

Dr Gupta said that the patient was lucky as the bone might have caused a tear in the wall of food pipe, which is life-threatening. Removing foreign body from the oesophagus with the help of endoscope is not rare, but this bone was stuck deep inside and left two deep ulsers at the site of impact.

Doctors have decided to keep the patient under observation for at least 48 hours. His condition is reported to be stable and improving. Gastroenterologists Dr Harit Kothari, Dr Vinita Gupta, Dr Sahil Parmar, and anasthetist Dr Ketaki Ramteke were in the surgery team.

Relief at last

The man was suffering from severe pain and had difficulty in swallowing since Jan 3

It took two weeks for him to see a private practitioner

Doctor told him about a bone stuck in his food pipe and surgery is must to get rid of it

Due to poor financial condition, the patient was not able to undergo surgery in a private set-up

He reported at Super Specialty Hospital (SSH) on Jan 28

Here, surgery was performed for free and the bone was removed from his food pipe

Title: 2 Zirakpur municipal employees suspended
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Mohali: The department of local bodies, Punjab, has issued suspension orders of executive officer of the municipal council (MC), Zirakpur, and executive officer of the nagar panchayat, Zirakpur.

The orders have been issued by Sanjay Kumar, additional chief secretary of the local bodies department, Punjab, on Tuesday.

Sukhjinder Singh Sidhu, executive officer of the municipal council, Zirakpur, and Girish Verma, executive officer of nagar panchayat, Zirakpur, have been directed to be present at the local bodies department Punjab daily at its Sector 35 office, Chandigarh. Four more employees of the municipal council and nagar panchayat have also been issued show-cause notices.

They have been asked to hand over their charge with immediate effect to their predecessors and relieve from duty. While serving the suspension period, they will get half their salary in the form of day to day expenses.

Action came after the officers were found negligent in checking and ignoring violations made by a Dhakoli-based builder and promotor, which caused loses to the government exchequer, said sources in the local bodies department.

Director of the local bodies department, Bhupinder Pal Singh, said, “Two officers have been suspended with immediate effect. Further action will be taken once enquiry is completed.”

Sources in local bodies department said their role had been found dubious and suspicious favoring the builder to carry out violations in the building construction and evading charges and taxes to be paid to the government.

Title: Public health official fined Rs 10,000
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Mohali: The commissioner of the Punjab State Information Commission during hearing found the executive engineer (Xen) of the public health, department of water supply and sanitation, negligent in providing information sought under the RTI.

The commission fined the executive engineer of Rs 10,000 to be deducted from his salary in parts. The complainant will also be paid Rs 3,000 as compensation by the department.

The executive engineer of the department of water supply and sanitation, Anil Kumar, is accused of delaying information sought under the RTI beyond 100 days. The information was sought by Surjit Kaur and KNS Sodhi, residents of Sector 70, Mohali.

They had sought information about tube-wells installed in the area of municipal corporation, Mohali, besides some allied information.

After hearing the arguments supported by the documentary evidences from the two parties, Yashvir Mahajan, state information commissioner, noted that needless delay had been taken by the executive engineer in providing information. The deemed PIO in the office of Xen, department of water supply and sanitation, was duly informed by the PIO in the municipal corporation.

However, he dealt with the application lackadaisically, read the orders.

It has taken almost relentless pursuit of a year by the appellant to procure information. The commission observed that the deemed PIO in the office of Xen, department of water supply and sanitation, has failed to meet his obligation under Section 7 (1) of the RTI Act and thus, has rendered himself for an imposition of penalty.

He has not come up with a satisfactory response to the show-cause notice. Therefore, exercising its authority under Section 20 (1) of the RTI Act, the commission imposed a penalty of Rs 10,000 in lump sum on Anil Kumar, department of water supply and sanitation, Mohali.

The officer is directed to deposit the amount of penalty in the government treasury in two equal installments from his salary from the month of January, 2020. As the appellant has been put to undue inconvenience and harassment, he is awarded a compensation of Rs 3,000 which shall be paid to him through a bank draft by the public authority from its own account.

Title: Punjabi University to invite fresh tenders for canteens
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Punjabi University

PATIALA: A week after student bodies’ staged a protest against the authorities of Punjabi University for overlooking canteens allegedly being run without permission, the university authorities on Tuesday agreed to invigte fresh tenders of canteens and shops, owners of which had not paid rent since June 2018.

The authorities of the university have also formed a committee comprising senior medical officer of a government hospital, faculty members and students that can conduct inspections to check the quality of food in the canteens.

There are eight canteens that are operating on the premises of the university. The student bodies’ alleged that among these, four canteens had not paid rent since June 2018 as they filed litigation in the court against the university authorities against the university’s decision on hike in 30 per cent rent.

Besides canteens, the university authorities have also decided to get e-tendering of four shops that too were operational without any formal tendering after a case was filed against the university.

“It is a matter of fact that contractors of all eight canteen owners had separately filed a case in the court to challenge the decision of the university authorities on hike in rent and get fresh tendering. However, the court declared in one case that the university was authorised to take fresh tenders and a person having a contract from last 40 years does not provide them with any possession or right to continue running the canteen. Four of eight canteens landed in a compromise with the university authorities and managed to get five years contract. This happened for the first time that contractors got five years contract against the convention of three years. Now, the contractors of the remaining four canteens are still fighting the case in the court against the university’s decision. The university has not demanded rent from these four canteen owners so far, whereas, there are no restrictions or decision on this matter by the court,” said Harvinder Singh, former SYFI president, who raised the matter in May 2018 demanding e-tendering of canteens and shops.

He said the university authorities after meeting on Tuesday agreed to conduct invite tenders for four canteens and shops that had not paid rent since June 2018.

Title: Draw of lots postponed as only 62 vendors turn up
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Panchkula: An emergency town vending committee meeting will be called by the Panchkula municipal corporation in the next three days after out of 162 vendors only 62 vendors turned up for the first draw of lot which was held on Tuesday by the authorities concerned.

MC commissioner-cum-administrator Sumedha Kataria said they had postponed the draw of lots which they had planned to organise on Tuesday after officials found that only 62 vendors turned up instead of 162 for the Sector 19 vending sites.

She said the town vending committee would hold a meeting to decide on how the draw for lots would be held. She said the 62 vendors who turned up, belonged to different area and she would table before the committee that if the corporation could accommodate them at the Sector 19 vending site. She said all those vendors whose documents were verified would get the site when the draw of lots would be conducted.

Officials said during the verification they found that there were vendors who were not setting up shops in Sector 19 but applied for the site in this area.

Officials also proposed that the corporation should ask the company to issue identity cards to vendors whose names were mentioned in the survey list.

They said it would be unfair on the part of the corporation to allocate vending sites as all were not present during the draw of lots. It is mentioned that residents raised objection on the name of vendors in the survey of Sector 19 and demanded to re-conduct it.

The street vending market would be constructed on one-acreland and around 458 stalls would be allocated. The MC has been given space for vending zones in Sectors 2, 4, 10, 11, 12, 15 and 19 by the HSVP.

Title: Actor Jameela Malik passes away in Thiruvananthapuram
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

File photo of actor Jameela Malik

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Veteran actor Jameela Malik passed away in Thiruvananthapuram on Tuesday. She was 73. She was living with her son at her residence in Palode . She came to the city on Monday to attend Beemapally Uroos festival and was staying at a relative's residence.

At night she complained of chest pain, following which she was first taken to a private hospital and then to the medical college, where she was declared dead on arrival. Her mortal remains were kept for public to pay homage at Bharat Bhavan. By evening her body was taken to her native place in Kollam for final rites.

Jameela was born as the eldest child of Thankamma Malik and Malik at Jonakapuram in Kollam. Her progressive mother’s persuasions bore fruit when she became the first woman from Kerala to graduate from the Film and Television Institute of India, Pune.

During the 70s, she worked in Tamil and Malayalam films, donned various roles and occasionally dubbed for movies. But her career never took off as a breakthrough role evaded her. She was also cast in several television serials.

She had worked as a dubbing artist in Hindi movies, she lent her voice to Manjula in ‘Mayoora’ and had dubbed for Jayamalini. She had acted with J Jayalalithaa in the film ‘Nadiye Thedi Vantha Kadal’. She did roles with top actors like Sharada, Chiranjeevi and Rajesh Khanna.

Her first movie (that was released) was K S Sethumadhavan’s ‘Adyathe Katha’. She got a significant role with the film ‘Ragging’ directed by NN Pisharody in which she acted along with a star cast comprising PJ Antony, Balan K Nair and Rani Chandra. She did a notable role of Devi teacher in the film ‘Pandavapuram’.

Title: Mundhe takes charge, NMC officials get 3 days to shape up
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

TIGHTENING THE SCREWS:

Nagpur: A week after being appointed, IAS officer Tukaram Mundhe, who is known for being transferred frequently, assumed charge as municipal commissioner at Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) on Tuesday morning. Immediately after taking charge, Mundhe gave three days ultimatum to NMC officials to ensure a positive change in the city, and also in their behaviour towards people.

An IAS officer of 2005 batch, Mundhe announced a ‘janata durbar’ on daily basis. He would meet people between 4pm and 5pm every day on all working days at his office in NMC headquarters, Civil Lines.

Outgoing municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar was not present when Mundhe assumed charge. Bangar had gone to Mumbai on Monday to attend a meeting organized by speaker Nana Patole.

During his 14-month tenure, Bangar never fixed any time table for meeting people, and allowed visitors whenever he was available at the office. Bangar is yet to get his new posting.

As soon as he stepped into the NMC head office premises, Mundhe reportedly expressed displeasure over parking system for vehicles in front of the new administrative building.

In the meetings organized with assistant commissioners and heads of all departments, Mundhe said, “We are service providers and should work in the larger interest of public. I want discipline and transparency in working. Roads didn’t look clean, so ensure proper work within three days,” he said.

On the first day itself, Mundhe raised question on existence of public works department (PWD) engineers in other departments like slum. He directed officials to submit list of project management consultants, financial break-up of NMC, and also asked for presentations from all departments.

Expressing frustration at ringing mobile of an official, Mundhe reportedly suggested keeping mobiles on silent mode during meetings. He reportedly asked his personal assistant to seize mobile handsets of officials and donate them to any organization if they ring during the meeting. “I believe in punctuality, so all should come on time or even 10 minutes before the meeting, but I will not tolerate anyone coming after commencement of the meeting,” he said.

Mundhe has been transferred 13 times in his 15-year career. His posting at NMC is the 14th transfer. This is his second posting in the city. In 2008, he worked as chief executive officer of the zilla parishad here.

Mundhe could not meet mayor Sandip Joshi on Monday since the latter reportedly did not come to NMC in the morning, and went out of the city after attending MahaMetro’s function in the afternoon.

People excited over Mundhe coming to NMC

Immediately after news of Tukaram Mundhe assuming charge was posted on NMC’s Facebook page, over 1,300 people liked the post and 236 commented on it. Probably, this is the highest response for a post by NMC, which receives very few likes and comments. Congratulating Mundhe, many people said they expect him to free NMC of corruption, solve various civic problems including encroachments, garbage dumps etc. A retired NMC official also requested Mundhe to curb corruption in NMC health department. Considering the comments, it seems people have high expectations from Mundhe.

Top Challenges Before Mundhe

* Curb corruption in various departments like water works, PWD, health, property tax etc

* Find new revenue sources and increase recovery of property tax, water bills

* Improve door-to-door garbage collection, transportation up to Bhandewadi dumping yard, and stop dumping of garbage on roadsides, open spaces

* Control unwanted expenditure by office bearers and corporators on welcome gates, statues, sports, cultural, social programmes, tours etc

* Improve quality of works in cement and tar roads, water supply, civil works

* Remove encroachments on footpaths, roads and curb unauthorized constructions

* Improve education quality in NMC schools

* Stop destruction of playgrounds and trees

* Improve complaints receiving and redressal system

* Improve city bus service

Title: 449 travellers penalized for ticketing offences by C Rly
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Nagpur: Central Railway’s commercial staffers have pulled up 449 travellers, either without tickets or irregular ones, collecting more than Rs1.4 lakh from them at a special drive conducted at various stations as well as on trains on January 24.

A 11-member ticket checking squad along with two Railway protection force (RPF) personnel conducted checks on Geetanjali Express, Mumbai-Kolkata LLT Shalimar Express, Maharashtra Express and Ahmedabad-Howrah Express during the special drive conducted under the supervision of Divisional railway manager Somesh Kumar and Senior divisional commercial manager Krishnath Patil.

Around 53 persons were found travelling without tickets. A fine amounting to Rs24,400 was also collected from ticketless travellers. Another Rs1.03 lakh in fine was collected from 269 travellers with irregular tickets.

The Central Railway authorities have appealed to monthly ticket holders to abstain from boarding reserved coaches. More special drives against ticketless travellers and irregular ticket holders will continue by the Central Railway.

Title: VHP aims to stop forced conversions by 2024: Sudhanshu Patnaik
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

ALLAHABAD: The central secretary of Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP) Sudhanshu Patnaik on Monday said that the organisation would increase its activities in 31 “conversion-prone” pockets falling under Kashi prant. VHP hopes to reach out to all people in these areas and end forced conversions by 2024, he said.

During the concluding meet of ‘dharm prasar vibhag’ at the ‘chintan shivir’ on VHP campus on Monday, Patnaik said, “The organisation would increase its activities in conversion-prone pockets so that Hindus are not trapped using greed. We would be engaging with saints, seers, storytellers and use the employment mode to reach out to people. We would have to focus on unity among Hindus and make sincere efforts to end evils like casteism and untouchability, prevailing in society.”

More than 100 office-bearers from eastern UP attended the workshop on the concluding day. They have been asked to reach every house in the identified pockets and connect with more and more people and tell them about Hinduism and Indian culture. On Monday, deputy CM Keshav Prasad Maurya also visited the VHP camp and viewed the VHP’s model for the proposed Ram temple.

Title: Wrap up Silda massacre case in a year: HC
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Kolkata: The Calcutta High Court on Tuesday asked a trial court to complete the Silda EFR camp massacre case in a year. In the February 2010 attack, 24 EFR jawans were gunned down by suspected Maoist guerrillas. The HC also asked the DGP to help the trial court expedite the proceedings.

The HC was hearing bail petitions by three accused in the Silda camp attack. The HC granted bail to Indrajit Karmakar, but turned down the pleas of the two others. The HC had sought a CID report before deciding on the bail plea. The CID report said that while witnesses identified the two accused, no witness was found to testify against Karmakar. The HC also asked the trial court to complete the trial within a year. tnn

Title: Digestive tract woes? Check gut flora for the root cause
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Pune: Bhashkar, a 42-year-old school teacher, began to lose focus and was constantly distracted. Often, he had to leave the classroom midway and rush to the washroom. The increased urge to pass stool with mucus discharge had put him in embarrassing situations. He was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome.

Bhashkar opted for a gut flora analysis and based on the report, he was put on pre and probiotic supplements for a few weeks, advised dietary changes and simple lifestyle modifications. Six weeks later, Bhashkar reported significant relief from the symptoms and in his overall health.

He was one of the 15 participants in the six-month study conducted by the city-based doctors since December 2018. Under the study, stool samples of the enrolled patients suffering from constipation, inflammatory bowel diseases, irritable bowel syndrome and ulcerative colitis were analysed.

“These samples were sent for gut microbiome analysis to the Bengaluru-based laboratory. The samples were further processed in the US as well,” consultant colorectal surgeon Ashwin Porwal, founder-head of Healing Hands Clinic, said.

Gut flora or microbiota are the micro-organisms that live in the digestive tracts of humans. The study also undertook an indepth analysis of the gut microbiome and the impact of pre and probiotics on the changes in the gut flora, and the resultant change in the symptoms of the patients. “The patients were also put on a Kiwi fruit extract regimen, a rich prebiotic, for a month. After the period, stool samples of all the patients were collected again and sent for gut microbiome analysis to study the changes,” Porwal said.

At the end, a comparative pre- and post-study data suggested that all the patients, except for one who was lost to follow-up, showed a significant improvement in symptoms associated with irritable bowel syndrome, ulcerative colitis and chronic constipation.

“I was amazed to see how my gut diversity score improved with dietary changes and supplements,” Bhashkar said.

Diversity score is the diversity index of gut, in which the mathematical measure of the gut flora is represented in numbers. “A higher number represents higher diversity and better gut health,” Porwal said.

While the gut microbiome test has a lot of potential, it has drawbacks as it is in its nascency. “The faecal-based testing does not provide microbiota information of the whole gut, but primarily of the large intestine only. Besides, the cost of the technology and hence the affordability at the present charges is another major limitation of the gut microbiome test,” physician Leena Dhole, one of the investigators of the study, said.

Title: ‘Nokku Vidya Paavakali is grandma’s life’
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Moozhikkal Pankajakshi (centre), flanked by daughter Radhamani (R) and granddaughter Ranjini, at the Kottayam ... Read More

KOTTAYAM: Moozhikkal Pankajakshi ’s biggest wish is to hand over her knowledge and skills in the fading art form ‘Nokku Vidya Paavakali ’ to the future generation. The 83-year-old artist, who was recently honoured with Padma Shri, was successful in finding a successor when her granddaughter Ranjini K S started showing keen interest in the art form.

The grandmother took it as a mission to impart the skills to Ranjini. “Nokku Vidya Paavakali is my grandmother’s life. So, I can’t leave this art form. I wish to carry on with it along with my education,” said Ranjini.

On Tuesday, Pankajakshi, daughter Radhamani and granddaughter Ranjini were at a function held to honour the Padma Shri awardee at the Press Club here. She hails from Monippally in the district.

Pankajakshi is the last surviving link with Nokku Vidya Paavakali, the centuries old traditional puppetry of Kerala. As a child, Pankajakshi wanted to go to school. But being the eldest of five siblings, her father wanted her to practise the traditional art form practised in the family. She started acquiring the skills of the art form at the age of 11. She took the art seriously after she got married and her husband Sivarama Panikkar joined her.

Ranjini started studying the art form at the age of 8. Ranjini says that it took five years to learn the art form. “High concentration and dedication is needed. Physical exertion in presenting the art form is another challenge,” said Ranjini, a BCom student in St Stephen’s College in Uzhavoor.

Title: Court of inquiry into scrap pilferage at Chennai depot
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Pune: The Army’s Southern Command has ordered a Court of Inquiry to investigate the alleged pilferage of 28 tonnes of scrap material from the Avadi Ordnance Depot (AOD) in Chennai.

The depot stores spares of Army vehicles, clothing items of recruits and tent-related items. It provides these material to the units based in the southern sector of the command. A junior commissioned officer (JCO) of the Army lodged an FIR with the Avadi Tank Factory police station on December 20 against a private contractor.

“It is intimated that the Court of Inquiry for the case is under progress. The time frame is related to availability of witnesses and cannot be specified exactly. Details of violation of procedures as per the standard operating procedure (SOP) will be ascertained after culmination of the Court of Inquiry. Further details of legal action against the contractor/agency may be ascertained from the police authorities,” a command officer said.

“A Brigadier rank officer has been appointed the presiding officer of the Court of Inquiry panel. He will be assisted by three officers. The panel is yet to submit its report,” an Army officer from the Southern Command told TOI on condition of anonymity. “The depot is headed by a Colonel rank officer, who is responsible for all kinds of administrative decisions, including the dispatch of scrap material,” he said.

“There is an SOP for uploading and dispatching of the material from the depot. No outside vehicle is allowed to leave the depot without going through a weigh in. As per the procedure, the weight of empty vehicle and after filling up of the scrap is recorded separately. If a vehicle is carrying extra weight beyond the actual order, it is expected to be caught within the depot. We are surprised how the vehicles involved in pilferage were permitted to leave the establishment,” added the officer.

On the other hand, the police authorities of Avadi range said such an illegal activity could not be done without the insiders’ help. “This racket must be going on for the past few years. It is possible that the contractor stole tonnes of scrap with the help of depot officials as well. It may not be the first time that the contractor has done it,” assistant commissioner of police V Satyamurti of the Avadi Range said.

“The Military Intelligence unit of the Southern Command came to know about this illegal practice first. Based on their specific inputs, we acted,” Satyamurti told TOI over the phone.

According to Satyamurti, this contractor had been buying scrap from the Avadi depot since 2014. “He is involved in this business for the past 15 years.” he said. The police have booked the contractor under sections 465 (punishment for forgery), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating) and 420 (cheating) of the IPC.

Title: Disease-resistant variant to boost tomato cultivation
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Panaji: A new disease-resistant tomato hybrid ‘Arka Rakshak’ is set to bring a smile to farmers’ faces. Developed by the Indian institute of horticulture research (IIHR) in a bid to achieve high yields and resist diseases like tomato leaf curl virus bacterial wilt and early blight, the variant’s seeds have already been distributed among farmers in North Goa.

“Tomato seedlings are often plagued with the problem of wilting, due to which farmers are reluctant to grow tomatoes . However, this particular variety developed by the IIHR is resistant to wilt,” said Dilip Paranjape, project director, Agriculture Technology Management Agency’s (ATMA), North Goa.

“It has not wilted after farmers grew it in Goa last year. It has proven a hardy variety, therefore,” he said.

Last year, there was a yield of 200kg of tomatoes from a patch measuring 25sqm— it showed that a single plant could produce 11kg of tomatoes. The overall production went up to a few tons.

“If we succeed in this, farmers can go for large-scale tomato cultivation and we can slowly discontinue importing them from other states,” Paranjape said.

ATMA-North Goa is planning to have a continuous year-round programme for self-help groups in Goa, beginning with the rainy season, upto the Rabi season. “We will start with the planting ginger and turmeric, followed by vegetable nurseries in the Rabi season,” he said.

“We are however focusing more on tomato and broccoli this year,” he added.

ATMA and Krishi Vijgyan Kendra (KVK) have sponsored shade-net houses for these self-help groups; some have also been given to them by Zuari Agro, under their CSR programme. These are for farms in Ela, Old Goa; Duler, Bardez; Kavalebaag, Pernem, Valpoi and Bicholim. It costs around Rs 5,000-6,000 to erect small nurseries of 25sqm. The seeds and materials like vermicompost and coco peat are given by ATMA.

While many farmers have already cultivated the seeds and the tomato seedlings are slowly coming up, broccoli is not popular in Goa yet.

“Not many farmers are aware that broccoli fetches a very good sum in the market. There is especially high demand in the markets of the coastal areas because tourists are aware of its nutritional value,” he said.

Title: Peyjal Nigam repairs damaged sewer lines
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Local residents have expressed their content with the development

Mussoorie: The damaged sewer lines that were polluting water sources of the town have been repaired by the Peyjal Nigam after TOI brought the issue to the fore in an article titled “Sewage from hotels, houses polluting water sources of Rajpur, Mussoorie”.

Speaking to TOI, Subhash Chandra, Executive Engineer of Peyjal Nigam, said that the sewer lines that were damaged at Gaddi Khana (near Gandhi Chowk) have been completely repaired by the department. “After this issue was brought to our notice, we took immediate action and now the lines have been repaired and leakage has stopped completely,” Chandra informed.

Local residents have expressed their content with the development. “We all had become concerned after getting to know about the possibility of sewerage contaminating the water supply of the town. The repair of leaking sewer pipes is a major relief. We thank TOI for raising this matter with the authorities,” said Ashish Goel, a resident of Gandhi Chowk.

Notably, TOI had come to know that just above the Bhilaru and Jincy water sources (which account for nearly half the water supply of the town), huge quantities of sewage, reportedly from the Library bazaar area of Mussoorie, was flowing down into the catchment of these water sources.

“It could have led to a major health hazard. The flowing sewage was like a huge stream flowing in the catchment of the springs and near the points where these springs were being tapped,” says Virender Bhandari, a resident of Bhilaru locality near Mussoorie.

It is worth mentioning that the entire town of Mussoorie derives its water supply through water pumped from more than 20 nearby springs. Bhilaru and Jincy are among the largest springs.

Title: Maharashtra deputy CM Ajit Pawar’s Pune metro plans may cost Rs 4,200 crore
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Ajit Pawar

PUNE: The proposed Shivajinagar-Kadamwak Wasti Metro extension and a fresh line from Swargate to Pulgate are likely to set PMRDA back by an additional Rs4,200 crore.

Pune Metropolitan Regional Development Authority (PMRDA) is developing the 23km Hinjewadi-Shivajinagar. Last week, deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar had proposed the extension and the new route at a meeting with PMRDA and told officials to study the plan and submit a report.

According to officials in the know, early assessment reports have suggested the entire line be elevated, as an underground line would further escalate the cost. The Delhi Metro Rail Corporation will prepare a detailed project report by next month

“The estimated cost of the Shivajinagar-Hadapsar elevated Metro line is Rs4,500 crore,” an official said, adding, “The extension and the new line would further increase the expenses by another Rs4,200 crore.” Each additional kilometre is expected to cost Rs300 crore.

Title: SECR takes the lead in cleanliness at 283 stations
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Nagpur: The South East Central Railway (SECR) has taken the lead in cleanliness at 283 stations which also includes mechanized cleaning at 36 stations.

SECR consists of Nagpur, Raipur and Bilaspur divisions. “We have been giving cleanliness at stations, colonies and aboard trains top priority. Apart from mechanized cleaning at 36 strategic stations like Bilaspur, Durg, Gondia, manual cleaning is being done at 115 stations,” said senior PRO Santosh Kumar.

“The SECR has topped the ranking in cleanliness across the Indian Railways in an independent survey conducted by the Quality Council of India (QCI) recently,” said Kumar.

All trains passing through Bilaspur and Raipur stations are cleaned by machines. Both these stations have fast watering facility, thereby reducing time to water trains. “Plans are afoot to start automatic coach washing units at Bilaspur and Durg stations,” he added.

Kumar said ‘Coach Mitra’ service has been introduced wherein passengers can send an SMS on 138 or 9821736069 for cleanliness-related issues.

To address the complaints of dirty linen, the capacity of mechanized laundry in Bilaspur has been enhanced from 1 tonne to 3 tonnes per shift. Similarly, the capacity of the laundry at Raipur has been increased from 1 tonne to 4 tonnes. “SECR’s 22 trains have been supplied linen through these laundries,” he added.

Title: Demand for labour court in Pimpri Chinchwad
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: The Pimpri Chinchwad Small Industries Association (PCSIA) has sought an industrial and labour court in Pimpri Chinchwad in a memorandum.

Belsare said a delegation of the association led by former Shiv Sena Pimpri MLA Gautam Chabukswar met industries minister Subhash Desai and power minister Nitin Raut in Mumbai.

The association demanded strict action against unauthorised mathadi organisations, a reduction in the water tax and land transfer fees of the MIDC, slums on MIDC land be removed and such land be allotted to set up new industries and measures to control rising prices of raw material and property tax for industries.

Belsare said, “Desai said a meeting will be held in Mantralaya to discuss these problems.”

The association’s memorandum to Raut said the new proposal given by MSEDCL to MERC for increasing the power rates will make it impossible to run industries in the state.

They also wanted that industrialists be permitted to pay their power bills in instalments and sought strict action to prevent power theft. Belsare said, “ Raut said efforts would be made to solve the problems of the industrialists.”

Title: 18 years on, Pakistan activist Chawla’s Nagpur-based family still awaits justice
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Sudhamchand, who ran a movement — restoration of joint elections in Pakistan, was shot dead in the Jacobabad t... Read More

Nagpur: Sudhamchand Chawla, a political activist in Pakistan, who fought against the system of separate electorates based on religion, was shot dead in public view in the Jacobabad town of Sindh province on January 28, 2002. Sudhamchand, who ran a movement — restoration of joint elections in Pakistan, had won a case against separate electorates in the Supreme Court less than a month before his killing.

The assassination had led to an uproar on both sides of the borders. Narendra Modi, who was the then chief minister of Gujarat, had called him the Mahatma Gandhi of Pakistan. Jacobabad was shut for three days and in Nagpur, the RSS had held a public meeting to condemn Chawla’s killing.

Eighteen years down the line, his family, settled in Nagpur, still awaits justice.

In the backdrop of the protests against CAA-NRC and recent developments of alleged abductions in Pakistan, public meets to mark Chawla’s death were held on Tuesday. The day was marked in Indore and Nagpur.

Chawla’s story had slipped into oblivion. “Whatever has happened lately, has left the community disturbed again,” says his son Manoj, referring to incidents of alleged abduction of a girl (Mahek Kumari) in Jacobabad and the daughter of a Granthi (priest) in the Sikh shrine of Nanakana Sahib. “May be public memory of my father is a reaction to those incidents,” he says. For years, the family drew attention of even the international media.

“His (Chawla’s) main intent was to do away with separate religion-based elections. He believed in bringing all voters and candidates at par. With separate electorates, voters of the minority communities were being alienated from Muslim politicians. My father wanted to break the barriers,” he says.

“The case was won on January 5 and on the 28th, he was going to the Jacobabd collectorate’s office for some work related to the case. The assailants shot him from the rear,” says Manoj, who was in Nagpur that day.

“I had already joined my kin in Nagpur in 1992 and studied in SFS School. The others joined us after my father’s assassination,” he says.

His uncle Laxman came down to Nagpur from Pakistan in 1978 and was a member of the BJP.

The assailants were shot dead when they were going to depose before the court against Aijaz Jhakrani, a politician from the Pakistan People’s Party (PPP), who allegedly masterminded Chawla’s killing. The case hasn’t moved any further. “We had filed a plea two years ago from Nagpur but because of our absence, no progress has taken place,” he says.

“Jhakrani had been named in the FIR. I have written many letters to leaders like former prime minister Nawaz Sharif, federal ministers and chief justices. The last letter was sent to Asif Sayeed Khosa, the then chief justice, three months ago,” says his brother Kanwar Chawla.

“Ghinwa Bhutto was among the many politicians who expressed outrage over the killing. She compared Chawla’s killing to her husband Murtuza Bhutto’s assassination,” he says.

“Chawla was a cult figure in Jacobabad and had the support of both Hindus and Muslims,” says his friend and social activist Azeez Abro from Pakistan.

Title: Public hospital sees organ donation in Mumbai after two years
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: After a gap of two years, the city has witnessed an organ donation from a public hospital this week. Parel’s KEM Hospital on Monday facilitated the cadaver donation of a 52-year-old man whose liver saved the life of a Satara man.

In an otherwise growing organ donation programme, the contribution of public hospitals has been lacking in the city. In 2019, for instance, out of the record number of 79 donations, not one came from a public hospital. In fact, the last time public hospitals contributed to a handful of donations was in 2017 when J J Hospital facilitated two and Sion one. KEM Hospital had last recorded a donation in May 2016.

The recent donor was admitted to the hospital with a history of fall. Subsequently, he was diagnosed as having suffered a stroke. Dean Dr Hemant Deshmukh said the patient was declared brain dead after two apnea tests on Monday. “The family willingly consented to donate his organs. Due to certain blood parameters, his kidneys were not considered suitable for donation by the kidney committee of the Zonal Transplant Coordination Committee (ZTCC),” he said. The liver was allotted to Apollo Hospital, where the organ was transplanted into a Satara man. “We have restarted the program after over two years. The family has also expressed their desire to assist in spreading awareness about organ donation,” he said.

Experts say the reasons for failure to convert brain deaths into successful donations in public hospitals range from inability to carry out timely apnea tests within six hours, finding doctors to complete the brain death certification process to maintaining the donor. “Lack of awareness among the clientele coming to public hospitals is also an issue. But the situation is changing fast,” said a social worker. He added that awareness drives by the state’s medical education department have managed to make people aware of the concept of organ donation.

Dr S Mathur, president of ZTCC that distributes cadaver organs, said they have provided a transplant coordinator to handhold KEM with paperwork and other processes. “We believe the participation of public hospitals will grow. We will provide them with whatever support we can” said Mathur and added this month has seen seven donations in the city.

Title: Chennai: Man cuts cake with machete on wedding, warned and let off
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Video of the man cutting his wedding cake with a machete went viral

CHENNAI: A young man who cut a cake with a machete at Thiruverkadu on Monday to celebrate his marriage after being persuaded by his friends found a police team on his doorstep the next day. Bhuvanesh’s friends had come to greet the man who was a ‘bus route rowdy’ when they were all in college.

The law enforcers, however, let 23-year-old Bhuvanesh off with a warning that any such ‘heroic’ activity in future would see him behind the bars. “We considered his future,” said an investigating officer.

The trend of cutting cakes with machetes, which began with gangster Binu Papachan, has led to police booking those celebrating in such fashion. But Bhuvanesh’s friends, all of who travelled on the bus route that he had lorded over during their college days, didn’t know that.

When they trooped into the wedding hall where the resident of Karumariamman Koil Street had got hitched to his girlfriend on Monday, the ‘gifts’ they carried a cake and a few machetes took everyone by surprise.

Bhuvanesh, a history graduate, was wondering about the unusual present, when his friends convinced him to cut the cake with the ‘sword’. Taken in by the promise of instant stardom, he gave in. The 29-second video of Bhuvanesh cutting the cake and two of his friends, also holding machetes on the stage, and cheering the bride and hailing their former ‘leader’ soon went viral on social media platforms. His friends had shared it without informing him.

On Tuesday, Bhuvanesh was all over social media and even television after some channels had picked up the video clip and had started flashing it. A few of his shocked relatives rushed to his house to know what had happened. Soon, a police team reached the spot looking for him. He was taken to the police station and a few of his friends were also picked up for interrogation.

Investigation revealed that the man who had brought the machete was a man named Mani, Bhuvanesh’s junior in college. He is said to have switched off his mobile phone after the incident. Bhuvanesh, who now works at a private firm, had been booked for a few minor offences during his college days, said a police officer.

Title: PMRDA’s plea for allotment of 4 TMC water remains pending
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Pune: The Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority’s demand for 4 TMC water from 15 dams in the district is still pending with the irrigation department, casting a shadow on the liveability of the proposed townships.

“A review meeting was conducted last week, but no clear guidelines were issued on water allocation from the dams. With several constructions to come up in the area, water allocation is a must,” said an official of the Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority (PMRDA).

At present, people solely depend on the extraction of underground water in the PMRDA limits.

The estimated present population of nearly 29 lakh in the PMRDA limits is expected to double in the next two decades. The Maharashtra Krishna Valley Development Corporation has to clear its proposal for fetching water from dams like Vadiwale, Andra, Chaskaman, Bhatghar, Rihe, Urawade or Pusane.

“A number of projects such as town planning schemes, ring road and Metro line have been proposed in the PMRDA limits. Against this backdrop, allocation of water to the area should be given priority,” said another PMRDA official.

Many areas around Hinjewadi and Wagholi have been protesting over water shortage and citizens have raised an alarm on tanker mafia.

On Monday, deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar told TOI that they would request for 10 TMC water from Tata dam to help meet the demands of the city as well as the rural areas. He discussed the water allocation for the PMRDA limits last week but steered clear from the assessment of the dams in its area.

The state government had constituted a six-member committee last September to revise water distribution and usage plan for the area. The panel headed by the principal secretary of the state urban development department made recommendations about the distribution to the water resources department on the available storage and the use of water in the metropolitan region. It also carried out a survey of all reservoirs in the district to assess the ways to meet the demand.

Title: Kolkata: 12-year-old back home for puja found hanging
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: A 12-year-old boy was found hanging at his Chandernagore residence in Hooghly on Tuesday morning.

Samrat Pal studied at a school in Barrackpore, where he lived with a relative. He had come to his Chandernagore home on Sunday during the Saraswati Puja break. It was on Tuesday morning that his family found him hanging from the ceiling fan in his room. He was immediately taken to a local hospital, where he was declared dead. Police have not found any note but preliminary investigations pointed at suicide. The family told an officer from the Chandernagore police station that on returning home this time, Samrat did not want to return to Barrackpore.

The body has been sent for post-mortem. Nobody has yet been detained. “We are yet to know what led to Samrat’s death but it looks like he had hanged himself. Post-mortem will reveal the exact cause of his death. On speaking to his parents, we feel he might have wanted to stay back at home,” an officer said.

Title: Pune man in isolation ward tests negative; 29-year-old placed under quarantine
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A 29-year-old man from the city, who had travelled to China recently, was quarantined at the PMC-run Naidu Infectious Diseases Hospital on Tuesday evening after he complained of minor influenza-like symptoms, including cold and fever.His throat swab samples would be sent to the National Institute of Virology laboratory for testing on Wednesday to rule out a coronavirus infection.Earlier on Tuesday, the throat swab samples of a 51-year-old man — also quarantined at Naidu hospital — tested negative. The test results of the other man in quarantine are awaited. Both men had complained of similar symptoms.The 51-year-old had returned recently from Shanghai, while the other man, a 30-year-old, had travelled to parts of Wuhan “The 51-year-old tested negative for the novel coronavirus infection, when his throat swab samples were analysed at NIV’s laboratory,” public health expert Ramchandra Hankare, who is also the head of PMC’s health department, said.“He will remain isolated for a few more days only as a precautionary measure. We will retest his throat swab samples after two to three days,” Hankare said.Three others from Pimpri Chinchwad, who travelled to China recently, have been under surveillance for 28 days. “The three travellers in Pimpri Chinchwad are showing no symptoms and so, they have not been isolated. Their samples have also not been sent for testing to NIV’s laboratory. We will only keep track of their health status over the telephone,” a state health official said.

Title: Now, women roped in to nurture saplings planted by forest department
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Dehradun: In a bid to increase the survival rate of lakhs of newly planted saplings, the Rudraprayag forest division has started an initiative in which local women in the villages will be hired to look after the plants. Till now, plantation watchers -- with salary of Rs 8,000 a month -- took care of the plants, but still the survival rate of the saplings had not improved. Under Compensatory Afforestation Fund Act (CAMPA), several crores of saplings were planted in the state.

In a pilot project, one plantation spread over 10 hectares each in all the six ranges of Rudraprayag forest division -- Agasthyamuni, Khakra, North Jakholi, South Kakholi, Rudraprayag and Guptkashi -- has been handed over to women Self Help Groups (SHGs) for upkeep. Each forest division is given additional funds annually for the maintenance of these plants, and forest officials are of the opinion that women, by playing an active role, will not only help in safeguarding the newly planted 'mini forests' but will also ensure that saplings are protected from ‘forest fires’, which are primarily responsible destruction of saplings.

“Till now, each plantation is looked after by one plantation watcher. But it is not possible for one man to look after all the plants. Now, with SHGs in the role, we will have over hundred eyes and hands to safeguard the saplings, especially from forest fire. It will also promote transparency in the system as these women will be responsible for taking care of each sapling . They will also get paid for it. We have given a month-wise checklist to these women to which they will have to adhere to ensure that the saplings survive,” said Vaibahv Singh, DFO, Rudraprayag forest division.

Rudraprayag forest division is spread across 59, 867 hectares of land and has massive plantation of kachnar, gooseberry, bamboo, deodar and ringal -- based on topography and location.

Environmentalists have praised the initiative as it creates a win-win situation for the hill women and the forest department. They say women had spearheaded some of the world renowned movements to protect trees. “In the hills, women have always been emotionally connected to the forests; for example, the Chipko Movement. Hence, it is a praiseworthy move by the forest department. It would not be taxing for these women to do the task as they go to the jungle to collect fodder every day," said Padma Shri KS Rawat, founder of Maiti Aandolan who initiated a similar move in 1995 under which a girl plants a tree in her parents' place on her wedding day and thereafter her mother takes care of it.

The women are all agog about the new initiative, saying the hills will be saved now, “These are our forests, we will always need fodder for our livestock. By protecting the plants, we are protecting our future,” said Manju Devi (38) of Mahila Mangal Dal Jakholi, Rudraprayag.

Title: Padmavati refuses to end fast despite officials’ request
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020
