Haridwar: Senior officials of state government, including Haridwar’s DM and SSP, couldn’t convince Brahmacharini Padmavati (23) to end her hunger strike against what she terms as the government’s apathy towards river Ganga .

The officials met the woman seer from Bihar on Tuesday at Matri Sadan Ashram. Padmavati, who has been fasting for 45 days now, cleared that she won’t end her strike until all the four hydropower plants on Ganga are shut.

“Most of her demands are being considered but it takes a while for things to happen. We have urged the seer to call off her hunger strike,” Haridwar SSP S Senthil Avoodai Krishnaraj told TOI.

Incidentally, their visit was followed by the visit of anther senior official from Muzaffarnagar district (in Uttar Pradesh). The UP official jotted down Padmavati’s demands and identified those which have already been met.

According to seers, the UP official came to Matri Sadan after state chief minister Yogi Adityanath was quizzed about the efforts being taken to meet Padmavati’s demands during his visit to Bijnor to flag-off the five-day long Ganga Yatra. “Padmavati is risking her life for the cause of Ganga. If not Uttarakhand CM, we hope at least the UP CM pays heed to her demands,” said Brahamachari Dayanand, a Matri Sadan seer.

On Saturday, Matri Sadan seers had expressed their fear that the state government might use force to end the ongoing fast-unto-death by Padmavati. Some had even said that the state government might make an attempt to kill Padmavati or Matri Sadan Ashram chief Swami Shivanad Saraswati.

In an application given to Haridwar chief judicial magistrate, Brahmachari Dayanand has claimed that two Matri Sadan seers – professor GD Agrawal and Swami Nigamanand – were “killed” for protesting against Ganga pollution.

A few days ago, Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar urged Prime Minister Narendra Modi to intervene to end the fast being observed by Sadhvi Padmavati.

Title: TSF moves PCMC to undertake drainage repair & plug pollution
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Sewage flowing into the Pavana river before the repair work

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The drainage department of the civic body has repaired the broken drainage chambers and diverted sewage from a nullah through pipelines to the Kalewadi sewage treatment plant (STP) to prevent pollution of Pavana river.

Thergaon Social Foundation (TSF) found that a nullah and three broken drainage chambers in Thergaon and nearby areas were polluting the river. It drew the attention of the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) towards plugging the pollution sources.

Rahul Sarvade of TSF said, “Fish deaths have been a common occurrence in Pavana river over the past few years because of untreated sewage entering the river. We received information from Chinchwad residents in December about foaming water being seen in the morning near Dhaneshwar bridge. We found three broken drainage chambers near Sukhwani society.”

Prashant Patil, the executive engineer of the drainage department, said, “We laid a new pipeline to connect the chambers to another pipeline for taking the sewage to the nearest STP.”

Title: Kolkata: Cops nab three pickpockets, find 18 mobiles
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Police have claimed to have busted a gang of pickpockets that had been targeting passengers travelling on EM Bypass in crowded buses.

A raid by the watch section of the detective department led to the arrest of three persons — Aftab Alam alias Altaf (52), Md Rehan (18) and Sakir Alam. While Altaf is from Garia, the other two are from Tiljala and Karaya respectively.

“As many as 18 high-end mobile phones were recovered. They used to steal mobile phones in crowded buses on EM Bypass during peak hours,” said joint CP (crime) Murlidhar Sharma. Cops are now trying to locate the owners of the phones.

In another incident, a huge cache of ornaments was recovered from a man, Hannan Ali Gayen (45) from Canning, who was accused of stealing them.

Title: Why Chennai corporation bureaucrats will visit Singapore’s mosquito lab
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

City Corporation officials will be visiting Singapore to study a ‘mosquito laboratory’ in a bid to contain the... Read More

CHENNAI: Greater Chennai Corporation officials will be visiting Singapore to study a ‘ mosquito laboratory ’ in a bid to contain the spread of dengue .

Singapore has successfully bred male mosquitoes in controlled laboratory conditions and injected them with the Wolbachia strain of bacteria. The mosquitoes are released in the surroundings with guns. When infected mosquitoes mate with the females, the embryos formed die. In effect, the male mosquitoes are rendered sterile by the bacteria.

Over a period of time, this can gradually bring down the number of the mosquitoes carrying the dengue virus, thereby reducing the spread of dengue, said a senior official. There are published studies documenting this, he said.

In Tuesday’s review meeting, corporation commissioner G Prakash briefed local bodies minister S P Velumani on the steps taken by Singapore. Prakash informed the minister about the civic body’s plan to conduct a study tour.

While Velumani is understood to have given a green signal, he said the conditions and landscape in Singapore was different. Spread of dengue is dependent on conditions like how water is stored and the extent of urban planning which impacts mosquito behaviour, a source said.

The officials are likely to conduct a study of how the mosquito colonies are reared, how the eggs are produced and the male mosquitoes are maintained.

B Dhanraj, retired chief vector control officer of the corporation, told TOI that in principle the idea worked but there would be practical difficulties in executing it.

“Singapore is an island, where the sterile male mosquitoes will mate with wild females. However, Chennai is an open place and there are many wild males which may come along with migrants coming on bus or train from nearby towns or districts,” Dhanraj said.

However, there was no harm in conducting a trial and gauge its success. “Since we are going against nature, rate of success will depend on many factors,” he said.

Dhanraj recalled how in 70s, chemo-sterile mosquitoes were released in Delhi but faced a public backlash when the mosquitoes were released. “It was because the residents had not been informed and educated about the process and benefits it would give,” he said.

Title: Maharashtra: New FYJC system to have toll-free help
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The admission process for the 2020-21 first year junior college (FYJC) in the state will have additional features such as possible options of institutes for the students and a toll-free call centre to address their queries.

The new system will also have an online payment option for the students to buy soft copies of the booklet on guidelines. State education director Dinkar Patil said the Kolhapur division has been included in the online system, while Pune, Mumbai, Nagpur, Aurangabad and Nashik would continue with the e-admission process.

“We are constantly trying to upgrade the system to make the Standard XI admission process user-friendly and convenient for lakhs of students across the state. Out IT team is working on ways to incorporate the latest technology inputs in the system and the new features will be added from this year. We have floated a tender for companies to implement the new features,” Patil said.

When a student will file the “option” form Part 2, the new system will pop up possible options of colleges for him or her to choose from.

“The data from the previous year will be used as the base for this feature. The system will automatically show the options to the students. They can refer to the options while filling their college preferences,” the official said.

Every year, the students complain about several issues while filling the forms, after submitting them and also when the merit list is announced. Students from outside Maharashtra and from the non-state board willing to apply to colleges and schools affiliated to the state board require time-to-time assistance.

Patil said the call centre would be set up to address the queries of all the applicants.

Another important feature is on the book of guidelines the students receive at their respective schools. “Instances of parents returning home from work during late hours are galore and it is difficult for them to buy the booklet from the schools. Keeping this in mind, we have introduced the system of an online guidebook. The students can get a soft copy of it following an online payment.”

Among the new features in the current request for proposal in the system are customizations of the old online admission system, the eligibility module and cellphone application. Close to one lakh students from Pune take part in the online FYJC admission process every year. The number of students from Mumbai is around 2.25 lakh.

The new system will also have an online payment option for the students to buy soft copies of the booklet on guidelines. When a student will file the “option” form Part 2, the new system will pop up possible options of colleges for him or her to choose from.

“The data from the previous year will be used as the base for this feature. The system will automatically show the options to the students. They can refer to the options while filling their college preferences,” the official said.

Every year, the students complain about several issues while filling the forms, after submitting them and also when the merit list is announced. Students from outside Maharashtra and from the non-state board willing to apply to colleges and schools affiliated to the state board require time-to-time assistance.

Patil said the call centre would be set up to address the queries of all the applicants.

Another important feature is on the book of guidelines the students receive at their respective schools. “Instances of parents returning home from work during late hours are galore and it is difficult for them to buy the booklet from the schools. Keeping this in mind, we have introduced the system of an online guidebook. The students can get a soft copy of it following an online payment.”

Among the new features in the current request for proposal in the system are customizations of the old online admission system, the eligibility module and cellphone application. Close to one lakh students from Pune take part in the online FYJC admission process every year. The number of students from Mumbai is around 2.25 lakh.

Title: Goa sees sharp fall in tourists from UK, Finland, but Russia rises to the occasion
Content:
The UK has been a traditional charter market for Goa, but Sita Travels’ chief operating officer Ernest Dias sa... Read More

PANAJI: Goa witnessed a sharp decline in tourist footfalls from the UK in the last two months of 2019. While November saw a 40% reduction from the same month the previous year, the drop in December was a 50% from the same month in 2018. The collapse of British travel company Thomas Cook is mainly responsible for the decline, stakeholders said.The UK has been a traditional charter market for Goa, but Sita Travels’ chief operating officer Ernest Dias said that Goa has only been receiving four charters a week from there this season. The November-December period in 2018 saw 69 charters from the UK bring in 19,956 tourists, while the same period last year saw 9,723 tourists arriving in 36 charters.However, while the drop in British arrivals is along expected lines, Goa isn’t receiving charters from Finland either. Dias said that while a leading operator that handles Finnish charters has discontinued service to Goa, travellers from Finland, Sweden and Denmark are still visiting Goa via scheduled flights.However, not all foreign tourist arrivals are down. This rise has been contrary to expectations of stakeholders. Since Russian footfalls witnessed a drop during the last two seasons — from 1,67,339 travellers in 2017-18 to 92,396 in 2018-19 — stakeholders anticipated a further decline.But November 2019 saw 59 flights with 19,727 passengers and December, 65 flights with 21,471 passengers, a substantial rise from 2018, in which November saw 48 flights with 15,010 passengers, and December, 50 flights with 16,370 passengers.However, Dias doesn’t believe that this season has seen more tourists than the previous one. “I don’t think the figures are right,” he said.Meanwhile, Travel and Tourism Association of Goa (TTAG) president Savio Messias said that two other operators who handle Russian charters also have admitted to a slight rise in Russian tourist numbers, but also a drop in revenue. “We are not receiving high-spending tourists,” Messias said, adding that Russian tourists have turned away from Goa since they’ve found cheaper destinations elsewhere.

Title: PMC bid to beautify spaces below flyovers with murals & gardens
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

The Ramesh Wanjale flyover at Dhayari Phata and the space below it is full of two-wheelers parked by citizens

PUNE: If the civic administration has its way, the spaces under flyovers across the city will soon be free of encroachment, illegal use and unauthorized parking .

Pune Municipal Corporation ( PMC ) officials said the administration has decided to beautify such spaces with landscape designs, murals, hanging gardens and artificial lawns.

A proposal to develop the spaces has been tabled in the draft civic budget for 2020-21 presented by municipal chief Shekhar Gaikwad on Monday. The PMC has allocated Rs5 crore for the beautification work.

The city currently has 18 flyovers. The officials said two additional flyovers were under construction and many more at the proposed stages. In the coming financial year, the officials said, the administration was looking forward to beautify spaces under at least 10 flyovers. The administration has decided to inspect each flyover and then chalk out the beautification work.

PMC officials said steps have been proposed in the civic budget to keep a tab on the illegal use of the spaces under flyovers and curb encroachments. They said many citizens have been using the spaces to park their vehicles . At many spots, food stalls have taken over such spaces. “The administration will first seal the spaces and then go ahead with the beautification work,” an official said.

The state urban development department had in 2009 issued a notification banning parking of vehicles below flyovers, bridges and underpasses. The notification was issued after the 2008 Mumbai terror attacks and on the ground that parking of vehicles posed security threats to flyovers.

Copies of the notification were sent to all municipal corporations/councils and planning authorities to ban parking of vehicles at such facilities. The Bombay high court also banned parking of vehicles under flyovers on June 20, 2013, upholding the government’s 2008 decision and its 2012 stand on the threat perception.

The civic administration has carried out repeated drives to free the spaces under the flyovers of encroachments and stop illegal parking of vehicles. The problems, however, continued to persist, much to the chagrin of the civic administration and the law abiding citizens.

The civic body has initiated steps to find permanent solutions against encroachment under flyovers and bridges. Its city improvement committee (CIC) recently passed a resolution to vacate the spaces under flyovers. In fact, the CIC in its proposal stated that the city traffic police should shift all the chowkies that have come up under the flyovers to other places.

A CIC member said, “The space under a flyover should ideally be vacant, despite there has been a demand to develop these areas as authorized parking lots. The CIC has passed a resolution to keep a tab on encroachments below the flyovers. Such spaces should be utilized for the road users.”

Commuters and local residents have been frequently complaining about the illegal use of such spaces. One such example is the space under the flyover in the Patil Estate area. The space under the Patil Estate flyover in Wakdewadi is in a disarray because of illegal parking of vehicles and dumping of garbage. Over the time, it has become an extension of the Patil Estate slums, with people using it for all private purposes.

Sanjay Shinde, who regularly travels from old Pune-Mumbai road through the Patil Estate area, said, “The space under the flyover has been occupied by vehicles. There is no control over such activities. The space should be vacant.”

“The PMC can put up a mesh around the space to avoid its illegal use,” he added.

Title: Over 1L ghost teachers in engg colleges eliminated
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Pune: A scrutiny by All India Council of Technical Education (AICTE) of teachers on the rolls at engineering colleges across the country found that over one lakh either existed on paper or were working without the requisite qualification or teaching at multiple institutes as full-time faculty.

“Since renewal or continuation of engineering courses depended on AICTE’s approval of information provided by the colleges, the institutions were forced to submit correct data which eventually resulted in the number of teachers coming down from about 6.5 lakh to 5 lakh at engineering colleges. The number of seats in engineering colleges too has come down to about 14 lakh,” AICTE chairman Anil Sahasrabuddhe told TOI.

Sahasrabuddhe said, “We wanted to identify bogus teachers or ghost faculty in engineering colleges. We told all colleges to submit the data of their teachers when they apply for renewal or continuation of technical courses. As for the ID card, we asked them to submit the PAN card details or the Aadhaar card details of the faculty. We found that there were many colleges, which were showing ghost faculty or bogus faculty on their rolls. We also found that there were people who had their names as teaching faculty of several colleges. We were able to bring down over 1 lakh such teachers and now the number of teaching faculty is about 5 lakh.”

There were about 16 lakh seats in all engineering colleges of the country. After progressive closure clause, many colleges had to shut down divisions, some did it due to non-availability of students. About 10 lakh students enter engineering colleges across India. The remaining seats are vacant, Sahasrabuddhe added.

Title: Heated chemo drugs have more impact: Doctors
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Certain chemotherapy drugs when heated up can become more effective, say cancer specialists.

The novel method — Hyperthermic Intra-Vesical Chemotherapy ( HIVEC ) — is currently being used in city hospitals to treat bladder cancer patients.

The process involves warming the chemotherapy drug before releasing it into the cancer-affected bladder through a special catheter. The drug is heated up to 43-45 degree Centigrade. It’s circulated four times in a minute within the bladder and found to have encouraging results in preventing further development of cancer, say doctors.

Recently, the technique was used on a 58-year-old male bladder cancer patient at Fortis Hospital. “We use the heated chemo drug in the confined space of the bladder. This has greater bio-absorption and improves the entire process of chemotherapy. It further stimulates the body’s immunity to enhance the drug’s benefit,” said Dr Mohan Keshavamurthy, director urology, uro-oncology Fortis Hospital, who headed the treatment team.

“In high-grade bladder cancer, removal of the bladder is an option, but it has social and psychological consequences for a patient. In such cases we suggest HIVEC. Also, there is a significant probability of recurrence of cancer among many patients, which can be prevented using HIVEC,” said Dr Mohan.

At HCG hospital, HIVEC has been used to treat seven first-stage high-risk bladder cancer cases in the last two years.

“Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG), an intravesical immunotherapy used for treating early-stage bladder cancer, may turn out to be unresponsive for some patients. In such cases, we heat a chemotherapy drug, intravesical mitomycin, up to 43-45 degree Centigrade,” said Dr Raghunath S Krishnappa, uro-oncologist, HCG.

Heated chemotherapy drugs are also used in treating select cases of third-stage cancer in gastrointestinal tract and ovaries at some city hospitals. In HIPEC (hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy), the heated drug is passed via peritoneum, a membrane forming the lining of the abdominal cavity.

According to Dr Manjunath N, medical oncologist, Vydehi Hospital, HIPEC is being used at their hospital for close to seven years. “Increased temperature enhances the efficacy of the drug. It increases cell penetration,” he explained. Dr Rani Bhat, head and senior consultant, gynaecological oncology, HCG said: “Currently, we use HIPEC treatment only for select patients. The outcomes have been satisfying. However, research on this issue is on and we need to understand the future better.”

Not at govt-run Kidwai yet

The heated chemotherapy treatment mode is yet to be tried out at government-run Kidwai Memorial Institute of Oncology (KMIO). The required equipment costs no less than Rs 25 lakh, while one opting for HIPEC pays Rs 60,000.

“HIPEC is more essential at a public hospital like Kidwai, where we get patients in third and fourth stages of cancer. It can be very helpful in treating ovarian colorectal and stomach cancers. After removing the tumour, one sitting of HIPEC can check the recurrence,” said Dr C Ramachandra, director, KMIO.

“We can buy the equipment only when Ayushman Bharat-Arogya Karnataka scheme allows cashless treatment for the same. Else, it becomes very expensive for patients,” Dr Ramachandra told TOI.

Title: Goa government asks citizens to remain calm
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Goa Medical College dean Dr S M Bandekar said that though symptoms of Coronavirus are the same as common cold, they will be more severe in case a patient is afflicted with the new disease. “A person will have difficulty breathing, and the condition may lead to pneumonia,” he told TOI on Tuesday.Most patients, he said, also develop palpitations and headache, and may go on to suffer organ failure.He added that not much is known about Coronavirus. Also, there is no vaccine developed yet to treat the disease. “We must prevent it from spreading,” he said.However, he said people should not panic and not fall prey to false information circulated on social media. “There is a lot of wrong information transmitted via WhatsApp,” he said.Health secretary Sanjay Kumar said people should not panic as the government has taken all measures. The state team is in talks with the central team.So far all samples sent to NIV have come negative, Kumar said. GMC said as per WHO statistics, 53 confirmed cases have been discharged from hospitals. From the information coming in, children below 14 (padeatric age group) do not catch the virus, Bandekar said.Opposition leader Digambar Kamat also asked people to keep calm on the detection of one suspect case of Coronavirus. “Let us all be alert and careful. Prevention is better than cure. Let us all maintain hygiene. I urge chief minister Pramod Sawant and health minister Vishwajit Rane to take preventive steps on priority,” he added.People should not fall prey to false information circulated on social media. There is a lot of wrong information transmitted via WhatsApp. Let us all be alert and careful and maintain hygiene

Title: Pune airport director transferred
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

PUNE: The city airport director, Ajay Kumar , has been transferred on promotion as the new chief executive officer of the Chandigarh international airport.

“The Airports Authority of India (AAI) will announce Kumar’s replacement in due course. He has handed over the charge to A Srinivasa Rao, who will be the officiating airport director till the new director is appointed,” an AAI officer said.

Kumar held the Pune airport director ’s post from May 2015. He had taken charge from Manoj Kumar Gangal, who was transferred barely after completing a year-and-a-half in the office. The regular tenure for an airport director is three years.

Aviation analyst and expert Dhairyashil Vandekar said, “The new airport director should emphasize on making the facility passenger-friendly.”

Title: International Theatre Festival of Kerala concludes on Wednesday amid demand to make it more vibrant
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Those associated with ITFoK said it was an ‘average affair’ in terms of selection, seminar and discussions

THRISSUR: The International Theatre Festival of Kerala ( ITFoK ) will conclude on Wednesday, leaving behind a demand: a thorough revisit of the present format to ensure that it is on the same page with its founding goals.

Those associated with ITFoK said the festival was an ‘average affair’ in terms of play selection, seminar and discussions. Theatre activist Sheena A M said the usual festive mood at Regional Theatre was missing and the ambience felt silent as a grave during the festival on most occasions. C G Byju, another theatre activist, attributed this to lack of public participation largely to bureaucratization and organizers limiting their efforts to the limited few in their circles.

But festival coordinator K Jaleel refuted the charges and said some theatre activists in Kerala adopt an indifferent attitude if their plays are not included at ITFoK. He said paucity of funds was the culprit for 80% of the shortcomings. Only Rs 1 crore was sanctioned for ITFoK when Rs 3 crore was required, he said.

Prabalan Velur, who is active in this field for two decades, said an atmosphere of subtle fear was prevailing in the academy where theatre activists are not free to express their opinions and it is important to know why this is happening. P N Prakash, who was a member of the selection panel for Malayalam plays, said discussions at seminars did not reflect the intensity prevailing in India’s political landscape. Theatre activist K V Ganesh said the setbacks of this edition should be a lesson to evolve a more mass-based, vibrant festival in future.

Among international plays ‘Silver epidemic’ from Brazil and ‘Coriolanus’ from Iran was widely appreciated. Plays like ‘An evening with immigrant’ from the UK and ‘I is another–Rimbaud in Africa’ from Norway invited criticisms for failing to communicate with the audience. Among Malayalam plays, ‘Veendum Bhagavante Maranam’, ‘Bhaskara Pattelurum Thommiyude Jeevithavum’ and ‘Old Man and Sea’ were well received, while the play ‘Bombay Sketches’ invited criticism. ‘Salma Deewani’ from Hyderabad and Kala Dhabbah Badel Ki Tarah Aa Raha Hai from Bhopal were appreciated by the audience.

Title: Tortured, sexually abused in jail: Nirbhaya case convict
Content:
Mukesh Singh

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court will on Wednesday deliver its order on the plea of one of the death row convicts in Nirbhaya case , challenging rejection of his mercy plea by the President on the ground that all the relevant material was not placed by the government before him.A bench of Justices R Banumathi, Ashok Bhushan and A S Bopanna reserved its order after hearing the case for one and half hours during which senior advocate Anjana Prakash, appearing for Mukesh Kumar, contended that the President was not given all the documents to decide the mercy plea and there was non-application of mind in rejecting it. Solicitor general Tushar Mehta, however, refuted the allegation and said there was no illegality in dismissal of mercy petition as all relevant materials were placed before the President by the Union home ministry.Alleging that there was undue haste on the part of the government in deciding the mercy plea, Prakash contended that the convict was physically and mentally tortured inside Tihar Jail and he was illegally put in solitary confinement, which must be considered while deciding on his plea. She said Mukesh was beaten on a daily basis inside the jail and was even forced to have sexual intercourse with other convicts in the Nirbhaya case in public glare inside the prison premises.Countering her contentions, Mehta reminded the court of the brutal and bestial act of the convict in merciless rape and killing of Nirbhaya and said that the mercy plea is not a “luxurious jurisdiction” for him. Mehta said suffering inside the jail cannot be a ground to seek mercy and told the bench that the convict was never placed in solitary confinement. He said Mukesh was kept in a separate cell on many occasions like many of the prisoners and was allowed to mingle with other inmates.“There was no arbitrariness in the decision to reject his mercy plea. It is a mandate of law to expeditiously decide mercy plea as delay caused dehumanising effect on the death row convict. The home ministry placed all the documents along with report on his medical condition before the President,” Mehta said. He also placed before the bench two original files containing correspondence for consideration of mercy plea and file noting.Observing that it has very limited jurisdiction in examining the validity of the decision taken by the President, the bench reserved its order.Nirbhaya, a 23-year-old paramedic, was brutally assaulted and gang-raped in a moving bus in south Delhi and thrown out of the vehicle with her male friend on December 16, 2012. She died in a Singapore hospital on December 29.The trial court awarded the convicts death sentence in September 2013 and six months later, Delhi high court upheld their conviction and sentence.

Title: ‘Assured innovation policy need of time’
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Raghunath Mashelkar addresses the gathering at CSIR-Neeri

Nagpur: India needs a new innovation framework which is affordable, scalable and sustainable for which there should be a ‘quantified’ system to assess, fund and monitor everything, from start-ups to various projects, said Raghunath Mashelkar , former director general of Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR).

He was speaking on his book ‘From leap frogging to pole-vaulting: Creating the magic of radical yet sustainable transformation’ at CSIR-Neeri auditorium.

Mashelkar said suitable framework should be used for start-ups, government-funded, and in-house institutional and industrial projects. He showed how the assured framework can be used for judicious evaluation of successful as also unsuccessful innovations.

In his book, Mashelkar has laid out the contours of an integrated strategy with assured success. He also spoke about why start-ups should pole-vault and not leapfrog, based on the assured framework. It looks at scalability and sustainability in economic, environmental and societal context and delves on why start-ups should be distinctive, he added.

He said there were some recent game-changing assured innovations which had a deep impact. He said the telephone could reach 50 million users in 50 years, but a recent mobile phone entity took only 83 days. This is pole-vaulting, he said.

Earlier, Mashelkar had a meeting with Rakesh Kumar, director of CSIR-Neeri. He also interacted with Sunil Mansinghka, coordinator, Govigyan Anusandhan Kendra.

PK Labhasetwar, senior principal scientist and head, water technology and management division, CSIR-Neeri, briefed on performance evaluation of 12 water treatment technologies and other issues.

JS Pandey, chief scientist and head, climate change and skilling division (CCSD), introduced Mashelkar. Sadhana Rayalu, chief scientist and head, environmental material division (EMD), proposed a vote of thanks.

Shalini Dhyani conducted the proceedings while scientists Ankit Gupta, coordinated the event.

Title: Pune: Seven standard VIII pupils booked for assault
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Seven standard VIII students of an English medium school in Kondhwa were booked on Monday by the Wanowrie police on charges of rioting and assaulting their classmate on November 22, last year.The assault took place during the recess after a quarrel over the 15-year-old victim’s prompt replies to the teachers’ questions in class the same day.The victim’s father said he had reported the matter to the school’s authorities immediately, but they did not act on his complaint. He then met senior officials at the police commissionerate and then lodged an FIR against the students.He also said that some students in his son’s class do not like that his son replies to questions that teachers ask in the course of their study.The school’s authorities told TOI that the student was not beaten up and the allegations levelled by the father were false and baseless.“During the recess, the seven students cornered the victim and sought an explanation from him about his replies to the teachers’ questions. They told the victim that because of him the teachers scolded them,” the police said.Matters grew heated and a quarrel broke out among them. “In a fit of anger, the students abused the victim, then thrashed and kicked him. The FIR says one of the students pulled out a window curtain rod and attacked him. The other students gagged his mouth with the curtain and then beat him up, injuring him,” the police said.Investigating officer sub-inspector Abhijit Joagdand said they are recording the statement of the doctors treating the student, collecting his injury certificate and recording the statements of teachers and other students.“We will take a call on any action against the students who are 15-year-olds,” Joagdand added.The father said he took his son to three hospitals for treatment after the November 22 attack and filed a complaint with the school’s principal seeking action against the students who beat up his son but no action was taken even after several reminders.“When the school did not give me justice, I filed a complaint plea with the Pune police commissioner. The Wanworie police later called me and recorded my complaint,” he added.The school’s chairman told TOI that they took the boy to a private hospital immediately after he sustained injuries in school.“We inquired into the incident immediately and learned that the student had a fall after he was pushed by his classmates and fell unconscious. The student was not thrashed. We suspended all seven students involved in the incident for six days,” the chairman said.“The students and their parents parents were counselled for three days. We took an undertaking from them that they will not indulge in violent behaviour. We also counselled the injured student and his parents. We took action but I don’t know why the boy’s father has lodged an FIR against the students,” he added.

Title: Maharashtra: PCMC mops up barely 35 per cent of total water tax bill
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The civic body has till January 24 earned Rs34 crore in water tax as against the total bill of Rs94.78 crore.

Makrand Nikam, chief of the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation’s (PCMC) water supply department, said the civic body would soon launch a drive to recover the Rs60 crore arrears.

PCMC officials said the maximum amount of arrears Rs10.19 crore was from the Zone C comprising areas such as Chikhali, Moshi, Bhosari and parts of Pimpri. Water connection holders in Zone B (Chinchwad, Ravet, Kalewadi, Mamurdi and other areas) had to clear dues of Rs8.97 crore. The arrears in Zone A (Pimpri Camp, Akurdi gaothan, Chinchwad station and other areas) are to the tune of Rs8.63 crore. The officials said they have recovered the highest amount of water tax and arrears (Rs5.91 crore) from Zone B, followed by Zone C (Rs5.56 crore) and Zone A (Rs5.14 crore).

Nikam said, “A list of Top 10 defaulters of each zone will be prepared each month and submitted to the deputy engineers. The defaulters will be served a notice to clear the dues within seven days. If the arrears are not cleared by then, the water connections can be snapped.”

Title: Govt ‘confused’ on gas relief hike
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Bhopal: Ahead of Supreme Court constitutional bench hearing the curative petition for enhanced compensation for Bhopal gas victims, Madhya Pradesh government seems to be confused on its stand on the issue.

Bhopal gas relief and rehabilitation minister, Arif Aqueel said he is ‘unclear’ whether state government can provide supportive documentation pertaining to increase in number of deaths and injured, owing to the Bhopal gas disaster of 1984.

Confusion over the state’s stand comes at a time when enhanced compensation is being demanded by the NGOs as interveners in the case. It is pegged at USD 15 billion, at current exchange rates.

When contacted, state government officials did not clarify on what will be the increased number of dead and injured, 34 years after the Bhopal gas disaster.

On Tuesday, a five-judge bench headed by Justice Arun Mishra adjourned the hearing till Wednesday and said Chief Justice of India S A Bobde would take a call on composition of the bench to hear the matter. Supreme Court Judge Justice S Ravindra Bhat on Tuesday recused himself from hearing the Centre’s plea seeking Rs7,844 crore as additional fund from successor firms of US-based Union Carbide Corporation for giving compensation to the gas victims.

Five years after the world’s worst industrial disaster in 1989, GOI made an out-of-court settlement with Union Carbide Corporation of US$470 million or Rs713 crore at exchange rate of 1989. “Settlement was based on basis of assumption that there were 3,000 deaths and 20,000 injured. The magnitude of the disaster was grossly underestimated,” said Bhopal Gas Peedith Sangharsh Sahayog Samiti (BGPSS) co-convener ND Jayaprakash. Late Abdul Jabbar challenged the settlement between Union government and UCIL, and later it was converted into a curative petition.

“The number of deaths attributed to gas leak is about 20,000 and over 1.70 lakh are seriously injured,” he added.

“MP government is an intervener in this petition for enhanced compensation and justice for Bhopal gas victims. It is a chance to correct a historic wrong,” said gas activist, Rachna Dhingra.

“State government would infwsorm the court of accurate number of dead, owing to the disaster,” said Aqueel, after a meeting with officials including principal secretary Pallavi Govil. Enhanced compensation for gas affected and their dependents has been of the major poll promises of the Congress party. NGO activists have taken on the government and the chemical company (now Dow Chemicals) seeking rehabilitation and enhanced medical care compensation.

Going by MP government records number of cases awarded compensation as a result of injury or death due to the Bhopal gas leak are 5,74,366.

On January 8, 2012 then Madhya Pradesh chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan wrote to the PM seeking that as per records 15,342 people have died as a result of the disaster and there family members should all receive appropriate compensation in the category of death.

Title: All you need to know about Schengen VISA
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Amit Sharma, regional head of VFS Global, a visa facilitation firm that processes visa application in India for 50 governments and has 508 application centres in 17 cities, answered questions that often spring up in a traveller’s mind regarding visa application

Q. When seeking Schengen visa for multiple countries visits, to which country should one apply?

A. Application needs to be made to the country where one will spend the maximum number of days. Hence, if one plans to visit Italy, Germany and France with maximum number of days in Germany, then one needs to apply for Schengen visa from Germany although port of entry may be Italy and exit France. But if one spends equal number of days in all the countries, then the visa should be taken from the country where the port of entry is located

Q. How early should one apply for visa?

A. Most countries accept applications three months in advance. From February 2, Schengen that allows access to 26 countries in Europe will allow applications six months in advance. The time required to process the visa application and get back the passport may range from one working week (5 days) to three weeks (15 days). Between mid-March and July-end, the peak season for applications ahead of the summer break, it is best to apply for visa at least a month in advance

Q. What should one be careful of before applying for visa?

A. Go through the checklist of documents required for visa from the particular country and keep them ready for submission. Not only do documents vary from one country to another, the specification of passport photo (size and background colour) also varies. A mistake may lead to rejection of the application

Q. If one has taken a country’s visa that requires biometric enrollment or a Schengen visa, does one need to provide biometric yet again if travelling the next year?

A. If one travels to the same country or any one of the Schengen countries within 59 months or one month short of 5 years of the previous visit, one does not require to submit one’s biometric. That means, the visa application can be submitted by anyone and not necessarily the applicant

Q. If one’s visa application is rejected by a country, does that mean one can never travel there?

A. There is no restriction on making a fresh application to travel to the country. The rejection may happen due to several reasons, including the situation and circumstances at the time that may change when the person applies again. If there is query in the application inquiring if there has been a rejection of visa in the past, the correct answer needs to be furnished

Q. If a country rejects a visa application, will the visa fee be refunded?

A. Most countries do not refund visa fee. UK refunds application fee less an administrative fee

Q. Does availing specialised, prime time or premium service ensure early processing and expeditious issue of visa? Can a travel agent help in issue of visa?

A. No. The services offered by visa application centres are like premium lounge and allied offerings at an airport to different category of passengers who must wait to board the same plane. A travel agent can help file the visa form and arrange the documents but no one can influence the process, which is in the hands of the particular country’s consular staff. Any attempt to influence may actually lead to visa rejection

Title: K Chandrasekhar Rao: Telangana CM Chandrasekhar Rao seeks Rs 12,000 crore from finance panel
Content:
K Chandrasekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao has urged the 15th Finance Commission to allot an additional Rs 12,000 crore to Telangana this year. He said the state would badly require the funds to complete Kaleshwaram irrigation project and Mission Bhagiratha.In a two-page letter, the chief minister said Telangana has taken up irrigation and infrastructure projects under a mission mode and urged the Finance Commission to allot funds liberally. “Since Telangana and Gujarat have begun implementing the scheme of providing drinking water to every household, we asked the commission to allot funds. The Finance Commission has responded positively,” said finance minister T Harish Rao, who submitted the chief minister’s letter during the commission’s interaction with various states in Delhi on Tuesday.The chief minister also reminded Finance Commission chairman NK Singh how he had lauded the efforts of Telangana in the irrigation and infrastructure sectors. “The geographical terrain of Telangana is such that major rivers like Krishna and Godavari flow deep below ground level. Therefore, irrigation is possible only with multi-stage lift irrigation schemes, which require large-scale capital investments,” he said in the letter.KCR said Telangana had made Mission Kakatiya operational within a short period by investing Rs 80,000 crore. He said Telangana needs a substantial investment of Rs 1.5 lakh crore in the irrigation sector and recalled how Mission Bhagiratha is being lauded by other states.The operational and maintenance cost of lift irrigation projects is pegged at Rs 40,168 crore and for Mission Bhagiratha, it is Rs 12,772 crore. KCR said the Finance Commission should consider allocating funds so that state could complete works.Meanwhile, Harish said that when they asked the Finance Commission to hold its regional conference in Hyderabad, Singh had agreed immediately.

Title: Coronavirus alert in U’khand: Govt hosps cancel docs’ leaves
Content:
To combat the fatal disease, isolation wards have also been set up in various hospitals across the state

Dehradun/Nainital: With state government hospitals asked to be on alert against Coronavirus that has claimed several lives in China, leaves of doctors, para-medical staff and surveillance workers have been cancelled at several government medical facilities in state capital Dehradun , including Coronation Hospital and Gandhi Shatabdi Hospital. To combat the fatal disease, isolation wards have also been set up in various hospitals across the state, especially in districts that border Nepal and China.According to health department officials, Almora district hospital has kept 14 beds in its isolation ward, Chamoli district hospital has kept 18 beds, and Champawat district hospital has separated 16 beds for Coronavirus treatment. Government Doon Medical College and Hospital has arranged for a 30-bed isolation ward while in Nainital district, isolation wards have been set up in Dr Sushila Tiwari Hospital in Haldwani and BD Pandey Hospital in Nainital. Similarly, isolation wards have also been set up in the district hospitals of Pauri Garhwal, Rudraprayag, Tehri, Haridwar and Pithoragarh.“Special teams of police and health department have been prepared to check the tourist inflow at Banbasa-Tanakpur in Champawat, Dharchula-Baluwakot-Jaulajibi-Jhoolaghar-Nainisaini in Pithoragarh, Khatima-Pantnagar in Udham Singh Nagar, and Jollygrant Airport in Dehradun,” said Pankaj Kumar Pandey, secretary (in-charge) health.The official also added that if someone wants to share any information regarding a suspected patient, they can contact at integrated helpline number 104. The health directorate has also issued guidelines to all the hospital heads to organise awareness camps in hospitals for both staff and patients.On Tuesday, Gandhi Shatabdi Hospital organised a symposium on Coronavirus. Doctors and paramedics of the hospital were briefed about causes of the disease and how to tackle symptoms.Dr BC Ramola, chief medical superintendent of both Gandhi Shatabdi and Coronation Hospital, told TOI “We have asked the chief medical officer to provide us masks and other materials to sanitise the wards in case any virus-affected case comes to our hospitals. We have arranged for a six-bed isolation ward in Coronation Hospital and 24-bed ward in Gandhi Hospital."Meanwhile, Nainital’s chief medical officer (CMO) Dr Bharti Rana told TOI that an advisory has been issued to doctors in the region to handle the suspected cases with utmost care. "A meeting will be held with senior officials on Wednesday where we will decide on further course of action regarding this matter," Rana said.

Title: Coronavirus in Chennai: No facility at Chennai airport to handle infected flyers
Content:
Photo used for representational purpose only

CHENNAI: Chennai airport may be taking steps to screen passengers for coronavirus symptoms, but the airport lacks a well-equipped and isolated quarantine centre to handle people with infection.A plan which was floated to set up a quarantine and isolation centre outside the terminal during the Ebola breakout in 2014 has not materialised yet. Land has been identified near the airport terminals by Airports Authority of India (AAI) and Airport Health Organisation (APHO) under ministry of health and family welfare. But construction is yet to begin.The airport has now set up a quarantine room at the international arrival terminal to handle passengers who have influenza-like symptoms because coronavirus is spreading in China.The new building that was to come up near the terminal was supposed to accommodate Airport Health Organisation officials, isolation ward for infected passengers and a quarantine area to observe healthy passengers who need monitoring to find out if they would develop symptoms for infectious diseases (example for yellow fever).“The idea is that the building should be away from the main building and should not have common air conditioning or common sewage link,” said an official.Sources said the construction was stuck because APHO, which comes under ministry of health and family welfare, and AAI, which comes under ministry of civil aviation, are unclear about who should build it. Though it is meant for passengers at the airport, it will be run by APHO.“There are no cases of coronavirus yet. But if some passenger is found to be infected, they cannot be kept at the terminal for long because the air conditioning is common,” said an official.Dr Roshni Arthur senior regional director regional office of health and family welfare said, “Land has already been identified to build a centre for the airport. But it has not taken off because of some problems regarding construction. It is difficult to say when it can be completed. Now, we use Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital.”Passengers who come from countries with a risk of yellow fever without vaccination are sent to the quarantine facility at general hospital where they are observed for three to five days and are allowed to go if they do not develop symptoms.“There is a difference between quarantine centre and isolation centre. Quarantine is to keep the healthy people to see if they will develop symptoms like in the case of yellow fever while for coronavirus the need is for isolation of the passengers with symptoms,” Dr Roshni said.A quarantine facility is not needed for coronavirus because people with symptoms need to be isolated and a facility has been created at general hospital, she said.Airport director C V Deepak said, “The land was identified so that APHO office can be moved from the current location along with quarantine centre so that it can be taken up for development. They have to take a call on who should build and decision has to be taken at the ministry level. If the health ministry decides that we should build then the ministry of civil aviation needs to decide.”

Title: Senior citizen duped of Rs 43,000 at Valpoi
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

VALPOI: A senior citizen was allegedly duped of Rs 43,000 by some unidentified person who, he claimed, swiped his debit card at an ATM and withdrew money from his bank account late Sunday night.

In his complaint to the Valpoi police, Dilip Karpe said some unidentified persons allegedly made five transactions and withdrew Rs 43,000 from the savings account he holds at a scheduled bank in Valpoi. He said he learnt of the incident the next day, when he attempted to make payment with his card at a supermarket and found that he had insufficient funds.

Karpe rushed to the bank and found that five unauthorised withdrawals were made from his account through an ATM three transactions of Rs 10,000 each, one of Rs 8,000 and another of Rs 5,000.

Title: NIA will get Elgar case papers after DGP’s order: Pune police
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Pune: A senior officer of the city police on Tuesday said they were waiting for directives from the office of the director-general of police before taking a call on handing over the investigation papers of the Elgar Parishad case to the National Investigation Agency.

On Monday, a team of the National Investigation Agency (NIA) had visited senior officers at the Pune police commissionerate in the wake of the Union home ministry’s order on January 24, transferring further probe into the Elgar case to the NIA.

“The NIA officials sought to give us a letter requesting handing over of the case papers to them, but we could not accept it, nor did we hand over the case papers to them as we are waiting for specific directives in this matter from the DGP (director-general of police (DGP)’s office,” the city police officer told reporters with a request not to quote him.

“Normally, letters which order transfer of sensitive cases from one agency to another, ought to be routed through proper and legal channels. For instance, the transfer happens only when there are orders from the DGP’s office or from the court. We shall hand over the case papers to the NIA on the receipt of directives from the DGP’s office and we expect this to happen soon,” he said.

The officer said, “The NIA officials were allowed to see the documents related to the case which are already in public domain. These included the FIRs and the two chargesheets filed so far in the court, among other papers. Apart from these documents, nothing else was shown to the NIA officials. We cannot share the sensitive information, which is still with the police.”

Title: Gehlot to open khadi event as govt seeks to push sector
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Jaipur: The humble khadi may not have the same global appeal as its patron who saw it as a symbol of strength and self-reliance, creating a contemporary story for the iconic fabric would be a topic for the frontline designers from India, UK, Japan and other countries at an event to be held for marking the 150th anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi.

While lack of branding, designing that is fashionable to the youth, capacity building for increasing production volume and incentives to make the products cheaper is attributed to khadi losing out to competition, the fallout has also not helped the rural artisans and workers engaged in the sector.

Additional chief secretary, Industries, Subodh Agarwal said the two-day international conference will seek to address these challenges. “There is a sense of urgency for addressing issues of poverty eradication, community empowerment, social justice, gender equality and environmental concerns. Discussions will revolve around production capacity, quality designing, export potential, employment and livelihood at the conference,” said Agarwal about the two-day event that starts from January 30.

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot, whose government extended 50% discount on khadi products as part of its celebrations of 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi’s, will inaugurate the event. Anand Mishra, chairman of CII-Rajasthan, said, “More than 250 delegates have already registered, out of which more than 150 are from out of Jaipur.” Issues like ethical and sustainable fashion concept, natural organic fibers, innovation and new technology will be subjects of main discussion during the event. Stakeholder groups like international agencies, corporates, and representatives from NGOs will participate in the conference.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Three-member team at Gandhi Medical College to deal with Coronavirus scare
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: Madhya Pradesh health department only took the swab sample for the deadly Coronavirus suspected patient admitted at a hospital in Ujjain, admitted CMHO Ujjain Dr Mahavir Khadelwal.As per ICMR and Union ministry of health protocol, clinical specimens of tissue sampling from lungs and two serum samples should also be sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune.Dr Khandewal was in Bhopal in a meeting with top health department officials, including MP health commissioner Prateek Hajela. Specimen collection, packaging and transport guidelines for 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) were issued by the ICMR and Union ministry of health on January 20.The result of the swab sample with symptoms of the deadly strain that has killed over 100 people worldwide is expected in 15 to 20 days, said Dr Khandewal. The suspected patient was studying MBBS in China. He is expected to be in quarantine till NIV Pune responds.Meanwhile, a three-member team to deal with Coronavirus was formed at the Gandhi Medical College (GMC) here on Tuesday. It includes, GMC associate professor, department of pulmonology, Dr Parag Sharma, Dr RK Jain and Dr Nikunj Agrawal.“Protocols are in place for anyone with symptoms of sore throat, cough and high-grade fever. Breathlessness is serious condition. It is for anyone who has recently visited China and anyone who came in contact with anyone who travelled to China in the last 15 days,” said Dr Sharma.A five-bed quarantine facility for management of suspected Coronavirus strain has also been established in the GMC.

Title: 23-year-old theft case accused stabs friend
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: An accused in theft cases attacked his associate with a knife at Film Nagar basthi on Tuesday during an argument over a cellphone. The accused, Irshad, 23, was taken into custody and an attempt to murder case registered against him. Irshad and his friend Ravinder met at their residences and soon entered into a heated argument over the phone.

“In a fit of rage, Irshad attacked Ravinder on his neck with the knife. Family members and neighbours rushed Ravinder to a hospital where he is out of danger,” Banjara Hills inspector N Kalinga Rao said. Police said the duo has a criminal record. Both are accused in cellphone and two-wheeler theft cases registered at Banjara Hills, Jubilee Hills, Raidurgam and Narsingi police stations.

A few days ago, during the birthday celebrations of Ravinder, Irshad took his friend’s cellphone without informing anyone. Later, Ravinder realised that the phone was at Irshad’s home.

“Ravinder went to Irshad’s house and took the phone from his mother. Later, Ravinder and his friends roughed up Irshad accusing him of trying to steal the phone,” Rao said.

Title: Government to set up task force to ease foreign students’ visa issues: HRD minister Ramesh Pokhriyal
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

HRD minister Ramesh Pokhriyal ‘Nishank’ (left) inaugurates the national conference on Destination India on Sym... Read More

PUNE: The government will set up a task force to ease the foreign students ’ visa issues , said HRD minister Ramesh Pokhriyal ‘Nishank’ on Tuesday.

The task force would be set up by the ministry of human resource development (HRD) with the ministry of external affairs and officials of the University Grants Commission and Indian Council of Cultural Relations (ICCR), he said.

Pokhriyal was in the city to inaugurate the two-day conference “Destination India”, aimed to develop a road map for the country to attract more foreign students. The ICCR, in collaboration with Symbiosis International and Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU), is conducting the conference at Symbiosis International’s Lavale campus.

Pokhriyal spoke about the country’s “soft power” — ayurveda, yoga, classical dance and music, Indian literature, among others — and called for promoting it to attract foreign students.

Vinay Sahasrabuddhe, the president of the ICCR, spoke about various avenues to be explored if India wanted foreign students to choose it as a favourite destination. He said there was a need to strengthen the network of international students passing out of the Indian universities. Even making sure they got the food they prefer in the Indian universities would go a long way in attracting them, he said.

“We should look at standardizing traditional Indian knowledge systems (TIKS) such as Bharatnatyam, yoga and ayurveda, and allow easy access to students seeking them,” Sahasrabuddhe said. He also said there was need for an English test for students seeking admission in India with preparatory classes in Indian embassies abroad and at ICCR.

The director-general of ICCR Akhilesh Mishra spoke about the need to make the “Indian experience” an asset and emphasized on the importance of creating better infrastructure to attract more international students.

The secretary of UGC, Rajneesh Jain, spoke about enhancing collaborations with universities overseas.

SB Mujumdar, founder and president of the Symbiosis Society , Nitin Karmalkar, vice-chancellor of SPPU, and Anil Sahasrabudhe, chairman of All India Council for Technical Education, among others were present at the ceremony.

Title: Maharashtra: Law student held on charge of molesting friend in flat
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

Title: Organ donation goof-up: Family demands probe, plants saplings in memory of deceased
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Bhopal: The family of 10-year-old Mayank Chhawani, whose mother’s body could not be used for cadaveric organ donation, is demanding a thorough investigation into the goof-up at Gandhi Medical College (GMC).

“I would have been more proud if other organs (heart, lung, liver and kidneys) of my mother’s body could have benefited others. Only her eyes would give sight to others,” said Mayank, a class 5 student with tears of pride in his eyes. He had lost his father when he was three-and-a-half-years-old.

On Tuesday, Mayank and his family members planted saplings in Bairagarh, also putting the ashes of his deceased mother in the soil. “When the trees provide green cover and give fresh air to all, it will remind me of my mother,” he said. The family planted saplings of Neem, Tulsi, Mango, Sheemshan and Asoka. Mayank’s mother was holding the holy Tulsi plant in her hand when she met with an accident on the BRTS bus stop in Halalpur on January 23.

“The loss of his mother and the organ donation fiasco has moved Mayank immensely. I am not sure what is going on in his mind. He wants to serve the society. I only want to be his guide,” said his uncle and lawyer, Jadgish Chhawani. He did not rule out seeking intervention in the matter from the Prime Minister’s Office, National Organ and Tissue Transplant Organisation and other agencies.

“Government hospitals should be at the forefront of organ donation. At the time, my sister-in-law was in hospital, there were eight head injury patients. Two of them died. Their relatives could be convinced about organ donation too,” said Chhawani. The harrowing experience of the past week has left him deeply disappointed.

The deceased was considered fit for organ donation. However, the body was declared unfit for organ donation within a matter of hours. Interestingly, a private hospital’s final report stated that the patient was ‘declared brain dead in Hamidia hospital surgical ICU at 5 pm on January 25’. In the same page, it notes that the ‘patient underwent cardiac arrest at 8.42 am on January 26’. A post-mortem and funeral soon after, considered highly unusual on a national holiday.

“I agree with the contentions raised. I would seek an explanation from authorities concerned,” said GMC dean, Dr Aditya Agarwal.

Sheo Shekar Shukla, principal secretary of the Directorate of Medical Education (DME), said, “I am in Delhi and would reply after looking into the matter.”

Two days after the goof-up, the DME or GMC are yet to issue showcause notices to the doctors involved.

Title: Ninder farmers give 2 more proposals on relief to JDA
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Jaipur: The affected land owners of Ninder scheme on Tuesday submitted two more proposals to provide compensation to the Jaipur Development Authority (JDA). In a meeting, the farmers demanded that the authority should either provide compensation as per Land Acquisition Act, 2013 or as per two other fresh proposals.

As per the first proposal, the farmers urged that government should provide lease deed of the 25% developed land only after charging Rs 1 token fee. This land will be provided in the new scheme (which will be developed by JDA) as a compensation for acquiring their land. The farmers demanded cash compensation of Rs 2,250 per square metre for remaining 75% land.

The second proposal of the farmers says, if the JDA is not willing to provide cash compensation of Rs 2,250 square metre, it should develop 35% land in the scheme. Moreover, it should provide Rs 1,650 per square metre as a cash compensation for remaining 65%.

Samiti coordinator Nagendra Singh said, “We are not adamant and have given JDA all the options. Now, JDA has no option to refuse to the farmers demand,” he said. According to JDA records, a housing scheme is proposed on 327 hectares. Till date, approximately 204 hectares have been surrendered by farmers, while possession of 123 hectares are yet to be taken by the civic body.

A senior JDA official said, “The process of acquisition of land has already been completed. Directions will be sought from the state government on providing the compensation,” he said.

Title: Mayem locals press for railway station at Vaiginim
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

BICHOLIM: Villagers of Mayem on Tuesday urged officials of the Konkan Railway Corporation ( KRC ) to begin construction of a railway station at Shiran-Vaiginim. The request was made when the officials visited the constituency to help arrive at solutions to the issues people have been facing.

The KRC had, in 2015, proposed to set up a railway station at Mayem. The move was touted to boost tourism to spots like Mayem lake and Saptakoteshwar temple by making them accessible.

Tuesday’s discussions also focused on constructing an overbridge with a pedestrian lane at Haldanwadi, making crossing facilities available at two different spots in Shirgao, providing employment to the local youth and helping farmers who own fields at Narvem and Shirgao.

Title: Maharashtra: Booty worth Rs 39.5 lakh burgled from row house in Chikhali
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Leaving his house empty around the Republic Day weekend cost a man dearly.

Burglars broke into Kalpesh Anphalkar’s (29) row house at Manas Crest Society in Chikhali Pradhikaran and decamped with Rs10 lakh and 710g gold ornaments, totally worth Rs39.5 lakh, between January 23 and 26.

Sub-inspector SP Deshmukh of the Chikhali police said Anphalkar owned a manufacturing unit of engineering parts in Pimpri Chinchwad . “On January 23, he had gone to Bengaluru with some work. His wife had shifted to her parents’ house after childbirth. Anphalkar’s mother, too, had gone to Aurangabad ,” Deshmukh said.

When Anphalkar’s domestic help went to the house on the morning of January 26, she came across broken locks on the main door and alerted him.

Deshmukh said the complainant told the police that he had kept Rs10 lakh in his house to buy some machinery for his business. “The house did not have any safety door or CCTV cameras,” Deshmukh said.

The police suspect that the burglars had conducted a recce before burgling the place.

Cash, laptops stolen in Nigdi

A 70-year-old woman from Nigdi has lodged an FIR with the Dehu Road police stating that burglars broke into her house on Monday and stole Rs43,000, two laptops, two cameras and a wrist watch, collectively worth Rs82,000, when she was not at home.

Title: Juhu resident back from Wuhan, epicentre of novel Coronavirus, quarantined
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: A Juhu resident with a travel history to Wuhan, the Chinese city that is believed to be the starting point of the novel Coronavirus (nCov) outbreak, was quarantined at Kasturba Hospital, Chinchpokli, on Tuesday. A total of nine patients, including five in Mumbai, three in Pune and one in Nanded, are under isolation across hospitals in the state. Overall, 18 travellers in Maharashtra are under observation.Sources said the 49-year-old Juhu man was in Wuhan between January 14 and 20. He returned to Mumbai on January 21 and is believed to have been symptom-free. He developed fever and cough on January 24, though. On Tuesday, his relatives said he had travelled to the Chinese city for business. “We didn’t want to take chances, so we brought him here. We are sure he doesn’t have the infection or any symptoms resembling it,” said a relative, refusing to comment further.State officials said the man’s samples have been sent for tests to Pune’s National Institute of Virology (NIV). “We will be carrying out more tests locally to study a lung patch. Overall, his condition is stable,” said an official.Civic officials have confirmed of the five patients currently hospitalised at Kasturba, four have tested negative for the virus in the first round of tests. The four, though, including a 31-year-old Nalasopara woman, a 36-year-old Kalyan man, a 65-year-old British national and a 36-year-old Tardeo resident, will be discharged if the second set of tests is negative too. Some reports are expected on Wednesday. Travellers will be under observation for 28 days.State officials said a 51-year-old and a 30-year-old are among the three isolated at Pune’s Naidu Infectious Diseases Hospital. The 30-year-old had travelled to areas close to Wuhan but is currently not showing significant symptoms. TOI has learnt both have tested negative for the virus in the first round of tests. The sole person quarantined in Nanded is a 50-year-old man, kept in isolation at the Government Medical College.Nearly 4,000 travellers arriving from China have been screened at Mumbai’s Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (CSMIA).“We are following up with the 18 travellers daily telephonically. We have told them to self-report in case they develop any symptoms,” said Dr Pradeep Awate, the state’s epidemiologist.Meanwhile, the union health ministry tweeted that four more laboratories at Alleppey, Bengaluru, Hyderabad and Mumbai will be activated to test samples in addition to Pune’s NIV that is processing all the samples now. State officials said the lab gives the reports in less than 24 hours.
