Title: Leopard’s body recovered from Junnar well
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: The body of a 10-year-old male leopard was recovered from a well in Khamundi village near Otur in Junnar taluka on Tuesday morning.

Yogesh Ghodake, range forest officer (RFO), Otur, said that the leopard probably fell into the well with no protective wall while chasing a prey around two days ago. Its body was bloated, he said.

A post-mortem was conducted at Udapur nursery after which the leopard was cremated, he said.

SS Khunte, round officer, Otur range, said, “Khamundi village is around 6-7 km from Otur. Villagers informed us around 9.45 am that a body of a leopard was floating in the well of a farm belonging to Subhash Bodake and Anil Bodake. A forest department team reached the village around 10.30 am and brought it out.”

Title: Understanding complex legacy of Periyar
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

CHENNAI: Burning of Rama portraits took place in 1956, and continued even after 1971.

It is more than 46 years since the passing of Erode Venkatappa Ramasamy, later known as EVR and Periyar , yet he continues to dominate Tamil Nadu’s political space.

The controversy stoked by actor Rajinikanth’s recent reference to the 1971 anti-superstition conference in Salem of the Periyar-led Dravidar Kazhagam (DK) has not died even after a fortnight as some AIADMK ministers have entered the fray asking Rajinikanth to tender an apology for trying to discredit Periyar.

Such has been the extent of Periyar’s dominance that any party that claims to have a Dravidian tag has to defend him, even while distancing itself from an indefensible act like burning of Rama’s portrait. While Dravidian parties concede that it was morally wrong to burn images or portraits of Rama, Sita and Lakshmana as Periyar and his supporters sought to do right from the 1950s, they want to be politically correct to be seen as Periyar supporters, since he founded the Dravidian, social reform movement and enabled the DMK and the AIADMK to come to power.

Periyar’s diatribe against brahmins could have resulted in the movement towards a casteless society going off on a tangent, but he had a creditable record of having fought for women’s rights, including the right to property, widow marriage, self-respect and intercaste marriages, rights for entry of dalits, Tamil archakas and Tamil mantras in temples, reservation in educational institutions and government jobs. As Periyarists would like to say, let us not throw out the baby with the dish water.

What is surprising, however, is the lack of awareness about Periyar and DK’s acts of burning portraits or effigies of the Hindu gods. The 1971 Salem incident was not the first nor was it the last. While some rationalists, seen as Periyarists, have sounded almost defensive on the issue, Periyar himself had made no bones about it. The act of burning Rama pictures by Periyar was to celebrate Ravana Leela to counter the Ram Leela in Delhi during the Dussehra festival, his argument being that Ramayana sought to perpetuate the Aryan domination over Dravidian ‘sudran’, Ravana of Tamil origin.

Earlier, in 1953, Periyar organised agitations for the desecration of Ganesha idols. He had said in a speech in 1953, "We have to eradicate the gods who are responsible for the institution which portrays us as sudras, people of low birth, and some others as brahmins of high birth... We have to break the idols of these gods. I start with Ganesha because it is he who is worshipped before undertaking any task." In 1956, Periyar publicly announced an agitation to burn pictures of Rama on the Marina beach. Paula Richman, in ‘The Diversity of a Narrative Tradition in South Asia’ (Chapter 9: E.V. Ramasami’s Reading of the Ramayana) described in detail the events leading up to the burning of Rama’s pictures.

"On the first day of August in 1956, E. V. Ramasami (henceforth E.V.R.) set out for the Madras Marina to lead his followers in burning pictures of Lord Rama, hero of the Ramayana. This symbolic action would represent a reversal of the culmination of north Indian performances of the Ramayana, in which images of the epic’s villain, Ravana, are put to the flames as spectators watch in delight." The account goes on to detail how political leaders implored Periyar to cancel the event so as not to offend orthodox Hindu Tamils, but Periyar remained unmoved, noting that "there was bound to be a difference of views regarding any measure aimed at bringing social reform". On the following day, the deputy commissioner of police arrested Periyar when he was stepped out of his house to head to Marina. Periyar seemed prepared for this eventuality, in addition to the picture of Rama and a box of matches, he was carrying a bedroll to spread on the hard prison floor.

In 1971, Ravana Leela was a fixture at the Salem conference. This was published in detail by the DK daily, ‘Viduthalai’, which was not only unapologetic, but also hailed the burning as a celebration by more than two lakh Tamils assembled there. After his death, Maniyammai, who took over the DK leadership, and her associates, were arrested for burning effigies of Rama, Sita and Lakshmana to re-enact the Ravana Leela at the DK headquarters, Periyar Thidal, in 1974.

In an article on Periyar, Cho Ramaswamy had said, "There was no shade of hypocrisy in him (Periyar) and he never attempted sophistry while propounding his social philosophy." The former Tughlak editor added that though EVR is still hailed as one of the leaders of the Tamil people, his philosophy is hardly valued. He fought superstitions, but his followers in the AIADMK tonsured their heads for the good health of their former leader J Jayalalithaa; he cursed the caste, now offshoots of his movement — the DMK and the AIADMK — are using caste politics to fight elections, and more caste-based parties have come up in Tamil Nadu; he was the apostle of secession, but his followers swear allegiance to national integration. Cho aptly surmised the idea of the man, saying, "Periyar the singer was admired, his song was ignored. As a man Periyar was the embodiment of civility, which is why he is still loved. The man was greater than his message." That’s something that ought to be remembered now.

(The writer is a veteran journalist)

Title: Metro worker held for theft
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Pune: The Shivajinagar police have arrested a Metro worker for stealing a projector and a laptop worth Rs1.06 lakh from the office of a company in Shivajinagar on Sunday.

The arrest was made after an office-bearer lodged a complaint, claiming that the theft occurred during the night intervening Saturday and Sunday.

“A patrol team spotted the suspect carrying two bags. When he failed to answer their questions, he was brought to the police station, where he admitted to the theft,” sub-inspector Shesh More said.

Title: Industry seeks clarity on electric vehicle roadmap, Telangana says you can drive in straightaway with plans
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Nepal will replace China-made e-ricks with ones made in Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: The absence of a dedicated electric vehicle (EV) policy to rev up demand and the lack of charging infrastructure is marring the growth of EVs in Telangana , rued industry players. However, the state government said that despite not having a policy, it has guidelines in place and has been receptive of companies willing to invest in Telangana.

“We were very bullish on Hyderabad as it is a very large two-wheeler and three-wheeler market but nothing much has happened in the last one year as there is no clear policy framework. In fact, we wanted to promote our three wheeler EVs for last mile connectivity for metro passengers but could not make much headway. However, in other states like Delhi, we have 1,000 vehicles running… we have our e-ricks running in Kochi and Nagpur as well but we don’t find the support here,” Kinetic Green founder and CEO Sulajja Firodia Motwani said.

She pointed out that though Telangana had announced the setting up of a dedicated park for EV manufacturing it has failed to attract players as the demand for EVs is yet to pick up in the state. Her company has sold around 300 units in the state compared to 3,500 in AP, 10,000 in UP and around 3,000 in Bihar.

While the lack of policy is deterring buyers, Michael Liu, chairman, Dao EVTech, said the Telangana government should also abolish road tax on EVs like Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka. “Telangana state does not have ancillary units supporting electric vehicle manufacturers, so the government should give EV companies more incentives/ subsidies to set up manufacturing facilities,” he added.

Dao EVTech is currently setting up a 4000 square meters facility on the outskirts of Hyderabad and is in talks with the Andhra Pradesh government to set up a bigger manufacturing plant as AP has a favourable policy towards EV manufacturers.

While industry leaders have high expectations from the state, industries & IT principal secretary Jayesh Ranjan pointed out that the state government has guidelines in place and has been able to attract four battery manufacturers in the state and is also hopeful of clinching two mega deals by OEMs in the coming days. He also added that many startups working in the EV space have thrived in the city and are driving innovation.

While challenges remain, Arun Sreyas, founder, RACEnergy, points out that a large network of public transport and last mile connectivity options in Telangana provide an opportunity for electrification of mobility in scale. “Ranked second in the country in installed solar power capacity, the state also offers added opportunity to make EVs cheaper and cleaner,” he said.

He points out that the cost of EVs remains high primarily because of the high cost of the battery. RACEnergy has set-up an R&D facility and prototyping lab in Hyderabad and will be launching pilots in the near-term. “For commercial vehicles, the problem of lack of infrastructure is compounded as the drivers do not want to wait to charge their vehicles. Also, a vast network of public charging infrastructure is required to cover widespread areas of cities in Telangana,” he said.

Title: Soon, mandatory cyber security course for all JNTU students
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Jayesh Ranjan

HYDERABAD: It will soon be mandatory for students of JNTU to study a module on cyber security , regardless of their stream and course, said Jayesh Ranjan , principal secretary (IT).

Ranjan made the announcement after inaugurating cyber security Centre of Excellence (CCoE), a joint initiative of the Government of Telangana and Data Security Council of India (DSCI) at Manjeera Trinity Corporate on Tuesday.

“The modules on cyber security will be mandatory for all students in the 300 plus colleges affiliated with JNTU, regardless of the course or stream (including management or pharmacy). This will help them understand security concerns and have an idea about basic cyber hygiene,” said Jayesh Ranjan.

The module will be introduced by this academic year, he further added. “We are planning to introduce it to students from the second or third year. The marks of the module will not be added to the final score, but it is mandatory to pass the test. Teachers will also have to undergo training and tests,” Ranjan said.

Speaking about CCoE, Rajendra Pawar, Founder and Chairman, NIIT Group said that it has been set up with the objective to create awareness about the cyber security ecosystem. The centre will also focus on the rising threats of Cybercrime and the need for cyber security. “The centre is equipped with an incubation centre for start-ups, an experience zone, and a training centre which will aim at providing a conducive cyber security ecosystem in the city,” he said.

The 6,000 square feet facility will serve as the epicentre of cyber security development in Telangana. The centre will have a training room, a 30-seater incubation zone. This centre will propel cyber security innovation and product development.

Speaking on the occasion, Rama Vedashree , Chief Executive officer, DSCI, said, “We are grateful to the government of Telangana for their support in establishing a CoE and helping us collaborate with stakeholders to uplift cyber security ecosystem. We partner closely with the government to build entrepreneurs that will impact the future of cyber security.”

Title: Doodling takes city artist to prestigious Google calendar
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Rasika Barla’s artwork with the theme ‘Digital well-being’ features in Google’s 2020 calendar

Nagpur: Little did Rasika know that her love for doodling and drawing artistic graphics will lead to being featured in Google’s annual calendar. Rasika Barla ’s artwork shares space with 11 other artists in Google’s annual calendar for 2020 with the theme ‘Digital well being’.

Google’s theme aimed to bring technology and art together to help people establishing digital well-being. Google collaborated with 12 selected artists across India, and Rasika was one of them.

Rasika, who specializes in the most intricate hand-drawn doodle art with a real sense of depth and art journaling, was one of the few people selected. Doodle art is a creative and fun way of expressing emotions and situations, which catches the fancy of many and is shared actively on social media platforms. Despite all the buzz, it still remains an underrated form of art.

Rasika's work offers an array of numerous, beautiful, black and white, and colour-filled doodles, all of which can be found in her awe-inspiring Instagram portfolio. She enjoys graphic design and illustration, and has made a name for herself with her series of flat lays and doodled notes from art session talks that add a fantastic visual element to boring old note-taking.

She has turned a collection of sketch notes into powerful journals. Expressing her thoughts about her art, she said, “The brief was to depict the idea of digital well being and creating a concept of playing with ideas. It is a rare opportunity to be given a free rein on such a brilliant canvas.”

All of her doodles are work of mind and hand, and some applications, which come handy, “The doodles were all hand-drawn, then scanned in, edited and composited in Photoshop.”

Rasika has collaborated with various artists and constantly worked towards growing the art quotient of Nagpur, conducting various art jamming sessions and workshops on doodling, art journaling etc.

Sharing her thoughts and happiness on being featured in Google Calendar, she said, “I am glad and extremely happy about the achievement. Art journal is an important part of my life and a place for creative expression.”

She stressed on the fact that spontaneous art acts as a mirror to our inner world and can help you to express, release, see, and heal your emotional pain.

Title: No mining activity found at Shirgao
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

BICHOLIM: Acting on the directions of the Bicholim deputy collector, Bicholim mamlatdar Pravinjay Pandit on Tuesday inspected a site at Mayem-Shirgao after locals complained that a mining firm had begun excavation there.

During the inspection, it was observed that no illegal mining or extraction had been undertaken and that only iron ore that had been purchased during e-auction was being transported.

Title: Hyderabad ICMR lab among four across India to detect novel Coronavirus
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: The Union ministry of health and family welfare on Tuesday announced that testing for the dreaded Novel Corona Virus (2019-nCoV) will begin at the ICMR lab in Hyderabad and at three other places in the country. In fact, several suspected cases of the virus which has now spread to at least six countries, have been reported in Hyderabad city.

The samples are being sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) Pune. In a bid to cut out the time and hassle of transporting the samples (likely to have the highly contagious virus) the decision has been taken. The ICMR lab in Hyderabad, located in the Gandhi Medical College at Secunderabad, is biosafety level four lab which is the highest level and at par with the NIV lab.

ICMR has 10 labs in the country. The labs are only used for research and are not used for testing samples even in case of outbreaks. “The plan is to prepare it in 7-10 days for testing of samples. Since many suspected cases are being reported, the sample load is expected to increase,” said Dr K Shankar, director Institute of Preventive Medicine (IPM), Meanwhile, Hyderabad has a Biosafety Level 2 lab at the Institute of Preventive Medicine (IPM) where tests for Swine flu are currently done but the lab is not prepared as yet to do tests for more contagious viruses. It is currently stuck in an upgradation process.

Title: Caught with Rs 50,000 illegal wood, offender attacks forest staff
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

The vehicle carried 47 logs of khair wood of one cubic metre volume

PANAJI: There was high drama in Virdi, Sakhali, on Saturday night, after a man who was nabbed by forest guards for illegally transporting khair wood first tried to burn his vehicle and himself and then attempted to attack the forest guards with a knife.

Prahlad Chari, a resident of Virdi, was chased by three forest guards in the Keri range including Surla beat guard Shekhar Gawas after they received information that he was scheduled to transport illegally cut khair logs from Surla-Keri to Virdi. Upon intercepting him, they found that Chari did not have valid permissions for cutting and transporting the logs, which were estimated to be worth Rs 50,000.

Realising that he was cornered, Chari tried to first set his vehicle on fire and then immolate himself. Both attempts were foiled by the forest guards.

“Finding no way to escape, the offender attacked the forest personnel on duty with a sharp knife. The forest guards, however, thwarted his attempts and with assistance from the Bicholim police, nabbed him and took him into custody,” an official said.

Chari was subsequently booked by the range forest office at Keri for the illegal cutting and transportation of khair wood. An FIR for attempt to murder was also lodged against him.

Around 47 logs of khair wood having a volume of one cubic metre were seized together with the vehicle used to transport them.

“The seized khair wood has a market value of around Rs 50,000. More recovery of wood from the offender is anticipated as he has hidden the same at different places,” the official said.

Khair wood has substantial market value in Maharashtra’s Sawantwadi taluka as it is used in the preparation of ‘kattha’. The forest department has carried out similar seizures in the past.

Title: India most cyber-attacked country: Expert
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Hyderabad: India is the most cyber-attacked country, said Lt. General Rajesh Pant, chief, National Cyber Security Coordinator. “Because of the population and presence of over 500 million internet users, India is bound to be the most attacked country in terms of cyber attacks,” he said.

Stressing on increasing number of cybercrime cases, he said the Ministry of Home Affairs had introduced a cybercrime portal to register complaints (cybercrime.gov.in)

“Over 90 per cent of cybercrimes are mobile-related crimes. Bangalore alone records over 1 lakh complaints through the portal every month,” he said, adding that detection of cyber crime and conviction still remains in nascent stages. TNN

Title: Central universities suppressing our voice, allege Hyderabad students
Content:
Police detain UoH students protesting on campus against the CAA on account of Republic Day on Sunday

HYDERABAD: With constant monitoring of student movements and by issuing regular warnings to those participating in protests , the central universities located in the state are said to be suppressing the voices of students against CAA, NRC, and NPR or any other issue.While students of English and Foreign Languages University (EFLU), who organised a protest programme on Monday on the campus, said they were warned that they will be thrown out of the hostel if they take part in the programme. Same is the case with University of Hyderabad (UoH) students, who have been asked to take prior permission to organise public meetings.“We have organised a protest programme in the form of canvass painting event, where students can come and paint slogans to show their dissent. The administration immediately asked us to stop our protest. We were even threatened that protesters will be asked to vacate the hostel,” said an EFLU student, adding they are constantly being monitored.Students said that the university is stopping them from organising any kind of protests after Union human resource development minister, Ramesh Pokhriyal, said that the Centre will not tolerate universities becoming political hubs. UoH students, too, said that the administration is trying to snatch the democratic rights of students by abstaining them from organising public meetings without prior permission.“Every other day, the administration is releasing new circulars,” said Abhishek Nandan, president, student union, UoH. “They are asking us not to organise any protest programmes, and take prior permissions. Even today, there is a new circular saying that we can hold protests, dharnas, or marches only at Gurubakksh Singh Maidan or open air auditorium. They are just trying to snatch our democratic rights.”While EFLU administration said they are only asking students to follow ‘ordinance 61-rules of discipline-students’, UoH said that they are only asking students to organise protests in a democratic and peaceful manner.“The ordinance has been there since 2016,” said E Suresh Kumar, vice-chancellor, EFLU. “We have uploaded it recently on the website. Maybe, that’s why students are assuming that these are new rules.”Vinod Pavarala, UoH spokesperson, said that they had to release a circular saying that students can’t organise protests after 9pm as they are disturbing others on the campus.

Title: Create awareness on novel Coronavirus: Expert team
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: The three-member expert team from New Delhi, which visited the state-run Fever Hospital on Tuesday to inspect the preparedness to deal with a possible outbreak of the Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV), made suggestions to improve awareness about the virus among hospital staff, particularly the ones likely to deal with nCoV patients in case of an outbreak.The team, including Dr Shubha Garg, Dr Anitha Varma and professor Ajay Chauhan, along with director of Airport Health Organisation Hyderabad, Dr Anuradha Meduju, inspected the 40-bed isolation facility set up for patients with symptoms of Novel Coronavirus, hospital plan and the virology laboratory.The team interacted with hospital staff and took notes on how samples were being taken, availability and use of safety gear and sample sending procedure among others. The team also spoke to patients from the city, who were at the isolation ward on Tuesday.“While the expert team consisting of a general medicine expert, a microbiologist and an epidemiologist was largely satisfied with the arrangements here, they also made some suggestions,” said Dr K Shankar, superintendent Fever Hospital.“The suggestions included improving awareness among the staff in the isolation ward and emergency departments (on handling outbreaks) as they found a few staff members to be unaware of the issue. We will educated them as per the suggestion. Proper maintenance of charts and special training for washing and disposing area have been suggested. After a meeting with the state authorities, we will rectify these problems as per the directions of the government.”Dr Meduju said that two review meetings were held in Hyderabad, which discussed end-to-end preparedness for management of 2019-nCoV at the airport, thermal screening process, transportation of patients and the hospital facility. One meeting was with the state health authorities (including health secretary Shanti Kumari), and another at Fever Hospital to understand the state’s preparedness in dealing with an nCoV outbreak.

Title: After EC nod, DDA to restart giving property papers in illegal colonies
Content:
The agency has also set up 25 help desks to help the applicants

NEW DELHI: Delhi Development Authority will resume the process of providing conveyance deeds and registration papers for unauthorised colony properties following a clarification from the Election Commission on the implementation of model code of conduct.After 20 residents of Raja Vihar and Suraj Park, two unauthorised colonies in north Delhi, were provided these documents under the Pradhan Mantri Unauthorised Colonies in Delhi Awas Adhikar Yojana (PM-UDAY) on January 3, DDA had stopped the process as the model code of conduct for the February 8 assembly polls came into effect.According to a DDA source, it has now received a clarification from ECI that the regularisation process can be carried out for those who registered on the central agency’s portal before January 6, when the election dates were announced. The number of eligible people is around 80,000. So far, 1.97 lakh property owners in Delhi’s 1,731 unauthorised colonies have registered on DDA’s web portal for getting the ownership rights, he added.An official said over 4,000 applications with complete documents had been uploaded on the portal, out of which geo-coordinates and site mapping of around 300 properties had been completed.In October 2019, the Union Cabinet approved a proposal to grant ownership rights to the residents of 1,731 unauthorised colonies in Delhi under PM-UDAY. The agency then uploaded the boundaries of these unauthorised colonies on its website for the purpose of delineation of each property.The DDA portal was launched on December 16, 2019, letting the residents apply for the ownership rights online. The agency has also set up 25 help desks to help the applicants.DDA has outsourced the work of carrying out GIS mapping of properties for which applications have been received. After collecting location coordinates and site measurements of the properties, these companies are preparing the coordinates, maps, etc, which residents are submitting, making DDA’s job of processing the application smoother.The central agency has also set up processing centres near these unauthorised colonies. DDA has tried to put up help desks and processing centres at all clusters of the unauthorised colonies as it’s not possible to put up one each at every colony, a source said. After the verification, conveyance deeds of properties will be issued at these centres.While a conveyance deed gives ownership right to a property owner, he will need to get it registered to be able to sell it.

Title: DK police identify 123 spots prone to road accidents
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Head-on: File photo of an accident that happened in Bantwal

Mangaluru: The Dakshina Kannada police , which has recently conducted a survey, has identified 123 spots prone to road accidents or black spots. The survey reports have been submitted to the PWD and NHAI, requesting them to make necessary changes on the roads, which witness frequent accidents.

The survey was conducted recently under the leadership of superintendent of police B M Laxmi Prasad . The government, which has taken into consideration the report of the Dakshina Kannada district police of the border road from Mani to Kodagu, has earmarked Rs 2 crore to make necessary changes to rectify accident spots.

“The Dakshina Kannada police which operates in Bantwal, Sullia, Belthangady, Puttur and Kadaba taluks, recently conducted a survey to find out spots prone to accidents or black spots, which saw fatal and non-fatal accidents in the past few years. The survey was conducted by personnel of various police stations, and they found 123 accident spots on the Bantwal-Bengaluru highway, BC Road-Belthangady Road and Bantwal-Sampaje road (which is in the border of Kodagu district). Now, we have asked the government bodies who are responsible to take corrective measures to prevent accidents from happening,” Laxmi Prasad told TOI.

The highest fatal and non-fatal accidents occur on the Bantwal-Sampaje road. According to Laxmi Prasad, these roads are wide and motorists tend to speed here, resulting in many head-on collisions, which result in multiple deaths.

The measures include making curved roads straight so there is clear visibility , construction of proper drains beside roads, installation of speed breakers, pedestrian crossings, road strips, cat eyes or reflectors, road marking and sign boards, road widening in certain places, removal of shops or any hurdles, installation of lights wherever there is poor illumination, construction of safety walls and trimming of trees.

“These are all simple changes but will have a great impact when implemented, and help reduce accidents,” added Laxmi Prasad.

In the first phase, changes will be made on the Mani-Sampaje highway, which is about a 70 km stretch. The government has earmarked Rs 28 crore for road widening and other works, and also kept aside Rs 2 crore to make necessary arrangements in accident spots. “The work has already commenced,” said Laxmi Prasad, adding that work on the BC Road to Belthangady Road stretch will begin soon, but the Bantwal-Bengaluru highway road widening, which has been stalled, will take some time, as a fresh tender is necessary for the same.

Title: Stay alert about coronavirus but no need to panic: Experts
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Nagpur: There is lot of panic among people over coronavirus these days. WhatsApp forwards are adding to their confusion. Doctors, on the other hand, have told people not to panic at all as lots of screening, tranquillization, and treatment initiatives have been taken across the state.

People affected by this virus are mainly those who have travelled to China recently. Most of such passengers are getting screened at major international airports in the country. So far, no person affected with new coronavirus has been found in India.

As far as Nagpur is concerned, there is absolutely no need to panic as no flyer coming via China reaches Nagpur airport without screening at some or the other international airport. “Still, we have issued advisory to keep record of travellers coming via China. Even if they are non-infected, the government will keep track of their health record,” said Dr Sanjay Jaiswal, deputy director (health) for Nagpur division.

Public health system in government as well as private set-ups have been asked to stay alert.

Microbiologist Dr Ashwini Tayde said that following common respiratory antiquates and hand washing habits are points to remember for all of us. “Coronavirus is not new for microbiology. But, one new variant in this family has been found in China and it is creating panic. Coronavirus is responsible for common cold and flue-like illnesses. As a result, staying away from viral infections can be a good preventive measure,” she said.

According to her, majority of victims of new coronavirus in China are elderly and ill people. So, keeping yourself fit and fine is the best way to stay safe.

Another news creating panic among people is that doctors in China are using HIV drugs for treatment of illness caused by coronavirus. Dr Milind Bhrushundi, who is expert in HIV treatment, said the two viruses are different.

“No vaccine has been developed to treat the new coronavirus yet. So, doctors are trying different combinationsfar. One of them is a combination of lopinavir and ritonavir — drugs used for treatment of HIV. But, both these viruses function differently,” he said.

Even WHO advisory has stated that standard recommendations to reduce exposure to and transmission of a range of illnesses should be followed. This include maintaining basic hand and respiratory hygiene, safe food practices and avoiding close contact with anyone showing symptoms of respiratory illness such as coughing and sneezing.

Title: No action after 1st paper leak inquiry, new one in Palloti case
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur University (NU) board of examinations and evaluation (BoEE) has set up a panel to inquire into the alleged paper leak at St Vincent Palloti College of Engineering, where the model question paper on November 22 exactly matched the Engineering Chemistry paper of NU exam on December 7.

There has been no action, however, in a similar inquiry panel into an earlier paper leak at Kamala Nehru College of Pharmacy. Here, the model question given on December 6, 2019, matched NU’s BPharm 3rd semester Organic Pharmaceutical Chemistry III paper.

The inquiry in the second case was conducted by BoEE director Prafulla Sabale, Dean of Science and Technology GS Khadekar and a subject expert. Acting pro-VC Vinayak Deshpande is likely to take a final decision on action to be taken in this case.

Sabale and Khadekar, beside a subject expert, would also be holding an inquiry into the Palloti case, which the TOI had reported on January 26. Deshpande refused to comment on both issues.

NU officials said the panel for the pharmacy paper leak has recommended strict action against the paper setter and moderator. They said there was a possibility that questions in internal exams by chance matched those appearing in university exams.

“The question paper set that goes for print is chosen through a rigorous process. This can’t be a coincidence. But, it is also expected that a teacher would avoid giving same practice questions he or she has put for university exams during class tests or revision,” officials said.

They said apathy on the part of moderator too can’t be ruled out, and therefore the panel has recommended action against both.

However, there may not be any immediate action, as the Pro-VC would refer the case to Disciplinary Action Committee (DAC), which will take a long time.

Former NU chairman of mass communication board Sunil Mishra said vice chancellor SP Kane must lodge an FIR as per norms. “Both cases amount to playing fraud with the university,” he said.

Title: Respond to plea on lion relocation: SC
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

NEW DELHI: The SC sought the environment and forests ministry’s response to an NGO’s application seeking relocation of some Asiatic lions from their sole habitat in Gir forests of Gujarat to Madhya Pradesh to help strengthen conservation.

The case has been pending in the SC for long.

Title: Over 4K farmer suicides in last 19 years in Ngp div
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Nagpur: Despite efforts from the Central and state governments, farmer suicides continue unabated in the six Vidarbha districts coming under Nagpur division.

An RTI reply to activist Abhay Kolarkar’s queries stated that 4,286 farmers committed suicides in the six districts between 2001 and 2019, not only due to mounting debts, but also on account of nature’s vagaries, which often led to continuous crop failure on one or the other count — like unseasonal or excessive rains. Schemes like crop insurance too failed to stem the farmers’ deaths in the region.

The Maharashtra government, however, could find only 2,170 farmers’ families eligible for receiving compensation, while 2,042 were declared ineligible and 74 cases were pending for inquiry. In this period of 19 years, the government distributed compensation of over Rs21 crore.

Of all the deaths, 1,592 took place in the last five years, raising doubts over the government’s claim of providing aid to farmers through loan waivers and other schemes. The loan waivers introduced by both UPA and NDA governments also failed to grant any solace to the struggling farmers.

In reply to Kolarkar’s queries, Naib Tehsildar Padmashree Tasgaonkar of revenue section from the divisional commissioner’s office further informed that of over 4,000 deaths in Nagpur division, 3,086 took place between 2001 and 2015, and 1,200 since 2016.

Among the six districts, Wardha topped the list with 623 deaths, followed by Chandrapur with 352, Nagpur with 256, Bhandara with 206 and Gondia with 107. The naxal and tribal-dominated Gadchiroli witnessed 48 farmer deaths in the last five years — the least in the division.

Flaying the Central and state governments for ignoring the plight of farming community, Kolarkar said that while incomes in all sectors were rising, those in farming were still struggling to make ends meet. Successive governments failed to address the root cause for the large number of suicides and only indulged in pep talk for all these years, he said.

Title: Will kill rivals after joining reds: Man posts on social media
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Nagpur: Miffed by friends-turned-foes, a man posted a threat message on a social media group in Etapalli taluka vowing to eliminate his rivals after joining the Maoist movement in Gadchiroli district.

Police are trying to zero in on the man who posted the message in the wee hours of Thursday.

The man, who is allegedly debt-ridden, mentioned ‘Lal Salam’, a key word used by Maoists, at the top of his post which he ended with a dramatic phrase ‘yeh Raj Naxal commando ka vada raha’ (This is a promise of Maoist commander Raj). He elaborated by stating that he would ensure that four persons from Etapalli and one of Mulchera taluka will have to pay for breach of trust which made him desert his family, including his daughter.

SP Shailesh Balkawade said the man behind the message may not have joined the rebel outfit as of now but police are trying to verify his antecedents. “We are looking into the motive behind the post. He is debt-ridden,” said the SP.

Apart from settling scores with ‘traitors’, who led him to financial ruin, the man also intends to pay back his creditors and that too at their doorstep, after joining the movement.

Till the filing of this report, no complaint was lodged by the ones named in the post.

Title: Income Tax Dividend: Does your dividend income need to be taxed thrice?
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: If you attend any annual general meeting, inevitably you will find a shareholder standing up and demanding her fair share of dividend. While capital appreciation is one of the primary reasons why people seek to invest in equity , dividend income is always welcome.The sweetness, however, is blunted to some extent by the triple levy of tax on the dividend. Dividend is a distribution of ‘after tax’ profit of a company and the tax paid by the company is the first level of tax that dividend bears. Dividend Distribution Tax (DDT) is the second levy and the recently introduced ‘Super Rich Dividend Tax’ is the third. Shareholders earning dividend income of Rs 10 lakh or more have to bear a tax of 10% on such income. Thus, it comes as no surprise that both shareholders and companies are hoping for abolition of DDT.There are other challenges, too, for shareholders. If any expenditure is incurred in earning tax-free income, like dividend — say interest on borrowed funds for investments in equity, based on a formula, such expenditure is disallowed in the hands of the shareholder, as per the provisions of section 14A.Dividend, no matter the quantum, is tax-free in the hands of foreign shareholders. However, in most cases (unless the investment is structured via a few favourable countries such as Mauritius), investors cannot claim credit in their home country on the underlying tax — DDT.The triple whammy impact and a future scenario where DDT is abolished are explained by this illustration and the accompanying graphic: X is a small shareholder and has total income of less than Rs 5 lakh. In short, he does not bear any tax liability.Y earns dividend income of more than Rs 10 lakh and has total income of more than Rs 5 crore.In computing the scenario where DDT is abolished, it is presumed that the dividend income will be taxable in the hands of all shareholders at the applicable income-tax rates. While Budget 2020-21 may change the tax slabs/rates, the illustration uses the existing rates.Today, no country in the world has a DDT regime. While South Africa had introduced such a regime it was later abolished. Historically, in India, dividend has been taxed in the hands of shareholders and it was only in 1997 that DDT was introduced in the income-tax law. Interestingly, DDT was scrapped in 2002 only to be re-introduced in the next year on grounds of ease of tax administration.Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman has publicly termed DDT as regressive. Ideally, the DDT regime should be replaced by the classical system of taxing dividends in the hands of the shareholders. However, as seen in our illustration, given the high rate of surcharge of 37% in the hands of the super-rich, a concessional rate for taxing dividend income should be introduced.If this is done, it will not only help domestic shareholders, but also attract foreign investors who will get a foreign tax credit on the regular tax paid by them and not face the challenges relating to non-credit of DDT.

Title: IndiGo grounds comic Kunal Kamra for 6 months
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Comedian Kunal Kamra. (Credits: Twitter)

NEW DELHI: Civil aviation minister Hardeep Singh Puri has “advised” all national carriers to suspend Kunal Kamra from flying for the next six months following the comedian’s “unacceptable behaviour” with TV anchor Arnab Goswami on an IndiGo flight. Puri posted his views on Twitter after IndiGo had suspended Kamra for the same duration and tagged the minister. Late night, Air India too banned Kamra from its flights “until further notice”.

Kamra, while aboard a Mumbai-Lucknow flight, had asked Goswami for an explanation of his “journalism”. He tweeted a nearly 2-minute-long video around 4pm, with caption “I did this for my hero... I did it for Rohit (deceased Dalit scholar Rohith Vemula ).” It shows Kamra talking to Goswami, while the latter remains silent.

Hours after the video went viral, IndiGo tweeted a statement saying it had suspended Kamra from using its services for next six months. Within minutes, Puri tweeted back to Indigo replying, “Offensive behaviour designed to provoke & create disturbance inside an aircraft is absolutely unacceptable & endangers safety of air travellers. We are left with no option but to advise other airlines to impose similar restrictions on person concerned,” Puri wrote. This means Kamra’s name could feature in a No Fly List . Soon after the suspension, Kamra tweeted, “Thank you Indigo a six month suspension is honestly very kind of you... Modiji might be suspending Air India forever.”

Title: Khalistani ultra linked to killing of RSS activists shot in Lahore
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

LAHORE: A top member of a pro-Khalistan outfit, wanted in India, has been shot dead by two unidentified attackers outside a gurdwara near the Wagah Border, a police source said on Tuesday.

Harmeet Singh alias ‘Happy PhD’, a member of the Khalistan Liberation Force , was killed on Monday near Dera Chahal Gurdwara on the outskirts of Lahore, the source said.

Singh, who hailed from Amritsar and was allegedly involved in the murder of RSS members in Punjab in 2016-2017, was among eight Khalistan-linked terrorists against whom the Interpol had issued “red notices” last year.

No FIR has been registered over Singh’s murder.

“We have been asked not to pursue this case. Therefore, no FIR has been registered in the murder of Harmeet Singh,” the source said.

The law enforcement agencies have cordoned off the area near the gurdwara since Monday and no one, including journalists, are allowed to go there. The source said the body has not been shifted to any of Lahore’s morgue for autopsy. Asked about the murder, a police spokesperson, however, expressed his ignorance over it. “We have no knowledge of such an incident,” the spokesperson said.

There are reports that Singh was shot dead by a local gang over financial disputes related to drug smuggling.

Singh had a degree of doctorate that earned him the alias “PhD”.

Title: ‘Kids with 3 hours of screen time a day grow up less active’
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

NEW DELHI: Is your little one spending more time watching television, videos on phone or using computer? If so, you need to be careful. Children aged two to three years, who spend more than three hours a day viewing screens such as tablets and televisions, grow up to be less physically active at age 5.5 years, compared to those who used screens for an hour or less each day, says a new study published in Lancet.

The study found that excessive screen time in childhood is linked to a range of health problems, including increased risk of obesity and reduced cognitive development. Doctors say screen viewing is becoming common among children in India with working parents being busy and finding inadequate time to spend with them. Also, screen viewing often comes as an easier option for parents as they go about their chores.

“Screen viewing, especially at an early age, impacts functioning of the brain, cognitive functions, social interactions, mood regulation and academic performance,” says Dr Yatan Pal Singh Balhara, additional professor of psychiatry and in-charge of behavioural addictions clinic at AIIMS. “It is parents who initially decide for their children but if these children get habituated in their formative years, it becomes a lifestyle for them as they grow up with an addiction during adolescence,” he further states.

Doctors say screen-viewing influences health mainly because it replaces time that would otherwise be spent doing something else, like physical activity and sleep.

World Health Organisation has already classified addiction to digital and video gaming as a mental health disorder. The latest study, involving more than 500 children in Singapore and published in Lancet Child and Adolescent Health journal, suggests that adhering to WHO guidelines to limit screen time to one hour per day or less among children aged two to five years may promote healthier behaviour in later life.

Parents were asked to report how much time the children spent on average either watching or playing video games on TV, using a computer, or using a hand-held device like mobile phone or tablet. These screen habits were recorded when the children were aged two years and again at three. Children in the study spent an average of 2.5 hours a day watching screens at age 2-3 years. The findings revealed that children who had used screens for three or more hours a day at age two to three years spent an average of 40 minutes more time sitting down each day at age five than those who had used screens for less than an hour a day at the same ages.

Title: Tamil Nadu BJP’s ‘razor gift to Omar’ tweet gives it nicks and cuts
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Image courtesy: Twitter

NEW DELHI: BJP Tamil Nadu stirred an online controversy on Tuesday after it posted a tweet from its verified handle stating the party had sent a razor set to former J&K CM Omar Abdullah . The tweet was deleted after online outrage.

The post came after an image believed to be of Abdullah with a grizzled beard went viral on January 25, when 2G internet services were restored partially in the union territory, only to be snapped again.

On Tuesday, BJP’s state unit tweeted, “Dear Omar Abdullah. It is very disheartening to see you like this while your corrupt friends are enjoying life outside. Kindly accept our sincere contribution, in case of any assistance, feel free to contact ur (sic) counterpart (Congress) for further help in this regard.”

The tweet was accompanied by a screenshot of the delivery receipt of e-commerce website Amazon addressed to Omar’s residence. The parcel contained a razor set. The tweet was criticised by several users as insensitive, including journalists, following which it was deleted.

DMK spokesperson Manuraj S @manuraj1983 attacked the BJP over the tweet, “And then no one wondered why @BJP4TamilNadu gets lesser votes than NOTA in Tamil Nadu. (B)ad Taste. (J)uvenile. (P) uerile. Thy name is BJP. The lowering of political discourse is led by the BJP leadership and executed by its official social media handles,” he tweeted while quoting the BJP Tamil Nadu original post.

Title: CPM asks govt to stay away from pooling farmland
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The CPM Visakhapatnam district committee has demanded that the state government revoke the GO No 72, which was issued to facilitate pooling of about 6,150 acres of land in 10 mandals of the district for housing projects. In a press release, CPM district secretary K Lokanatham said that thousands of farmers in 64 villages in these mandals could barely eke out a living by cultivating these lands for the last several decades.

“As per the guidelines stipulated in the earlier government order No 294, the government should not pool lands being utilised for farming. Even the recent government order No 72 made it clear that the land pooling exercise shall follow the guidelines mentioned in the earlier order (GO No 294). But again the same order unfortunately included assigned lands and other lands being used for farming in the land pooling proposals,” said Lokanatham.

“As per the government order, the assignees will get 900 square yards developed plot per an acre. The encroachers who have settled in these lands for more than 10 years will be given 450 square yards plot per an acre, while the encroachers for 5 to 10 years will get 250 square yards land. It is very unfortunate to mention these farmers as encroachers in the order. It is purely government’s mistake to not regularise the lands in the name of the farmers, ” said Lokanatham.

Title: More than one lakh students to take Inter exams in EG
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Rajahmundry: Arrangements have been to conduct Intermediate exams in East Godavari district which will be taken by 1,09,334 students.

I Sarada, regional inspection officer, Rajahmundry, on Tuesday said strict vigilance would be maintained at all centres to conduct the exams peacefully. She said that the practical exams would commence from February 1 and end on February 20. Around 32,400 students will appear at the 90 centres in the district in four spells. The main exams will commence on Mrach 4 and end on March 23. They will be conducted in 139 centres.

District Level Monitoring Committes headed by collectors and comprising SP and other senior officials will closely monitor the exams. Task forces and flying squads will also be constituted for the purpose.

The RIO said it is for the first time that facility the Intermediate Board has made available the facility to download hall tickets directly by students.

A special control room with number 08832473430 has been established at the RIO’s office to answer students queries.

Title: Drones, satellite images help torch 500 acres of ganja crop
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A special task force, comprising officials of the prohibition and excise department have destroyed ganja plantations across 500 acres land over the last one month in Visakhapatnam Agency with the help of drones and satellite images and the support of the police, forest and revenue departments.

Now, officials are chalking out plans to destroy ganja plantations in 4,000 acres land. While the government agencies are being vigilant, rooting out ganja cultivation in the area remains a challenge as the green drug is cultivated across 15,000 acres land across the Agency.

The special task force began the exercise of destroying ganja plantations across 4,000 acres land in a bid to root out its cultivation in the Agency and parts of East Godavari district in September 2017.

Speaking to TOI, T Srinivas Rao, deputy excise commissioner of Visakhapatnam said that the special task force has destroyed ganja across 4,300 acres land since 2017 in seven mandals of the Agency. “The drive to destroy ganja will continue,” he added.

Meanwhile, officials of ITDA (Integrated Tribal Development Agency), Paderu have come forward to help tribals switch from growing ganja to growing rajma, millets, turmeric and other cash crops.

“We hope our drives will yield results as more ganja growers will switch to other crops. We are using drones and satellite images to identify plantations in remote areas,” Srinivas Rao further said.

On the other hand, K Surendra of CPI(M) said that some farmers are managing to make a lot of money by growing ganja, which is why they are averse to switching crops.

Surendra further said that the special task force has only managed to destroy ganja plantations in roadside villages and the force is hesitant to foray into remote areas suspecting the presence of Maoists and possibility of facing resistance from tribals.

Sources informed that many ganja growers are reluctant to switch to other crops is because of its high profitability.

However, the cultivation, smuggling, selling, buying and consumption of ganja are punishable under the NDPS Act, said ACP (Task Force), Vizag , A Trinad Rao. He added that many people, from tribals to inter-state land sharks are involved in the trade.

According to activist G Srinivas, most of the ganja cultivation occurs in remote areas along the Andhra-Odisha border. Srinivas said that if officials can put an end to investment in the crop, tribals will gradually migrate to other crops.

Title: Businessman robbed in west Delhi
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: A 23-year-old man was choked and his bag and wallet were robbed by two persons in West Delhi's Hari Nagar on Sunday night.

The incident was also captured in the CCTV cameras installed near the crime spot. The footage showed one of the accused men grabbing the victim by his neck until he fell unconscious.

While a case was registered in this connection, no arrests had been made till Tuesday night.

According to police, the incident took place around 10.30 pm on Gurdwara road. The victim, Dheeraj Gosain, runs his own business.

"I had got down at Mayapuri metro station and while I was walking on Gurdwara road, a man grabbed me by the neck from behind. I thought it was one of my friends joking around but as the grip got tighter I realised there was something wrong. I fell unconscious in a few minutes and they fled with my wallet and bag," Gosain told TOI.

The accused duo, who fled on a scooter, were not wearing a helmet. Their faces were clearly visible in the CCTV footage.

Title: Nearly 500 screened, no cases detected
Content: Visakhapatnam: Following the outbreak of the coronavirus in China, the Port City too is on high alert. Medical teams have screened 500 travellers since the alert was sounded across the country.Medical and health officer Dr S Tirupati Rao said on Tuesday that no suspected cases have been detected in Visakhapatnam, but the airport, port and the railway station are being kept under strict vigil.Tirupati Rao informed that two separate wards have been allocated at King George Hospital to quarantine patients suspected to have been infected.The officer further said that arrangements have also been made to send samples to the National Institute of Virology in Pune for tests in case someone is suspected to have been infected.Speaking to TOI, PL Haranadh, deputy chairman of Visakhapatnam Port said that the port authorities receive nearly 10 vessels from China, Hong Kong and Vietnam in a month. “We have checked the crew of the vessel which came from China. No cases have been detected,” he added. He further said that China-bound vessels that have come to the port in the last 28 days have been asked to undergo screening.Dr KSLG Sastry, chief medical officer of GVMC said that the civic body is planning to organise awareness campaigns near the port, the airport and the railway station.Since the virus spread through seafood in Wuhan, China, the fisheries department has alerted fishermen about taking precautions while handling seafood.K Phani Prakash, joint director of Visakhapatnam fisheries said that a meeting will be called with seafood exporters and fishermen soon. Railway officials said that they have also started alerting passengers as many people travel in trains such as Godavari, Garibrath and Duronto after alighting from international flights from China or Hong Kong.

Title: GVMC urges citizens to vote on social media
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Visakhapatnam: With only three days left for the conclusion of the annual urban cleanliness survey ( Swachh Survekshan ) 2020, civic authorities are gearing up to introduce a few initiatives to keep the city clean.

Meanwhile, the Garbage-Free Cities (GFC) team will continue their inspection for the next two days. Since the city will be evaluated on collection and processing of solid waste, GVMC authorities have urged the citizens to segregate waste at the source. They have also requested the people to support GFC, ODF and ban of single-use plastic, which are the main indicators of Swachh Survekshan. Since, feedback of people also carries 25% weightage in the survey, the municipal authorities are organising awareness campaigns at schools and colleges.

People can vote for Visakhapatnam through the SS2020 Vote For Your City app as well as through the official website. People can also vote on Twitter and Facebook.

Dr KSLG Sastry, chief medical officer of health, GVMC, said, “To bridge the gap between people and the municipality, we are creating social media accounts for the civic staff of respective zones. ”

Title: 10 more Indian wetlands get global importance tag
Content: NEW DELHI: Ten more Indian wetland sites, including the first from Maharashtra, have received the tag of international importance under the Ramsar Convention — an inter-governmental global treaty to preserve ecological character of selected wetlands across the globe.With the addition of these ten sites, one in Maharashtra, three in Punjab and six in Uttar Pradesh, the list of wetlands in India under the Convention has grown to 37 with surface area of over 10,679 sq km, an area nearly the size of Sikkim and Goa put together.India’s list of 37 includes Sambhar lake of Rajasthan which had last year seen mass mortality of migratory birds due to avian botulism caused by a bacteria. This saline lake had entered the global list in 1990. Globally, there are over 2,300 Ramsar sites around the world, covering over 2.1 million sq km.The new Indian sites include Nandur Madhameshwar bird sanctuary (Maharashtra); Beas conservation reserve, Keshopur-Miani community reserve and Nangal wildlife sanctuary (Punjab); Nawabganj bird sanctuary, Parvati Arga bird sanctuary, Saman bird sanctuary, Sarsai Nawar lake, Samaspur bird sanctuary and Sandi bird sanctuary (Uttar Pradesh).“The site (Nandur Madhameshwar) is used by diverse group of species especially by resident birds for breeding and by migratory birds as a winter stopover site,” tweeted Union environment minister Prakash Javadekar while congratulating Maharashtra on getting its first Ramsar site.Under the Ramsar (Iran) Convention of 1971, the member countries identify those sites which are recognised as being of significant value not only for the country or the countries in which they are located, but for humanity as a whole.“The inclusion of a wetland in the list embodies the government’s commitment to take steps necessary to ensure that its ecological character is maintained. The Convention includes various measures to respond to threats to the ecological character of sites,” said the global accord on its website.The wetlands — land areas covered by water, either temporarily\seasonally or permanently — play a key role in flood control, water supply and providing food, fibre and raw materials. Besides, such land areas also support migratory birds from colder regions of the world in summers, apart from mangroves that protect coastlines and filter pollutants.Sharing information on new Ramsar sites ahead of the World Wetlands Day (February 2), the environment ministry on Tuesday claimed that it has prepared a four-pronged strategy for the restoration of wetlands which includes preparing a baseline data, wetland health cards, enlisting wetland ‘mitras’ (friends) and preparation of targeted Integrated Management Plans.The ministry had on January 6 notified new guidelines for implementing Wetlands (Conservation and Management) Rules, 2017 which prohibit setting up or expansion of industries, and disposal of construction and demolition waste within the wetlands.

Title: AU students protest semester, exam fee hike
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A large number of postgraduate students of Andhra University staged a protest demonstration on Tuesday, demanding the varsity to roll back the fee hike . Protesting students alleged that the exam fee was increased to Rs 1,200 from Rs 800.

Speaking to TOI, SFI Greater Visakha City committee secretary LJ Naidu said that the first-year semester fee of a few of the Arts courses has been increased to Rs 2,850 from Rs 2,050. “Likewise, the second-year semester fee was hiked to Rs 2,700 from Rs 1,900. A majority of the students of Andhra University belong to weaker sections and rural and tribal parts of the region. The nearly 50% fee hike is sheer injustice to them,” said Naidu.

Meanwhile, registrar Prof V Krishna Mohan tried to pacify the students . He said the university’s executive committee took the decision a year ago.

But, L Chinnari, SFI Visakhapatnam city committee president, said students had no clue about the fee hike. “They came to know about it only after they approached the varsity office to pay the fee. Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy promised to reimburse 100% tuition fee of the students. But now how can the state government increase the fees?,” questioned Chinnari.

The AU students told TOI that university authorities have promised to address the issue in the next few days. tnn

Title: Fresh search: Still some miles to go before AU gets new VC
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The state government issued a fresh notification on January 27 overriding the previous notification inviting applicants for the position of the vice-chancellor of Andhra University . It will be followed up by the setting up of a new search committee.

After the then incumbent vice-chancellor Professor G Nageswara Rao’s tenure came to an end in July 2019, Prof PVGD Prasad Reddy was given the additional charge of vice-chancellor. Consequently, the state government invited applications for the post and constituted a committee in August to select three suitable candidates.

After a series of meetings and scrutiny of more than 100 applications, the search committee submitted its report to the government about three months ago. But with the new notification, the selection process may be protracted.

According to well-placed sources, although the search committee received more than 100 applications for the post of vice-chancellor. “But a total of only 20 names were short-listed in the preliminary stage and finally three names were chosen. But we don’t know why they cancelled the earlier notification,” the source said.

The state government’s decision however has led to several speculations among varsity circles. There were discussions on how the new notification and committee may affect the chances of serious contenders for the post.

Andhra University has to expend the Rs 100 crore given to it in the second phase of the Rashtriya Uchchatar Shiksha Abhiyan (RUSA) scheme by April 2020 to become eligible for receiving Rs 1,000 crore funds in the third phase.

Andhra University is one of the 10 state universities from across the country to get the Rs 1,000 crore assurance from ministry of human resource development. The delay in the appointment of a new vice-chancellor may adversely affect the RUSA project.

Title: Rains expected across north AP
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Light to moderate rains or thundershowers are likely to occur at places over north-coastal Andhra Pradesh and Yanam in the next 24 hours, according to India Meteorological Department (IMD) Meteorological Centre, Amaravati.

According to a weather bulletin issued on Tuesday evening by the IMD, light to moderate rains will occur due to change in weather conditions from winter to summer.

However, dry weather conditions will prevail across the north-coastal region of the state and Yanam from January 30 to January 31. Rains are likely to resume on February 1.

Title: Gallantry medal for 2 ICG personnel
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Two Coast Guard personnel from Vizag received the Tatrakshak gallantry medal for saving many lives during the devastating fire on-board Coastal Jaguar, an offshore support vessel, off Vizag coast on April 12 last year.

Subordinate officer SK Singh Adhikari, who is presently posted on-board Coast Guard ship Samudra Paheredar, and sailor Subhash from ICG ship Rani Rashmoni were honoured with the medals on Republic Day. Samudra Paheredar is on deployment to West Asian countries, and was in Doha (Qatar) when the news of the subordinate officer being bestowed with the gallantry medal reached the ship. P Kumaran, ambassador of India to Qatar, felicitated Adhikari for saving the lives of several mariners by risking his own life.

The other recipients of Tatrakshak medal are DIG Mukul Garg, and deputy commandants Abhishek Kumar and IK Balan, who are posted at the maritime force’s regional headquarters (A and N), ICGS Rajveer (Port Blair) and ICGAS Ratnagiri, respectively.

Meanwhile, Samudra Paheredar has left Doha after completing its four-day goodwill visit to Qatar. On its third leg, the ship will visit Saudi Arabia, where it will be stationed till January 31. During its stay in Doha, cross-deck visits and professional interactions between the maritime agencies of both countries were undertaken. In addition, the ship was kept open for the Indian diaspora in Qatar to visit and interact with Coast Guard officials.

Title: Indian Pompano species harvested successfully in marine cage culture
Content: Visakhapatnam: Showcasing success of the marine cage culture, Indian Pompano species harvested from a marine cage were displayed at the Fishing Harbour on Tuesday.In a research initiative by the Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute (CMFRI) and funded by the National Fisheries Development Board (NFDB), a partial harvest of nearly 500 kg fish was done from one of the five cages where the pompano species is being reared in Visakhapatnam . Much of the harvested fish will be sent to Kerala.In each HDPE (high density polyethylene) cage of 6 metre diameter and 3.5 metre depth, around 2,500-3,000 fingerlings were stocked from end of May to beginning of June, 2019.After eight months of culture, with around 90 % survival rate, the fish are now ready for harvest, yielding around 2-2.5 tonnes of fish from each cage. CMFRI pioneered cage culture of pompano and orange spotted grouper species in 2015-16.Dr Shubhadeep Ghosh, principal scientist of Visakhapatnam regional centre of CMFRI said, “Fingerlings were initially fed artificial pellets containing 45% protein. Average body weight at harvest ranges around 700 gms. The cost of production is around Rs 220 per kg and the market price is Rs 320-Rs 350 per kg. In 2015, for the first time in the world, CMFRI grew seeds of the Indian Pompano species. The institute has produced over two lakh seeds so far. The species is scarce in the wild but can withstand a wide variety of temperatures and salinity and is suited for cage culture. NFDB has provided funds worth Rs 3.5 crore for 100 cages in Andhra Pradesh. There are 20 cages installed at various sites off Vizag coast.Imelda Joseph, head of the mariculture division of CMFRI, Kochi averred that the government needs to support and facilitate marketing of the harvested fish. KM Dipin, executive from NFDC stated that 100 marine cages have been sanctioned by NFDC for AP and 3,000 across Indian coasts.In Video: Vizag: Indian Pompano species harvested from a marine cage displayed at fishing harbour

Title: CAA Protest in Vizag: Protest in city against CAA, NRC
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Activists of various organisations came together under the banner of Protection of Constitutional Right Committee (PCRC) to protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and the National Register of Citizens ( NRC ). The protestors staged a demonstration at the Mahatma Gandhi statue near the GVMC administrative office on Tuesday.

Speaking on the occasion, B Ganga Rao of CPI(M) said that the BJP government, under the leadership of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, is spoiling the ‘unity and sovereignty’ of the nation. “People from all over the country have united against NRC and CAA,” he said.

Rao further said that the BJP government has failed to address issues of unemployment, white collar offences and inflation and has been trying to divide the nation by introducing CAA and NRC in the country.

“We have decided to organise satyagraha against CAA and NRC on January 30. CAA and NRC will lead to violence and will hurt the development of the nation,” another protester said.

Title: CRPF screens its 3 lakh staff after Jammu and Kashmir DSP’s terror expose
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

GURGAON: The CRPF has carried out a mega audit of its over three lakh personnel to check for any possible “subversive” elements in the wake of a Jammu & Kashmir Police officer being caught with terrorists recently, the chief of the paramilitary force said here on Tuesday.

CRPF Director General (DG) A P Maheshwari said the incident involving Deputy Superintendent of Police Davinder Singh was “grave” and an “area of extreme concern” for the security forces, adding that all should see that these things don’t occur.

So it was “common sense” to carry out such an audit of its manpower, deployed as the lead force for counter-terrorist and anti-Naxal operations across the country, when any incident like this take place, he said.

A senior official said the counter-intelligence units of the force were recently asked to check the credentials of the personnel after obtaining data from all available sources and they have been asked to be kept on “active mode” for some more time.

“No security grid should be allowed to be weakened by such episodes. So, all forces have to keep an internal watch,” he said on the arrest of DSP Singh.

J&K Police had arrested Singh in J&K’s Kulgam district along with Hizbul Mujahideen terrorists Naveed Baba and Altaf, besides a lawyer who was operating as an overground worker for terror outfits, on January 11.

Maheshwari said that somebody from a security force trying to collaborate with adversaries is a “serious matter”. However, he added that a lone incident cannot be used to “brand” the entire force which has done onerous work in the past.

CRPF has deployed close to 70,000 personnel in Kashmir Valley for counter-terrorist and law and order duties.

Title: Rajini shoots for Bear Grylls, makes meme makers go wild
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Rajinikanth

CHENNAI: Question: What did Bear Grylls tell Narendra Modi at Jim Corbett last year? Answer: It’s my job to keep you safe. Question: What did Rajinikanth tell Bear Grylls at Bandipur Tiger Reserve on Tuesday? Answer: It’s my job to keep you safe.

From the moment ‘Superstar’ entered the Karnataka forest, meme creators have gone wild. By Tuesday, social media was celebrating stills from Rajinikanth’s old films in which he was seen with wild animals. The tagline read: ‘Leaked scenes from Rajini Vs Wild’.

Stills from ‘Annai Or Aalayam’, in which Rajinikanth plays a hunter, ‘Siva’, in which he confronts a leopard, and ‘ Padayappa ’, in which he kisses a cobra, after picking it up from its hideout were the hot favourites on social media.

Rajinikanth’s characters were not always that brave when it came to animals. A scene in ‘Thambikku Endha Ooru’ (1984) was a laugh riot as it shows a cobra entering Rajinikanth’s room.

Rajinikanth, who was busy shooting in Hyderabad for his 168th film, allocated two days for “Man Vs Wild” episode.

Title: Woman to pilot Central Railway's first AC local, hopes to run Rajdhani Express later
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

Manisha Mhaske worked as an assistant driver on a goods train after joining in 2002

MUMBAI: Manisha Mhaske (45) is rapidly gaining speed in her career. Starting out as an assistant driver on a goods train, she graduated to suburban locals, and now hopes to be in the driver's seat of the Rajdhani.

Mhaske will pilot the first AC train on Central Railway 's trans-harbour corridor between Thane and Panvel when services begin on January 30. Sixteen services will run on the corridor, of which three each will be in morning and evening peak hours.

Mhaske, who joined CR as an assistant driver in January 2002 has been piloting electrical multiple unit services since September 2019. "It is a privilege and big responsibility. I will cherish this moment forever," said Mhaske.

Her career took off after a vocational course in electronics. Initially, she was not keen on the railway job when she was selected. "I was told to join duty in Solapur. I was not keen, but my elder brother pushed me," said Mhaske, who stays with her husband in Badlapur.

Joining in 2002, she worked as an assistant driver on goods trains and later worked as a driver for a decade before being promoted as motorwoman. She is the only motorwoman to pilot a suburban train, even though there are two female seniors on the rota.

CR's chief public relations officer Shivaji Sutar said, "She is an excellent driver with a superb track record. Mhaske has never been involved in incidents like jumping a red signal or overshooting a platform."

Mhaske, who grew up in Ulhasnagar, said, "My ultimate aim is to pilot Rajdhani Express once I graduate to be a mail/express driver."

On why a woman was chosen to pilot the train, Sutar said, "CR has always taken decisions to empower women. We got an all-woman TTE train. Matunga station, India's first woman-only station, is another shining example. Mhaske's piloting the train will inspire many other women to take up the profession."

Title: I-T dept withdraws penalty appeal against Rajinikanth
Content:
This story is from January 29, 2020

CHENNAI: The Madras HC on Tuesday dismissed as withdrawn an Income Tax department appeal against Rajinikanth in respect of assessment for three years from 2002-03 after the department cited a CBDT circular doing away with further legal challenge in matters involving amount less than Rs 1 crore.
